Sophia has told some\r\nof her acquaintance, and all Deerbrook will hear it before long, that\r\nher cousins have withdrawn from the book club on account of Hester\'s\r\nsituation; that they are to be so busy with the baby that is coming,\r\nthat they will have no time to read."\r\n\r\n"As long as the Hopes are above false pretences, they need not care for\r\nsuch as are made for them.  There! show mamma what a nice plump walnut\r\nyou have cracked for her."\r\n\r\n"Nicely done, my pet.  But, Mr Rowland, the Hopes cannot hold out.\r\nThey cannot possibly stay here.  You will not get their rent at\r\nChristmas, depend upon it."\r\n\r\n"I shall not press them for it, I assure you."\r\n\r\n"Then you will be unjust to your family.  You owe it to your children,\r\nto say nothing of myself, to look after your property."\r\n\r\n"I owe it to them not to show myself a harsh landlord to excellent\r\ntenants.  But we need not trouble ourselves about what will happen at\r\nChristmas.  It may be that the rent will make its appearance on the\r\nmorning of quarter-day."\r\n\r\n"Then, if not, you will give them notice that the house is let from the\r\nnext quarter, will you not?"\r\n\r\n"By no means, my dear."\r\n\r\n"If you do not like to undertake the office yourself, perhaps you will\r\nlet me do it.  I have a good deal of courage about doing disagreeable\r\nthings, on occasion."\r\n\r\n"You have, my dear; but I do not wish that this should be done.  I mean,\r\nI desire that it be not done.  The Hopes shall live in that house of\r\nmine as long as they please.  And if," continued Mr Rowland, not liking\r\nthe expression of his lady\'s eye,--"if any one disturbs them in their\r\npresent abode--the consequence will be that I shall be compelled to\r\ninvite them here.  I shall establish them in this very house, sooner\r\nthan that they shall be obliged to leave Deerbrook against their will;\r\nand then, my dear, you will have to be off to Cheltenham again."\r\n\r\n"What nonsense you talk, Mr Rowland!  Who should disturb them, if you\r\nwon\'t be open to reason, so as to do it yourself?  I thought you knew\r\nenough of what it is to be ridden by poor tenants, to wish to avoid the\r\nplague, if warned in time.  But some people can never take warning."\r\n\r\n"Let us see that you can, my love.  You will remember what I have said\r\nabout the Hopes being disturbed, I have no doubt.  And now we have done\r\nwith that, I want to tell you--"\r\n\r\n"Presently, when we have really done with this subject, my dear.  I have\r\nother reasons--"\r\n\r\n"Which you will spare me the hearing.  My dear Priscilla, there are no\r\nreasons on earth which can justify me in turning this family out of\r\ntheir house, or you in asking me to do it.  Let us hear no more about\r\nit."\r\n\r\n"But you must hear.  I will be heard on a subject in which I have such\r\nan interest, Mr Rowland."\r\n\r\n"Ring the bell, my little fellow.  Pull hard.  That\'s it--Candles in the\r\noffice immediately."\r\n\r\nAnd Mr Rowland tossed off the last half of his glass of port, kissed\r\nthe little ones, and was gone.  The lady remained to compassionate\r\nherself; which she did very deeply, that she could find no means of\r\nridding herself of the great plague of her life.  These people were\r\nalways in her way, and no one would help her to dislodge them.  Her own\r\nhusband was against her--quite unmanageable and perverse.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THIRTY EIGHT.\r\n\r\nTHE VICTIMS.\r\n\r\nIf Mrs Rowland was dissatisfied with her success, while seeing that\r\nsome resources of comfort remained to the Hopes and Margaret, a view of\r\nthe interior of the corner-house would probably have affected her\r\ndeeply, and set her moralising on the incompleteness of all human\r\ntriumphs.  There was peace there which even she could not invade--could\r\nonly, if she had known it, envy.  Her power was now exhausted, and her\r\nwork was unfinished.  For many weeks, she had made Margaret as miserable\r\nas she had intended to make her.  Margaret had suffered from an\r\nexasperating sense of injury; but that was only for a few hours.  Hers\r\nwas not a nature which could retain personal resentment for any length\r\nof time.  She needed the relief of compassionate and forgiving feelings;\r\nand she cast herself into them for solace, as the traveller, emerging\r\nfrom the glaring desert, throws himself down beside the gushing spring\r\nin the shade.  From the moment that she did this, it became her chief\r\ntrouble that Philip was blamed by others.  Her friends said as little as\r\nthey could in reference to him, out of regard for her feelings; but she\r\ncould not help seeing that Maria\'s indignation was strong, and that\r\nHester considered that her sister had had a happy escape from a man\r\ncapable of treating her as Philip had done.  If it had been possible to\r\nundertake his defence, Margaret would have done so.  As there were no\r\nmeans of working upon others to forgive her wrongs, she made it her\r\nconsolation to forgive them doubly herself; to cheer up under them; to\r\nlive for the aim of being more worthy of Philip\'s love, the less he\r\nbelieved her to be so.  Her lot was far easier now than it had been in\r\nthe winter.  She had been his; and she believed that she still occupied\r\nhis whole soul.  She was not now the solitary, self-despising being she\r\nhad felt herself before.  Though cut off from intercourse with him as if\r\nthe grave lay between them, she knew that sympathy with her heart and\r\nmind existed.  She experienced the struggles, the moaning efforts, of\r\naffections doomed to solitude and silence; the shrinking from a whole\r\nlong life of self-reliance, of exclusion from domestic life; the\r\noccasional horror of contemplating the waste and withering of some of\r\nthe noblest parts of the immortal nature,--a waste and withering which\r\nare the almost certain consequence of violence done to its instincts and\r\nits laws.  From these pains and terrors she suffered; and from some of\r\nsmaller account,--from the petty insults, or speculations of the more\r\ncoarse-minded of her neighbours, and the being too suddenly reminded by\r\npassing circumstances of the change which had come over her expectations\r\nand prospects; but her love, her forgiveness, her conviction of being\r\nbeloved, bore her through all these, and saved her from that fever of\r\nthe heart, in the paroxysms of which she had, in her former and severer\r\ntrial, longed for death, even for non-existence.\r\n\r\nShe could enjoy but little of what had been her favourite solace at that\r\ntime.  She had but few opportunities now for long solitary walks.  She\r\nsaw the autumn fading away, melting in rain and cold fog, without its\r\nhaving been made use of.  It had been as unfavourable a season as the\r\nsummer,--dreary, unproductive, disappointing in every way; but there had\r\nbeen days in the latter autumn when the sun had shown his dim face, when\r\nthe dank hedges had looked fresh, and the fallen leaves in the\r\nwood-paths had rustled under the tread of the squirrel; and Margaret\r\nwould on such days have liked to spend the whole morning in rambles by\r\nherself.  But there were reasons why she should not.  Almost before the\r\nchilliness of the coming season began to be felt, hardship was\r\ncomplained of throughout the country.  The prices of provisions were\r\ninordinately high; and the evil consequences which, in the rural\r\ndistricts, follow upon a scarcity, began to make themselves felt.  The\r\npoachers were daring beyond belief; and deep was the enmity between the\r\nlarge proprietors and the labourers around them.  The oldest men and\r\nwomen, and children scarcely able to walk, were found trespassing day by\r\nday in all plantations, with bags, aprons, or pinafores, full of\r\nfir-cones, and wood snapped off from the trees, or plucked out of the\r\nhedges.  There was no end to repairing the fences.  There were\r\nunpleasant rumours, too, of its being no longer safe to walk singly in\r\nthe more retired places.  No such thing as highway robbery had ever\r\nbefore been heard of at Deerbrook, within the memory of the oldest\r\ninhabitant; the oldest of the inhabitants being Jim Bird, the man of a\r\nhundred years.  But there was reason now for the caution.  Mr Jones\'s\r\nmeat-cart had been stopped on the high-road, by two men who came out of\r\nthe hedge, and helped themselves to what the cart contained.  An\r\nill-looking fellow had crossed the path of Mrs James and her young\r\nsister in the Verdon woods, evidently with the intention of stopping the\r\nladies; but luckily the jingling of a timber-wain was heard below, and\r\nthe man had retreated.  Mr Grey had desired that the ladies of his\r\nfamily would not go further without his escort than a mile out and back\r\nagain on the high-road.  They were not to attempt the lanes.  The Miss\r\nAndersons no longer came into Deerbrook in their pony-chaise; and Mrs\r\nHowell reported to all her customers that Lady Hunter never walked in\r\nher own grounds without a footman behind her, two dogs before her, and\r\nthe game-keeper within hearing of a scream.  Mr Walcot was advised to\r\nleave his watch and purse at home when he set forth to visit his country\r\npatients; and it did not comfort him much to perceive that his\r\nneighbours were always vigilant to note the hour and minute of his\r\nsetting forth, and to learn the precise time when he might be looked for\r\nat home again.  It was observed, that he was generally back half-an-hour\r\nsooner than he was expected, with a very red face, and his horse all in\r\na foam.\r\n\r\nIn addition to these grounds of objection to solitary walks, Margaret\r\nhad strong domestic reasons for denying herself the rambles she\r\ndelighted in.  As the months rolled on, poverty pressed closer and\r\ncloser.  When the rent was secured, and some of the comforts provided\r\nwhich Hester must have in her confinement, so little was left that it\r\nbecame necessary to limit the weekly expenses of the family to a sum\r\nsmall enough to require the nicest management, and the most strenuous\r\ndomestic industry, to make it suffice.  Hope would not pledge his credit\r\nwhile he saw so little prospect of redeeming it.  His family were of one\r\nmind as to purchasing nothing which they were not certainly able to pay\r\nfor.  This being his principle, he made every effort to increase his\r\nfunds.  A guinea or two dropped in now and then, in return for\r\ncontributions to medical periodicals.  Money was due to him from some of\r\nhis patients.  To these he sent in his bills again, and even made\r\npersonal application.  From several he obtained promises; from two or\r\nthree the amount of whose debt was very small, he got his money,\r\ndisgraced by smiles of wonder and contempt.  From the greater number he\r\nreceived nothing but excuses on account of the pressure of the times.\r\nThe small sums he did recover were of a value which none of the three\r\nhad ever imagined that money could be to them.  Every little extra\r\ncomfort thus obtained,--the dinner of meat once oftener in the week, the\r\nfire in the evening, the new gloves for Hope, when the old ones could no\r\nlonger, by any mending, be made to look fit for him,--what a luxury it\r\nwas!  And all the more for being secretly enjoyed.  No one out of the\r\nhouse had a suspicion how far their poverty had gone.  Mr Grey had\r\nreally been vexed at them for withdrawing from the book club; had\r\nattributed this instance of economy to the "enthusiasm" which was, in\r\nhis eyes, the fault of the family; and never dreamed of their not dining\r\non meat, vegetables, and pudding, with their glass of wine, every day.\r\nThe Greys little knew what a blessing they were conferring on their\r\ncousins, when they insisted on having them for a long day once more\r\nbefore Hester\'s confinement, and set them down to steaming soup, and a\r\nplentiful joint, and accompaniments without stint.  The guests laughed,\r\nwhen they were at home again, over the new sort of pleasure they had\r\nfelt, the delight at the sight of a good dinner, to which nothing was\r\nwanting but that Morris should have had her share.  Morris, for her\r\npart, had been very happy at home.  She had put aside for her mistress\'s\r\nluncheon next day, the broth which she had been told was for her, and\r\nhad feasted on potatoes and water, and the idea of the good dinner her\r\nyoung ladies were to enjoy.  While their affairs were in this state, it\r\nwas a great luxury in the family to have any unusual comfort which\r\nbetokened that Hope had been successful in some of his errands,--had\r\nreceived a fee, or recovered the amount of a bill.  One day, Morris\r\nbrought in a goose and giblets, which had been bought and paid for by\r\nMr Hope, the messenger said.  Another morning, came a sack of apples,\r\nfrom the orchard of a country patient who was willing to pay in kind.\r\nAt another time Edward emptied his pockets of knitted worsted stockings\r\nand mittens, the handiwork of a farmer\'s dame, who was flattered by his\r\ntaking the produce of her evening industry instead of money, which she\r\ncould not well spare at the present season.  There was more mirth, more\r\nreal gladness in the house, on the arrival of windfalls like these, than\r\nif Hope had daily exhibited a purse full of gold.  There was no sting in\r\ntheir poverty; no adventitious misery belonging to it.  They suffered\r\nits genuine force, and that was all.\r\n\r\nWhat is Poverty?  Not destitution, but poverty?  It has many shapes,--\r\naspects almost as various as the minds and circumstances of those whom\r\nit visits.  It is famine to the savage in the wilds; it is hardship to\r\nthe labourer in the cottage; it is disgrace to the proud; and to the\r\nmiser despair.  It is a spectre which "with dread of change perplexes"\r\nhim who lives at ease.  Such are its aspects: but what is it?  It is a\r\ndeficiency of the comforts of life,--a deficiency present and to come.\r\nIt involves many other things; but this is what it is.  Is it then worth\r\nall the apprehension and grief it occasions?  Is it an adequate cause\r\nfor the gloom of the merchant, the discontent of the artisan, the\r\nforeboding sighs of the mother, the ghastly dreams which haunt the\r\navaricious, the conscious debasement of the subservient, the humiliation\r\nof the proud?  These are severe sufferings; are they authorised by the\r\nnature of poverty?  Certainly not, if poverty induced no adventitious\r\nevils, involved nothing but a deficiency of the comforts of life,\r\nleaving life itself unimpaired.  "The life is more than food, and the\r\nbody than raiment;" and the untimely extinction of the life itself would\r\nnot be worth the pangs which apprehended poverty excites.  But poverty\r\ninvolves woes which, in their sum, are far greater than itself.  To a\r\nmultitude it is the loss of a pursuit which they have yet to learn will\r\nbe certainly supplied.  For such, alleviation or compensation is in\r\nstore, in the rising up of objects new, and the creation of fresh hopes.\r\nThe impoverished merchant, who may no longer look out for his argosies,\r\nmay yet be in glee when he finds it "a rare dropping morning for the\r\nearly colewort."  To another multitude, poverty involves loss of rank,--\r\na letting down among strangers whose manners are ungenial, and their\r\nthoughts unfamiliar.  For these there may be solace in retirement, or\r\nthe evil may fall short of its threats.  The reduced gentlewoman may\r\nlive in patient solitude, or may grow into sympathy with her neighbours,\r\nby raising some of them up to herself, and by warming her heart at the\r\ngreat central fire of Humanity, which burns on under the crust of\r\nmanners as rough as the storms of the tropics, or as frigid as polar\r\nsnows.  The avaricious are out of the pale of peace already, and at all\r\nevents.  Poverty is most seriously an evil to sons and daughters, who\r\nsee their parents stripped of comfort, at an age when comfort is almost\r\none with life itself: and to parents who watch the narrowing of the\r\ncapacities of their children by the pressure of poverty,--the impairing\r\nof their promise, the blotting out of their prospects.  To such mourning\r\nchildren there is little comfort, but in contemplating the easier life\r\nwhich lies behind, and (it may be hoped) the happier one which stretches\r\nbefore their parents, on the other side the postern of life.  If there\r\nis sunshine on the two grand reaches of their path, the shadow which\r\nlies in the midst is necessarily but a temporary gloom.  To grieving\r\nparents it should be a consoling truth, that as the life is more than\r\nfood, so is the soul more than instruction and opportunity, and such\r\naccomplishments as man can administer: that as the fowls are fed and the\r\nlilies clothed by Him whose hand made the air musical with the one, and\r\ndressed the fields with the other, so is the human spirit nourished and\r\nadorned by airs from heaven, which blow over the whole earth, and light\r\nfrom the skies, which no hand is permitted to intercept.  Parents know\r\nnot but that Providence may be substituting the noblest education for\r\nthe misteaching of intermediate guardians.  It may possibly be so; but\r\nif not, still there is appointed to every human being much training,\r\nmany privileges, which capricious fortune can neither give nor take\r\naway.  The father may sigh to see his boy condemned to the toil of the\r\nloom, or the gossip and drudgery of the shop, when he would fain have\r\nbeheld him the ornament of a university; but he knows not whether a more\r\nsimple integrity, a loftier disinterestedness, may not come out of the\r\nhumbler discipline than the higher privilege.  The mother\'s eyes may\r\nswim as she hears her little daughter sing her baby brother to sleep on\r\nthe cottage threshold,--her eyes may swim at the thought how those wild\r\nand moving tones might have been exalted by art.  Such art would have\r\nbeen in itself a good; but would this child then have been, as now,\r\nabout her Father\'s business, which, in ministering to one of his little\r\nones, she is as surely as the archangel who suspends new systems of\r\nworlds in the furthest void?  Her occupation is now earnest and holy;\r\nand what need the true mother wish for more?\r\n\r\nWhat is poverty to those who are not thus set in families?  What is it\r\nto the solitary, or to the husband and wife who have faith in each\r\nother\'s strength?  If they have the higher faith which usually\r\noriginates mutual trust, mere poverty is scarcely worth a passing fear.\r\nIf they have plucked out the stings of pride and selfishness, and\r\npurified their vision by faith, what is there to dread?  What is their\r\ncase?  They have life, without certainty how it is to be nourished.\r\nThey do without certainty, like "the young ravens which cry," and work\r\nfor and enjoy the subsistence of the day, leaving the morrow to take\r\ncare of what concerns it.  If living in the dreariest abodes of a town,\r\nthe light from within shines in the dark place, and, dispelling the\r\nmists of worldly care, guides to the blessing of tending the sick, and\r\nsharing the food of to-day with the orphan, and him who has no help but\r\nin them.  If the philosopher goes into such retreats with his lantern,\r\nthere may he best find the generous and the brave.  If, instead of the\r\nalleys of a city, they live under the open sky, they are yet lighter\r\nunder their poverty.  There, however blank the future may lie before\r\nthem, they have to-day the living reality of lawns and woods, and flocks\r\nin "the green pasture and beside the still waters," which silently\r\nremind them of the Shepherd, under whom they shall not want any real\r\ngood thing.  The quiet of the shady lane is theirs, and the beauty of\r\nthe blossoming thorn above the pool.  Delight steals through them with\r\nthe scent of the violet, or the new mown hay.  If they have hushed the\r\nvoices of complaint and fear within them, there is the music of the\r\nmerry lark for them, or of the leaping waterfall, or of a whole\r\norchestra of harps, when the breeze sweeps through a grove of pines.\r\nWhile it is not for fortune to "rob them of free nature\'s grace," and\r\nwhile she leaves them life and strength of limb and soul, the certainty\r\nof a future, though they cannot see what, and the assurance of\r\nprogression, though they cannot see how,--is poverty worth, for\r\nthemselves, more than a passing doubt?  Can it ever be worth the torment\r\nof fear, the bondage of subservience?--the compromise of free thought,--\r\nthe sacrifice of free speech,--the bending of the erect head, the\r\nveiling of the open brow, the repression of the salient soul?  If;\r\ninstead of this, poverty should act as the liberator of the spirit,\r\nawakening it to trust in God and sympathy for man, and placing it aloft,\r\nfresh and free, like morning on the hill-top, to survey the expanse of\r\nlife, and recognise its realities from beneath its mists, it should be\r\ngreeted with that holy joy before which all sorrow and sighing flee\r\naway.\r\n\r\nTheir poverty, which had never afflicted them very grievously, was\r\nalmost lost sight of by the corner-house family, when Hester\'s infant\r\nwas born.  They were all happy and satisfied then, though there were\r\npeople in Deerbrook who found fault with their arrangements, and were\r\nextremely scandalised when it was found that no nurse had arrived from\r\nBlickley, and that Morris took the charge of her mistress upon herself.\r\nThe Greys pronounced by their own fireside that it was a strange fancy--\r\ncarrying an affection for an old servant to a rather romantic extreme--\r\nthat it was a fresh instance of the "enthusiasm" which adversity had not\r\nyet moderated in their cousins, as might have been wished.\r\nOut-of-doors, however, Sophia vaunted the attachment of Morris to her\r\nyoung mistress--an attachment so strong, as that she would have been\r\nreally hurt if any one else had been allowed to sit up with Hester; and\r\nindeed no one could have filled her place half so much to the\r\nsatisfaction of the family--Morris had had so much experience, and was\r\nas fond of her charge as a mother could be.  No one knew what a treasure\r\nher cousins had in Morris.  All of which was true in its separate\r\nparticulars, though altogether it did not constitute the reason why\r\nHester had no nurse from Buckley.\r\n\r\nThey were happy and satisfied.  Yes, even Margaret.  This infant opened\r\nup a spring of consolation in her heart, which she could not have\r\nbelieved existed there.  On this child she could pour out some of her\r\nrepressed affections, and on him did she rest her baffled hopes.  He\r\nbeguiled her into the future, from which she had hitherto recoiled.\r\nThat helpless, unconscious little creature, cradled on her arm, and\r\nknowing nothing of its resting-place, was more powerful than sister,\r\nbrother, or friend--than self-interest, philosophy, or religion, in\r\nluring her imagination onward into future years of honour and peace.\r\nHoly and sweet was the calm of her mind, as, forgetting herself and her\r\ngriefs, she watched the first efforts of this infant to acquaint himself\r\nwith his own powers, and with the world about him; when she smiled at\r\nthe ungainly stretching of the little limbs, and the unpractised\r\nmovement of his eyes seeking the light.  Holy and sweet were the tears\r\nwhich swelled into her eyes when she saw him at his mother\'s breast, and\r\ncould not but gaze at the fresh and divine beauty now mantling on that\r\nmother\'s face, amidst the joy of this new relation.  It was a delicious\r\nmoment when Hope came in, the first day that Hester sat by the fireside,\r\nwhen he stopped short for a brief instant, as if arrested by the beauty\r\nof what he saw; and then glanced towards Margaret for sympathy.  It was\r\na delicious moment to her--the moment of that full, free, unembarrassed\r\nglance, which she had scarcely met since the first days of their\r\nacquaintance.\r\n\r\nIt was a pleasure to them all to see Hester well provided with luxuries.\r\nMaria, knowing that her surgeon would not accept money from her, took\r\nthis opportunity of sending in wine.  Oh, the pleasure of finding the\r\nneglected corkscrew, and making Morris take a glass with them!  The\r\nGreys brought game, and Hester\'s little table was well served every day.\r\nWith what zeal did Margaret apply herself, under Morris\'s teaching, to\r\ncook Hester\'s choice little dinners!  Yes, to cook them.  Margaret was\r\nlearning all Morris\'s arts from her; for, of two troubles which somewhat\r\ndisturbed this season of comfort, one was that it appeared too certain\r\nthat Morris must go, as Susan and Charles had gone before her.  No one\r\nhad expressly declared this: it was left undiscussed, apparently by\r\ncommon consent, till it should be ascertained that baby was healthy and\r\nHester getting strong; but the thought was in the minds of them all, and\r\ntheir plans involved preparation for this.\r\n\r\nThe other trouble was, that with peace and comfort, some slight, very\r\nslight symptoms recurred of Hester\'s propensity to self-torment.  It\r\ncould not be otherwise.  The wonder was, that for weeks and months she\r\nhad been relieved from her old enemy to the extent she had been.  The\r\nreverence with which her husband and sister regarded the temper, in\r\nwhich she had borne unbounded provocation, and most unmerited adversity,\r\nsometimes beguiled them into a hope that her troubles from within were\r\nover for ever; but a little reflection, and some slight experience,\r\ntaught them that this was unreasonable.  They remembered that the\r\ninfirmity of a lifetime was not to be wholly cured in half-a-year; and\r\nthat they must expect some recurrence of her old malady at times when\r\nthere was no immediate appeal to her magnanimity, and no present cause\r\nfor anxiety for those in whom she forgot herself.\r\n\r\nThe first time that Hester was in the drawing-room for the whole day,\r\nMorris was laying the cloth for dinner, and Margaret was walking up and\r\ndown the room with the baby on her arm, when Hope came in.  Hester\r\nforgot everybody and everything else when her husband appeared--a fact\r\nwhich Morris\'s benevolence was never weary of noting and commenting upon\r\nto herself.  She often wondered if ever lady loved her husband as her\r\nyoung mistress did; and she smiled to herself to see the welcome that\r\nbeamed upon Hester\'s whole face when Hope came to take his seat beside\r\nher on the sofa.  This was in her mind to-day, when her master presently\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n"Where is my boy?  I have not seen him for hours.  Why do you put him\r\nout of his father\'s way?  Oh, Margaret has him!  Come, Margaret, yield\r\nhim up.  You can have him all the hours that I am away.  You do not\r\ngrudge him to me, do you?"\r\n\r\n"My master won\'t have to complain, as many gentlemen do," said Morris,\r\n"or as many gentlemen feel, if they don\'t complain, that he is neglected\r\nfor the sake of his baby."\r\n\r\n"If you enjoy your dinner to-day, love," said Hester, "you must not give\r\nme the credit of it.  You and I are to sit down to our pheasant\r\ntogether, they tell me.  Margaret and Morris will have it that they have\r\nboth dined."\r\n\r\n"There is little in getting a comfortable dinner ready," said Morris,\r\n"whether it is the lady herself, or another, that looks to a trifle like\r\nthat.  It is the seeing his wife so full of care and thought about her\r\nbaby as to have none to spare for him, that frets many an one who does\r\nnot like to say anything about it.  Fathers cannot be so taken with a\r\nvery young baby as the mothers are, and it is mortifying to feel\r\nthemselves neglected for a newcomer.  I have often seen that, my dears;\r\nbut I shall never see it here, I find."\r\n\r\n"I do not know how you should, Morris," said Hester, in something of the\r\nold tone, which made her sister\'s heart throb almost before it reached\r\nher ear.  "Margaret will save me from any such danger.  Margaret takes\r\ncare that nobody shall be engrossed with the baby but herself.  She has\r\nnot a thought to spare for any of us while she has baby in her arms.\r\nThe little fellow has cut us all out."\r\n\r\nMargaret quickly transferred the infant to her brother\'s arm, and left\r\nthe room.  She thought it best; for her heart was very full, and she\r\ncould not speak.  She restrained her tears, and went into the kitchen to\r\nbusy herself about the dinner she had cooked.\r\n\r\n"\'Tis a fine pheasant, indeed, Miss Margaret, my dear, and beautifully\r\nroasted, I am sure: and I hope you will go up and see them enjoy it.  I\r\nam so sorry, my dear, for what I said just now.  I merely spoke what\r\ncame up in my mind when I felt pleased, and never thought of its\r\nbringing on any remark.  Nor was anything intended, I am sure, that\r\nshould make you look so sad: so do you go up, and take the baby again,\r\nwhen they sit down to dinner, as if nothing had been said.  Do, my dear,\r\nif I may venture to say so.  I will follow you with the dinner in a\r\nminute."\r\n\r\n"I wonder how it is, my love," said Hope, in a voice which spoke all the\r\ntenderness of his heart; "I wonder how it is that you can endure wrong\r\nso nobly, and that you cannot bear the natural course of events.  Tell\r\nme how it is, Hester, that you have sustained magnanimously all the\r\ninjuries and misfortunes of many months, and that you now quarrel with\r\nMargaret\'s affection for our child."\r\n\r\n"Ah why, indeed, Edward?" she replied, humbly.  "Why, but that I am\r\nunworthy that such an one as Margaret should love me and my child."\r\n\r\n"Enough, enough.  I only want to show you how I regard the case about\r\nthis new love of Margaret\'s.  Do you not see how much happier she has\r\nbeen since this little fellow was born?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes."\r\n\r\n"One may now fancy that she may be gay again.  Let us remember what an\r\noppressed heart she had, and what it must be to her to have a new\r\nobject, so innocent and unconscious as this child, to lavish her\r\naffection upon.  Do not let us grudge her the consolation, or poison the\r\npleasure of this fresh interest."\r\n\r\n"I am afraid it is done," cried Hester, in great distress.  "I was\r\nwicked--I was more cruel than any of our enemies, when I said what I\r\ndid.  I may well bear with them; for, God knows, I am at times no better\r\nthan they.  I have robbed my Margaret of her only comfort--spoiled her\r\nonly pleasure."\r\n\r\n"No, no.  Here she comes.  Look at her."\r\n\r\nMargaret\'s face was indeed serene, and she made as light of the matter\r\nas she could, when Hester implored that she would pardon her hasty and\r\ncruel words, and that she would show her forgiveness by continuing to\r\ncherish the child.  He must not begin to suffer already for his mother\'s\r\nfaults, Hester said.  There could be no doubt of Margaret\'s forgiveness,\r\nnor of her forgetfulness of what had been said, as far as forgetfulness\r\nwas possible.  But the worst of such sayings is, that they carry in them\r\nthat which prevents their being ever quite forgotten.  Hester had\r\neffectually established a constraint in her sister\'s intercourse with\r\nthe baby, and imposed upon Margaret the incessant care of scrupulously\r\nadjusting the claims of the mother and the child.  The evils arising\r\nfrom faulty temper may be borne, may be concealed, but can never be\r\nfully repaired.  Happy they whose part it is to endure and to conceal,\r\nrather than to inflict, and to strive uselessly to repair!\r\n\r\nMargaret\'s part was the easiest of the three, as they sat at the table--\r\nshe with the baby in her arms, and all agreeing that the time was come\r\nfor an explanation with Morris--for depending on themselves for almost\r\nall the work of the house.\r\n\r\n"Come, Morris," said Hester, when the cloth was removed; "you must spare\r\nus half-an-hour.  We want to consult with you.  Come and sit down."\r\n\r\nMorris came, with a foreboding heart.\r\n\r\n"It will be no news to you," said Hope, "that we are very poor.  You\r\nknow nearly as much of our affairs as we do ourselves, as it is right\r\nthat you should.  We have not wished to make any further change in our\r\ndomestic plans till this little fellow was born.  But now that he is\r\nbeginning to make his way in the world, and that his mother is well and\r\nstrong, we feel that we must consider of some further effort to spend\r\nstill less than we do now."\r\n\r\n"There are two ways in which this may be done, we think, Morris," said\r\nHester.  "We may either keep the comfort of having you with us, and\r\npinch ourselves more as to dress and the table--"\r\n\r\n"Oh! ma\'am, I hope you will not carry that any further."\r\n\r\n"Well, if we do not carry that any further, the only thing to be done, I\r\nfear, is to part with you."\r\n\r\n"Is there no other way, I wonder," said Morris, as if thinking aloud.\r\n"If it must be one of these ways, it certainly seems to me to be better\r\nfor ladies to work hard with good food, than to have a servant, and\r\nstint themselves in health and strength.  But who would have thought of\r\nmy young ladies coming to this?"\r\n\r\n"It is a situation in which hundreds and thousands are placed, Morris;\r\nand why not we, as well as they?"\r\n\r\n"May be so, ma\'am: but it grieves one, too."\r\n\r\n"Do not grieve.  I believe we all think that this parting with you is\r\nthe first real grief that our change of fortune has caused us.  Somehow\r\nor other, we have been exceedingly comfortable in our poverty.  If that\r\nhad been all, we should have had a very happy year of it."\r\n\r\n"One would desire to say nothing against what is God\'s will, ma\'am; but\r\none may be allowed, perhaps, to hope that better times will come."\r\n\r\n"I do hope it, and believe it," said her master.\r\n\r\n"And if better times come, Morris, you will return to us.  Will you\r\nnot?"\r\n\r\n"My dear, you know nothing would make me leave you now (as you say I am\r\na comfort to you) if I had any right to say I would stay.  I could live\r\nupon as little as anybody, and could do almost without any wages.  But\r\nthere is my poor sister, you know, ladies.  She depends upon me for\r\neverything, now that she cannot work herself: and I must earn money for\r\nher."\r\n\r\n"We are quite aware of that," said Margaret.  "It is for your sake and\r\nhers, quite as much as for our own, that we think we must part."\r\n\r\n"We wish to know what you would like to do," said Hester.  "Shall we try\r\nto find a situation for you near us, or would you be happier to go down\r\namong your old friends?"\r\n\r\n"I had better go where I am sure of employment, ma\'am.  Better go down\r\nto Birmingham at once.  I should never have left it but for my young\r\nladies\' sakes.  But I should be right glad, my dears, to leave it again\r\nfor you, if you can at any time write to say you wish for me back.\r\nThere is another way I have thought of sometimes; but, of course, you\r\ncannot have overlooked anything that could occur to me.  If you would\r\nall go to Birmingham, you have so many friends there, and my master\r\nwould be valued as he ought to be; which there is no sign of his being\r\nin this place.  I do not like this place, my dears.  It is not good\r\nenough for you."\r\n\r\n"We think any place good enough for us where there are men and women\r\nliving," said Hope, kindly but gravely.  "Others have thought as you do,\r\nMorris, and have offered us temptations to go away; but we do not think\r\nit right.  If we go, we shall leave behind us a bad character, which we\r\ndo not deserve.  If we stay, I have very little doubt of recovering my\r\nprofessional character, and winning over our neighbours to think better\r\nof us, and be kind to us again.  We mean to try for it, if I should have\r\nto hire myself out as a porter in Mr Grey\'s yards."\r\n\r\n"Pray, don\'t say that, sir.  But, indeed, I believe you are so far right\r\nas that the good always conquers at last."\r\n\r\n"Just so, Morris: that is what we trust.  And for the sake of this\r\nlittle fellow, if for nothing else, we must stand by our good name.  Who\r\nknows but that I may leave him a fine flourishing practice in this very\r\nplace, when I retire or die?--always supposing he means to follow his\r\nfather\'s profession."\r\n\r\n"Sir, that is looking forward very far."\r\n\r\n"So it is, Morris.  But however people may disapprove of looking forward\r\ntoo far, it is difficult to help it when they become parents.  Your\r\nmistress could tell you, if she would own the truth, that she sees her\r\nson\'s manly beauty already under that little wry mouth, and that odd\r\nbutton of a nose.  Why may not I just as well fancy him a young\r\nsurgeon?"\r\n\r\n"Morris would say, as she once said to me," observed Margaret,\r\n"`Remember death, my dear; remember death.\'"\r\n\r\n"We will remember it," said Morris, "but we must remember at the same\r\ntime God\'s mercy in giving life.  He who gave life can preserve it: and\r\nthis shall be my trust for you all, my dears, when I am far away from\r\nyou.  There is a knock!  I must go.  Oh!  Miss Margaret, who will there\r\nbe to go to the door when I am gone, but you?"\r\n\r\nMr Jones had knocked at the door, and left a letter.  These were its\r\ncontents:--\r\n\r\n  "Sir,--I hope you will excuse the liberty I take in applying to you\r\n  for my own satisfaction.  My wife and I have perceived with much\r\n  concern that we have lost much of your custom of late.  We mind little\r\n  the mere falling off of custom in any quarter, in comparison with\r\n  failing to give satisfaction.  We have always tried, I am sure, to\r\n  give satisfaction in our dealings with your family, sir; and if there\r\n  has been any offence, I can assure you it is unintentional, and shall\r\n  feel obliged by knowing what it is.  We cannot conceive, sir, where\r\n  you get your meat, if not from us; and if you have the trouble of\r\n  buying it from a distance, I can only say we should be happy to save\r\n  you the trouble, if we knew how to serve you to your liking; for, sir,\r\n  we have a great respect for you and yours.\r\n\r\n  "Your obedient servants,\r\n\r\n  "John Jones,\r\n\r\n  "Mary Jones."\r\n\r\n"The kind soul!" cried Hester.  "What must we say to them?"\r\n\r\n"We must set their minds at ease about our good-will to them.  How that\r\nlittle fellow stares about him, like a child of double his age!  I do\r\nbelieve I could make him look wise at my watch already.  Yes, we must\r\nset the Joneses at ease, at all events."\r\n\r\n"But how?  We must not tell them that we cannot afford to buy of them as\r\nwe did."\r\n\r\n"No; that would be begging.  We must trust to their delicacy not to\r\npress too closely for a reason, when once assured that we respect them\r\nas highly as they possibly can us."\r\n\r\n"You may trust them," said Margaret, "I am convinced.  They will look in\r\nyour face, and be satisfied without further question; and my advice,\r\ntherefore, is, that you do not write, but go."\r\n\r\n"I will; and now.  They shall not suffer a moment\'s pain that I can save\r\nthem.  Good-night, my boy!  What! you have not learned to kiss yet.\r\nWell, among us all, you will soon know how, if teaching will do it.\r\nWhat a spirit he has!  I fancy he will turn out like Frank."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER THIRTY NINE.\r\n\r\nTHE LONG NIGHTS.\r\n\r\nAlmost as soon as Hope had left the house, Sydney Grey arrived, looking\r\nfull of importance.  He took care to shut the door before he would tell\r\nhis errand.  His mother had been obliged to trust him for want of\r\nanother messenger; and he delivered his message with a little of the\r\nparade of mystery he had derived from her.  Mr Grey\'s family had become\r\nuneasy about his returning from the markets in the evening, since\r\nrobberies had become so frequent as they now were, and the days so\r\nshort; and had at length persuaded him to sleep at the more distant\r\nmarket-towns he had to visit, and return the next morning.  From\r\nBlickley he could get home before the evening closed in; but on two days\r\nin the week he was to remain out all night.  When he had agreed to this,\r\nhis family had applauded him and felt satisfied: but as the evening drew\r\non, on occasion of this his first absence, Mrs Grey and Sophia had\r\ngrown nervous on their own account.  They recalled story after story,\r\nwhich they had lately heard, of robberies at several solitary houses in\r\nthe country round; and, though their house was not solitary, they could\r\nnot reconcile themselves to going to rest without the comfort of knowing\r\nthat there was, as usual, a strong man on their premises.  If they had\r\nbeen aware how many strong men there were sometimes on their premises at\r\nnight, they would not have been satisfied with having one within their\r\nwalls.  Not having been informed, however, how cleverly their dogs were\r\nsilenced, how much poached game was divided under the shelter of their\r\nstacks of deals, and what dextrous abstractions were at such times made\r\nfrom the store of corn in their granaries, and coal in their lighters,\r\nthey proposed nothing further than to beg the favour of Mr Hope that he\r\nwould take a bed in their house for this one night.  They dared not\r\nengage any of the men from the yards to defend them; they had not Mr\r\nGrey\'s leave, and he might not be pleased if they showed any fear to\r\ntheir own servants: but it would be the greatest comfort if Mr Hope\r\nwould come, as if to supper, and stay the night.  The spare room was\r\nready; and Mrs Grey hoped he would not object to leaving his family\r\njust for once.  Mr Grey intended to do the same thing twice a week,\r\ntill the days should lengthen, and the roads become safer.\r\n\r\nThough Sydney made the most of his message, he declared himself not\r\nthoroughly pleased with it.\r\n\r\n"They might have trusted me to take care of them," said he.  "If they\r\nhad just let me have my father\'s pistols--."\r\n\r\n"Come, come, Sydney, do not talk of pistols," said Hester, who did not\r\nrelish any part of the affair.\r\n\r\n"He would not talk of them if he thought they were likely to be wanted,"\r\nobserved Margaret.\r\n\r\n"Likely! when were they ever more likely to be wanted, I should like to\r\nknow!  Did you hear what happened at the Russell Taylors\' last night?"\r\n\r\n"No; and we do not wish to hear.  Do not tell us any horrible stories,\r\nunless you mean my husband to stay at home to-night."\r\n\r\n"Oh, you must just hear this, because it ended well; that is, nobody was\r\nkilled.  Mr Walcot told Sophia all about it this morning; and it was\r\npartly that which made her so anxious to have some one sleep in the\r\nhouse to-night."\r\n\r\n"Well, then, do not tell us, or you will make us anxious for the same\r\nthing."\r\n\r\n"What would your mother say if you were to carry home word that Mr Hope\r\ncould not come--that his family dare not part with him?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, then she must let me have my father\'s pistols, and watch for the\r\nfellows.  If they came about our windows as they did about the Russell\r\nTaylors\', how I would let fly among them!  They came rapping at the\r\nshutters, at two this morning; and when Mr Taylor looked out from his\r\nbedroom above, they said they would not trouble themselves to get in, if\r\nhe would throw out his money!"\r\n\r\n"And did he?"\r\n\r\n"Yes.  They raised a hat upon a pole, and he put in four or five\r\npounds--all he had in the house, he told them.  So they went away; but\r\nnone of the family thought of going to bed again."\r\n\r\n"I dare say not.  And what sort of thieves are these supposed to be?\r\nThey set about their business very oddly."\r\n\r\n"Not like London thieves," said Sydney, consequentially, as if he knew\r\nall about London thieves.  "They are the distressed country people, no\r\ndoubt--such as would no more think of standing a second shot from my\r\npistol, than of keeping the straits of Thermopylae.  Look here," he\r\ncontinued, showing the end of a pistol, which peeped from a pocket\r\ninside his coat; "here\'s a thing that will put such gentry into a fine\r\ntaking."\r\n\r\n"Pray, is that pistol loaded?" inquired Hester, pressing her infant to\r\nher.\r\n\r\n"To be sure.  What is the use of a pistol if it is not loaded?  It might\r\nas well be in the shop as in my pocket, then.  Look at her, cousin\r\nMargaret!  If she is not in as great a fright as the cowardly thieves!\r\nWhy, cousin Hester, don\'t you see, if this pistol went off, it would not\r\nshoot you or the baby.  It would go straight through me."\r\n\r\n"That is a great comfort.  But I had rather you would go away, you and\r\nyour pistol.  Pray, does your mother know that you carry one?"\r\n\r\n"No.  Mind you don\'t tell her.  I trust you not to tell her.  Remember,\r\nI would not have told you if I had not felt sure of you."\r\n\r\n"You had better not have felt sure of us.  However, we will not tell\r\nyour mother; but my husband will tell Mr Grey to-morrow, when he comes\r\nhome.  If he chooses that you should carry loaded pistols about, there\r\nwill be no harm done."\r\n\r\n"I have a great mind to say I will shoot you if you tell," cried Sydney,\r\npresenting the pistol with a grand air.  But he saw that he made his\r\ncousins really uneasy, and he laid it down on the table, offering to\r\nleave it with them for the night, if they thought it would make them\r\nfeel any safer.  There were plenty more at home.\r\n\r\n"Thank you," said Margaret, "but I believe we are more afraid of loaded\r\npistols than of thieves.  The sooner you take it away the better.  You\r\ncan go now, presently, for here comes my brother."\r\n\r\nSydney quickly pocketed his pistol.  Hope agreed to go, and promised to\r\nbe at Mr Grey\'s to supper by nine o\'clock.\r\n\r\nMargaret was incessantly thinking of Maria in these long evenings, when\r\nalarms of one kind or another were all abroad.  She now thought she\r\nwould go with Sydney, and spend an hour or two with Maria, returning by\r\nthe time her brother would be going to the Greys\'.  Maria\'s landlord\r\nwould see her home, no doubt.\r\n\r\nShe found her friend busy with book and needle, and as well in health as\r\nusual, but obviously somewhat moved by the dismal stories which had\r\ntravelled from mouth to mouth through Deerbrook during the day.  It\r\nseemed hardly right that any person in delicate health should be lonely\r\nat such a time; and it occurred to Margaret that her friend might like\r\nto go home with her, and occupy the bed which was this night to spare.\r\nMaria thankfully accepted the offer, and let Margaret put up her little\r\nbundle for her.  The farrier escorted them to the steps of the\r\ncorner-house, and then left them.\r\n\r\nThe door was half-open, as Morris was talking with some one on the mat\r\nin the hall.  An extremely tall woman, with a crying baby in her arms,\r\nmade way for the ladies, not by going out of the house, but by stepping\r\nfurther into the hall.\r\n\r\n"Morris, had you not better shut the door?" said Margaret; "the wind\r\nblows in so, it is enough to chill the whole house."\r\n\r\nBut Morris held the door open, rather wider than before.\r\n\r\n"So the gentleman is not at home," said the tall woman, gruffly.  "If I\r\ncome again in an hour with my poor baby, will he be at home then?"\r\n\r\n"Is my brother gone, Morris?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Miss, three minutes ago."\r\n\r\n"Then he will not be back in an hour.  We do not expect him--."\r\n\r\n"This good woman had better go to Mr Walcot, ma\'am, as I have been\r\ntelling her.  There\'s no doubt he is at home."\r\n\r\n"I could wait here till the gentleman comes home," said the tall woman;\r\n"and so get the first advice for my poor baby.  \'Tis very ill, ma\'am."\r\n\r\n"Better go to Mr Walcot," persisted Morris.\r\n\r\n"Or to my brother at Mr Grey\'s," said Margaret, unwilling to lose the\r\nchance of a new patient for Edward, and thinking his advice better, for\r\nthe child\'s sake, than Mr Walcot\'s.\r\n\r\n"It is far the readiest way to go to Mr Walcot\'s," declared Maria,\r\nwhose arm Margaret felt to tremble within her own.\r\n\r\n"I believe you are right," said Margaret.  "You had better not waste any\r\nmore time here, good woman.  It may make all the difference to your\r\nchild."\r\n\r\n"If you would let me wait till the gentleman comes home," said the tall\r\nwoman.\r\n\r\n"Impossible.  It is too late to-night for patients to wait.  This lady\'s\r\nlandlord, without there, will show you the way to Mr Walcot\'s.  Call\r\nhim, Morris."\r\n\r\nMorris went out upon the steps, but the tall woman passed her, and was\r\ngone.  Morris stepped in briskly, and put up the chain.\r\n\r\n"You were very ready to send a new patient to Mr Walcot, Morris," said\r\nMargaret, smiling.\r\n\r\n"I had a fancy that it was a sort of patient that my master would not be\r\nthe better for," replied Morris.  "I did not like the looks of the\r\nperson."\r\n\r\n"Nor I," said Maria.\r\n\r\nThe drawing-room door was heard to open, and Morris put her finger on\r\nher lips.  Hester had been alone nearly ten minutes; she was growing\r\nnervous, and wanted to know what all this talking in the hall was about.\r\nShe was told that Mr Hope had been inquired for, about a sick baby;\r\nand the rest of the discourse went to the account of Maria\'s unexpected\r\narrival.  Hester welcomed Maria kindly, ordered up the cold pheasant and\r\nthe wine, and then, leaving the friends to enjoy themselves over the\r\nfire, retired to rest.  Morris was desired to go too, as she still slept\r\nin her mistress\'s room, and ought to keep early hours, since, in\r\naddition to her labours of the day, she was at the baby\'s call in the\r\nnight.  Margaret would see her friend to her room.  Morris must not\r\nremain up on their account.\r\n\r\n"How comfortable this is!" cried Maria, in a gleeful tone, as she looked\r\nround upon the crackling fire, the tray, the wine, and her companion.\r\n"How unlooked for, to pass a whole evening and night without being\r\nafraid of anything!"\r\n\r\n"What an admission from you!--that you are afraid of something every\r\nnight."\r\n\r\n"That is just the plain truth.  When I used to read about the horrors of\r\nliving in a solitary house in the country, I little thought how much of\r\nthe same terror I should feel from living solitary in a house in a\r\nvillage.  You wonder what could happen to me, I dare say; and perhaps it\r\nwould not be very easy to suppose any peril which would stand\r\nexamination."\r\n\r\n"I was going to say that you and we are particularly safe, from being so\r\npoor that there is no inducement to rob us.  We and you have neither\r\nmoney nor jewels, nor plate, that can tempt thieves!--for our few forks\r\nand spoons are hardly worth breaking into a house for."\r\n\r\n"People who want bread, however, may think it worth while to break in\r\nfor that: and while our thieves are this sort of people, and not the\r\nLondon gentry whom Sydney is so fond of talking of, it may be enough\r\nthat gentlemen and ladies live in houses to make the starving suppose\r\nthat they shall find something valuable there."\r\n\r\n"They would soon learn better if they came here.  I doubt whether, when\r\nyou and I have done our supper, they would find anything to eat.  But\r\nhow do you show your terrors, I should like to know?  Do you scream?"\r\n\r\n"I never screamed in my life, as far as I remember.  Screaming appears\r\nto me the most unnatural of human sounds.  I never felt the slightest\r\ninclination to express myself in that manner."\r\n\r\n"Nor I: but I never said so, because I thought no one would believe me."\r\n\r\n"No: the true mood for these doleful winter nights is, to sit trying to\r\nread, but never able to fix your attention for five minutes, for some\r\nodd noise or another.  And yet it is almost worse to hear nothing but a\r\ncinder falling on the hearth now and then, startling you like a\r\npistol-shot.  Then it seems as if somebody was opening the shutter\r\noutside, and then tapping at the window.  I have got so into the habit\r\nof looking at the window at night, expecting to see a face squeezed flat\r\nagainst the pane, that I have yielded up my credit to myself, and\r\nactually have the blinds drawn down when the outside shutters are\r\nclosed."\r\n\r\n"How glad I am to find you are no braver than the rest of us!"\r\n\r\n"No; do not be glad.  It is very painful, night after night.  Every step\r\nclinks or craunches in the farrier\'s yard, you know.  This ought to be a\r\ncomfort: but sometimes I cannot clearly tell where the sound comes from.\r\nMore than once lately I have fancied it was behind me, and have turned\r\nround in a greater hurry than you would think I could use.  My rooms are\r\na good way from the rest of the house; you remember the length of the\r\npassage between.  I do not like disturbing the family in the evenings;\r\nbut I have been selfish enough to ring, once or twice this week, without\r\nany sufficient reason, just for the sake of a sight of my landlady."\r\n\r\n"A very sufficient reason.  But I had no idea of all this from you."\r\n\r\n"You have heard me say some fine things about the value of time to me--\r\nabout the blessings of my long evenings.  For all that (true as it is),\r\nI have got into the way of going to bed soon after ten, just because I\r\nknow every one else in the house is in bed, and I do not like to be the\r\nonly person up."\r\n\r\n"That is the reason why you are looking so well, notwithstanding all\r\nthese terrors.  But, Maria, what has become of your bravery?"\r\n\r\n"It is just where it was.  I am no more afraid than I used to be of\r\nevils which may be met with a mature mind: and just as much afraid as\r\never of those which terrified my childhood."\r\n\r\n"Our baby shall never be afraid of anything," asserted Margaret.  "But\r\nMaria, something must be done for your relief."\r\n\r\n"That is just what I hoped and expected you would say, and the reason\r\nwhy I exposed myself to you."\r\n\r\n"Why do not the Greys offer you a room there for the winter?  That seems\r\nthe simplest and most obvious plan."\r\n\r\n"It is not convenient."\r\n\r\n"How should that be?"\r\n\r\n"The bed would have to be uncovered, you know; and the mahogany\r\nwash-stand might be splashed."\r\n\r\n"They can get a room ready for a guest, to relieve their own fears, but\r\nnot yours.  Can nothing be done about it?"\r\n\r\n"Not unless the Rowlands should take in Mr Walcot, because he is afraid\r\nto live alone: in such case, the Greys would take me in for the same\r\nreason.  But that will not be so, Margaret, I will ask you plainly, and\r\nyou will answer as plainly--could you, without too much pain, trouble,\r\nand inconvenience, spend an evening or two a week with me, just till\r\nthis panic is passed?  If you could put it in my power to be always\r\nlooking forward to an evening of relief, it would break the sense of\r\nsolitude, and make all the difference to me.  I see the selfishness of\r\nthis; but I really think it is better to own my weakness than to\r\nstruggle uselessly against it any longer."\r\n\r\n"I could do that--should like of all things to do it till Morris goes:\r\nbut that will be so soon--."\r\n\r\n"Morris! where is she going?"\r\n\r\nMargaret related this piece of domestic news, too private to be told to\r\nany one else till the last moment.  Maria forgot her own troubles, or\r\ndespised them as she listened, so grieved was she for her friends,\r\nincluding Morris.  Margaret was not very sorry on Morris\'s own account.\r\nMorris wanted rest--an easier place.  She had had too much upon her for\r\nsome time past.\r\n\r\n"What then will you have, when she is gone?"\r\n\r\n"If I have work enough to drive all thought out of my head, I shall be\r\nthankful.  Meantime, I will bestow my best wit upon your case."\r\n\r\n"I am ashamed of my case already.  While sitting in all this comfort\r\nhere, I can hardly believe in my own tremors, of no earlier date than\r\nlast night.  Come, let us draw to the fire.  I hope we shall not end\r\nwith sitting up all night; but I feel as if I should like it very much."\r\n\r\nMargaret stirred up a blaze, and put out the candles.  No economy was\r\nnow beneath her care.  As she took her seat beside her friend, she said:\r\n\r\n"Maria, did you ever know any place so dull and dismal as Deerbrook is\r\nnow?  Is it not enough to make any heart as heavy as the fortunes of the\r\nplace?"\r\n\r\n"Even the little that I see of it, in going to and from the Greys, looks\r\nsad enough.  You see the outskirts, which I suppose are worse still."\r\n\r\n"The very air feels too heavy to breathe.  The cottages, and even the\r\nbetter houses, appear to my eyes damp and weather-stained on the\r\noutside, and silent within.  The children sit shivering on the\r\nthresholds--do not they?--instead of shouting at their play as they did.\r\nEvery one looks discontented, and complains--the poor of want of bread,\r\nand every one else of hard times, and all manner of woes, that one never\r\nhears of in prosperous seasons.  Mr James says the actions for trespass\r\nare beyond all example; Mr Tucker declares his dog, that died the other\r\nday, was poisoned; and I never pass the Green but the women are even\r\nquarrelling for precedence at the pump."\r\n\r\n"I have witnessed some of this, but not all: and neither, I suspect,\r\nhave you, Margaret, though you think you have.  We see the affairs of\r\nthe world in shadow, you know, when our own hearts are sad."\r\n\r\n"My heart is not so sad as you think.  You do not believe me: but that\r\nis because you do not believe what I am sure of--that he is not to blame\r\nfor anything that has happened--that, at least, he has only been\r\nmistaken,--that there his been no fickleness, no selfishness, in him.  I\r\ncould not speak of this, even to you, Maria, if it were not a duty to\r\nhim.  You must not be left to suppose from my silence that he is to\r\nblame, as you think he is.  I suffer from no sense of injury from him.\r\nI got over that, long ago."\r\n\r\nMaria would not say, as she thought, "You had to get over it, then?"\r\n\r\n"It makes me very unhappy to think how he is suffering,--how much more\r\nhe has to bear than I; so much more than the separation and the blank.\r\nHe cannot trust me as I trusted him; and that is, indeed, to be without\r\nconsolation."\r\n\r\n"Do men ever trust as women do?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Edward does.  If he were to go to India for twenty years, he would\r\nknow, as certainly as I should, that Hester would be widowed in every\r\nthought till his return.  And the time will come when Philip will know\r\nthis as certainly of me.  It is but a little while yet that I have\r\nwaited, Maria; but it does sometimes seem a weary waiting."\r\n\r\nMaria took her friend\'s hand, in token of the sympathy she could not\r\nspeak,--so much of hopelessness was there mingled with it.\r\n\r\n"I know you and others think that this waiting is to go on for ever."\r\n\r\n"No, love; not so."\r\n\r\n"Or that a certainty which is even worse will come some day.  But it\r\nwill be otherwise.  His love can no more be quenched or alienated by the\r\nslanders of a wicked woman, than the sun can be put out by an eclipse,\r\nor sent to enlighten another world, leaving us mourning."\r\n\r\n"You judge by your own soul, Margaret; and that should be a faithful\r\nguide.  You judge him by your own soul,--and how much by this?" she\r\nadded, with a smile, fixing her eyes on the turquoise ring, which was\r\nPhilip\'s gift, and which, safely guarded, was on a finger of the hand\r\nshe held.\r\n\r\nMargaret blushed.  She could not have denied, if closely pressed, that\r\nsome little tinge of the Eastern superstition had entered into this\r\nsacred ring, and lay there, like the fire in the opal.  She could not\r\nhave denied, that, when she drew it on every morning, she noted with\r\nsatisfaction that its blue was as clear and bright as ever.\r\n\r\n"How is it that this ring is still here?" asked Maria.  "Is it possible\r\nthat he retains gifts of yours?  Yet, I think, if he did not, this ring\r\nwould not be on your finger."\r\n\r\n"He does keep whatever I gave him.  Thank God! he keeps them.  This is\r\none of my greatest comforts: it is the only way I have left of speaking\r\nto him.  But if it were not so, this ring would still be where it is.  I\r\nwould not give it up.  I am not altered.  I am not angry with him.  His\r\nlove is as precious to me as it ever was, and I will not give up the\r\ntokens of it.  Why, Maria, you surely cannot suppose that these things\r\nhave any other value or use but as given by him!  You cannot suppose\r\nthat I dread the imputation of keeping them for their own sakes!"\r\n\r\n"No: but--"\r\n\r\n"But what?"\r\n\r\n"Is any proof of his former regard of value now?  That is the question.\r\nIt has only very lately become a question with me.  I have only lately\r\nlearned to think him in fault.  I excused him before...  I excused him\r\nas long as I could."\r\n\r\n"You will unlearn your present opinion of him.  Yes; everything that was\r\never valuable from him is more precious than ever now,--now that he is\r\nunder a spell, and cannot speak his soul.  If it were, as you think, if\r\nhe loved me no longer, they would be still more precious, as a relic of\r\nthe dead.  But it is not so."\r\n\r\n"If faith can remove mountains, we may have to rejoice for you still,\r\nMargaret; for there can be no mass of calumnies between you and him\r\nwhich you have not faith enough to overthrow."\r\n\r\n"Thank you for that.  It is the best word of comfort that has come to me\r\nfrom without for many a day.  Now there is one thing more in which you\r\ncan perhaps help me.  I have heard nothing about him for so long!  You\r\nsee Mr Rowland sometimes (I know he feels a great friendship for you);\r\nand you meet the younger children.  Do you hear nothing whatever about\r\n_him_?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing: nor do they.  Mr Rowland told me, a fortnight ago, that Mrs\r\nRowland and he are seriously uneasy at obtaining no answers to their\r\nrepeated letters to Mr Enderby.  Mrs Rowland is more disturbed, I\r\nbelieve, than she chooses to show.  She must feel herself responsible.\r\nShe has tried various means of accounting for his silence, all the\r\nautumn.  Now she gives that up, and is silent in her turn.  If it were\r\nnot for the impossibility of leaving home at such a time as this, Mr\r\nRowland would go to London to satisfy himself.  Margaret, I believe you\r\nare the only person who has smiled at this."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps I am the only one who understands him.  I had rather know of\r\nthis silence than of all the letters he could have written to Mrs\r\nRowland.  If he had been ill, they would certainly have heard."\r\n\r\n"Yes; they say so."\r\n\r\n"Then that is enough.  Let us say no more now."\r\n\r\n"You have said that which has cheered me for you, Margaret, though, as\r\nwe poor irreligious human beings often say to each other, `I wish I had\r\nyour faith.\'  You have given me more than I had, however.  But are we to\r\nsay no more about anything?  Must we leave this comfortable fire, and go\r\nto sleep?"\r\n\r\n"Not unless you wish it.  I have more to ask, if you are not tired."\r\n\r\n"Come, ask me."\r\n\r\n"Cannot you tell me of some way in which a woman may earn money?"\r\n\r\n"A woman?  What rate of woman?  Do you mean yourself?  That question is\r\neasily answered.  A woman from the uneducated classes can get a\r\nsubsistence by washing and cooking, by milking cows and going to\r\nservice, and, in some parts of the kingdom, by working in a cotton mill,\r\nor burnishing plate, as you have no doubt seen for yourself at\r\nBirmingham.  But, for an educated woman, a woman with the powers which\r\nGod gave her, religiously improved, with a reason which lays life open\r\nbefore her, an understanding which surveys science as its appropriate\r\ntask, and a conscience which would make every species of responsibility\r\nsafe,--for such a woman there is in all England no chance of subsistence\r\nbut by teaching--that almost ineffectual teaching, which can never\r\ncountervail the education of circumstances, and for which not one in a\r\nthousand is fit--or by being a superior Miss Nares--the feminine gender\r\nof the tailor and the hatter."\r\n\r\n"The tutor, the tailor, and the hatter.  Is this all?"\r\n\r\n"All; except that there are departments of art and literature from which\r\nit is impossible to shut women out.  These are not, however, to be\r\nregarded as resources for bread.  Besides the number who succeed in art\r\nand literature being necessarily extremely small, it seems pretty\r\ncertain that no great achievements, in the domains of art and\r\nimagination, can be looked for from either men or women who labour there\r\nto supply their lower wants, or for any other reason than the pure love\r\nof their work.  While they toil in any one of the arts of expression, if\r\nthey are not engrossed by some loftier meaning, the highest which they\r\nwill end with expressing will be, the need of bread."\r\n\r\n"True--quite true.  I must not think of any of those higher departments\r\nof labour, because, even if I were qualified, what I want is not\r\nemployment, but money.  I am anxious to earn some money, Maria.  We are\r\nvery poor.  Edward is trying, one way and another, to earn money to live\r\nupon, till his practice comes back to him, as he is for ever trusting it\r\nwill.  I wish to earn something too, if it be ever so little.  Can you\r\ntell me of no way?"\r\n\r\n"I believe I should not if I could.  Why?  Because I think you have\r\nquite enough to do already, and will soon have too much.  Just consider.\r\nWhen Morris goes, what hour of the day will you have to spare?  Let us\r\nsee;--do you mean to sweep the rooms with your own hands?"\r\n\r\n"Yes," said Margaret, smiling.\r\n\r\n"And to scour them too?"\r\n\r\n"No; not quite that.  We shall hire a neighbour to come two or three\r\ntimes a week to do the rougher parts of the work.  But I mean to light\r\nthe fire in the morning (and we shall have but one), and get breakfast\r\nready; and Hester will help me to make the beds.  That is nearly all I\r\nshall let her do besides the sewing; for baby will give her employment\r\nenough."\r\n\r\n"Indeed, I think so; and that will leave you too much.  Do not think,\r\ndear, of earning money.  You are doing all you ought in saving it."\r\n\r\n"I must think about it, because earning is so much nobler and more\r\neffectual than saving.  I cannot help seeing that it would be far better\r\nto earn the amount of Morris\'s maintenance, than to save it by doing her\r\nwork badly myself.  Not that I shrink from the labour: I am rather\r\nenjoying the prospect of it, as I told you.  Hark! what footstep is\r\nthat?"\r\n\r\n"I heard it a minute or two ago," whispered Maria, "but I did not like\r\nto mention it."\r\n\r\nThey listened in the deepest silence for a while.  At first they were\r\nnot sure whether they heard anything above the beating of their own\r\nhearts; but they were soon certain that there were feet moving outside\r\nthe room door.\r\n\r\n"The church clock has but lately gone twelve," said Maria, in the faint\r\nhope that it might be some one of the household yet stirring.\r\n\r\nMargaret shook her head.  She rose softly from her seat, and took a\r\ncandle from the table to light it, saying she would go and see.  Her\r\nhand trembled a little as she held the match, and the candle would not\r\nimmediately light.  Meantime, the door opened without noise, and some\r\none walked in and quite up to the gazing ladies.  It was the tall woman.\r\nMaria made an effort to reach the bell, but the tall woman seized her\r\narm, and made her sit down.  A capricious jet of flame from a coal in\r\nthe fire at this moment lighted up the face of the stranger for a\r\nmoment, and enabled Maria to "spy a creat peard under the muffler."\r\n\r\n"What do you want at this time?" said Margaret.\r\n\r\n"I want money, and what else I can get," said the intruder, in the no\r\nlonger disguised voice of a man.  "I have been into your larder, but you\r\nseem to have nothing there."\r\n\r\n"That is true," said Margaret, firmly; "nor have we any money.  We are\r\nvery poor.  You could not have come to a worse place, if you are in\r\nwant."\r\n\r\n"Here is something, however," said the man, turning to the tray.  "With\r\nyour leave, I\'ll see what you have left us to eat."\r\n\r\nHe thrust one of the candles between the bars of the grate to light it,\r\ntelling the ladies they had better start no difficulty, lest they should\r\nhave reason to repent it.  There were others with him in the house, who\r\nwould show themselves in an instant, if any noise were made.\r\n\r\n"Then do you make none--I beg it as a favour," said Margaret.  "There is\r\na lady asleep up-stairs, with a very young infant.  If you respect her\r\nlife you will be quiet."\r\n\r\nThe man did not answer, but he was quiet.  He cut slices from the loaf,\r\nand carried them to the door, and they were taken by somebody outside.\r\nHe quickly devoured the remains of the pheasant, tearing the meat from\r\nthe bones with his teeth.  He drank from the decanter of wine, and then\r\ncarried it where he had taken the bread.  Two men put their heads in at\r\nthe door, nodded to the ladies before they drank, and again withdrew.\r\nThe girls cast a look at each other--a glance of agreement that\r\nresistance was not to be thought of: yet each was conscious of a feeling\r\nof rather pleasant surprise that she was not more alarmed.\r\n\r\n"Now for it!" said the man, striding oddly about in his petticoats, and\r\nevidently out of patience with them.  "Now for your money!"  As he\r\nspoke, he put the spoons from the tray into the bosom of his gown,\r\nproceeding to murmur at his deficiency of pockets.\r\n\r\nMargaret held out her purse to him.  It contained one single shilling.\r\n\r\n"You don\'t mean this is all you are going to give me?"\r\n\r\n"It is all I have: and I believe there is not another shilling in the\r\nhouse.  I told you we have no money."\r\n\r\n"And you?" said he, turning to Maria.\r\n\r\n"I have not my purse about me; and if I had there is nothing in it worth\r\nyour taking.  I assure you I have not got my purse.  I am only a visitor\r\nhere for this one night--and an odd night it is to have chosen, as it\r\nturns out."\r\n\r\n"Give me your watches."\r\n\r\n"I have no watch.  I have not had a watch these five years," said Maria.\r\n\r\n"I have no watch," said Margaret.  "I sold mine a month ago.  I told you\r\nwe were very poor."\r\n\r\nThe man muttered something about the plague of gentlefolks being so\r\npoor, and about wondering that gentlefolks were not ashamed of being so\r\npoor.  "You have got something, however," he continued, fixing his eye\r\non the ring on Margaret\'s finger.  "Give me that ring.  Give it me, or\r\nelse I\'ll take it."\r\n\r\nMargaret\'s heart sank with a self-reproach worse than her grief, when\r\nshe remembered how easily she might have saved this ring--how easily she\r\nmight have thrust it under the fender, or dropped it into her shoe, into\r\nher hair, anywhere, while the intruder was gone to the room door to his\r\ncompanions.  She felt that she could never forgive herself for this\r\nneglect of the most precious thing she had in the world--of that which\r\nmost belonged to Philip.\r\n\r\n"She cannot part with that ring," said Maria.  "Look! you may see she\r\nhad rather part with any money she is ever likely to have than with that\r\nring."\r\n\r\nShe pointed to Margaret, who was sitting with her hands clasped as if\r\nthey were never to be disjoined, and with a face of the deepest\r\ndistress.\r\n\r\n"I can\'t help that," said the man.  "I must have what I can get."\r\n\r\nHe seized her hands, and, with one gripe of his, made hers fly open.\r\nMargaret could no longer endure to expose any of her feelings to the\r\nnotice of a stranger of this character.  "Be patient a moment," said\r\nshe; and she drew off the ring after its guard, made of Hester\'s hair,\r\nand put them into the large hand which was held out to receive them;\r\nfeeling, at the moment, as if her heart was breaking.  The man threw the\r\nhair ring back into her lap, and tied the turquoise in the corner of the\r\nshawl he wore.\r\n\r\n"The lady up-stairs has got a watch, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"Yes, she has: let me go and fetch it.  Do let me go.  I am afraid of\r\nnothing so much as her being terrified.  If you have any humanity, let\r\nme go.  Indeed I will bring the watch."\r\n\r\n"Well, there is no man in the house, I know, for you to call.  You may\r\ngo, Miss: but I must step behind you to the room door; no further--she\r\nshan\'t see me, nor know any one is there, unless you tell her.  This\r\nyoung lady will sit as still as a mouse till we come back."\r\n\r\n"Never mind me," said Maria, to her friend.  While they were gone, she\r\nsat as she was desired, as still as a mouse, enforced thereto by the\r\ncertainty that a man stood in the shadow by the door, with his eye upon\r\nher the whole time.\r\n\r\nMargaret lighted a chamber candle, in order, as she said, to look as\r\nusual if her sister should see her.  The robber did tread very softly on\r\nthe stairs, and stop outside the chamber-door.  Morris was sitting up in\r\nher truckle-bed, evidently listening, and was on the point of starting\r\nout of it on seeing that Margaret\'s face was pale, when Margaret put her\r\nfinger on her lips, and motioned to her to lie down.  Hester was asleep,\r\nwith her sleeping infant on her arm.  Margaret set down the light, and\r\nleaned over her, to take the watch from its hook at the head of the bed.\r\n\r\n"Are you still up?" said Hester, drowsily, and just opening her eyes.\r\n"What do you want?  It must be very late."\r\n\r\n"Nearly half-past twelve, by your watch.  I am sorry I disturbed you.\r\nGood-night."\r\n\r\nAs she withdrew with the watch in her hand, she whispered to Morris:\r\n\r\n"Lie still.  Don\'t be uneasy.  I will come again presently."  So, in a\r\nfew minutes, as seemed to intently listening ears, the house was clear\r\nof the intruders.  Within a quarter of an hour Margaret had beckoned\r\nMorris out of Hester\'s room, and had explained the case to her.  They\r\nwent round the house, and found that all the little plate they had was\r\ngone, and the cheese from the pantry.  Morris\'s cloth cloak was left\r\nhanging on its pin, and even Edward\'s old hat.  From these\r\ncircumstances, and from the dialect of the only speaker, Margaret\r\nthought the thieves must be country people from the neighbourhood, who\r\ncould not wear the old clothes of the gentry without danger of\r\ndetection.  They had come in from the surgery, whose outer door was\r\nsufficiently distant from the inhabited rooms of the house to be forced\r\nwithout the noise being heard.  Morris and Margaret barricaded this door\r\nas well as they could, with such chests and benches as they were able to\r\nmove without making themselves heard up-stairs: and then Morris, at\r\nMargaret\'s earnest desire, stole back to bed.  Anything rather than\r\nalarm Hester.\r\n\r\nWhile they were below, Maria had put on more coals, and restored some\r\norder and comfort to the table and the fireside.  She concluded that\r\nsleep was out of the question for this night.  For some moments after\r\nMargaret came and sat down by her, neither of them spoke.  At length\r\nMargaret said, half laughing:\r\n\r\n"That you should have come here for rest this night, of all nights in\r\nthe year!"\r\n\r\n"I am glad it happened so.  Yes; indeed, I am.  I know it must have been\r\na comfort to you to have some one with you, though only poor lame me.\r\nAnd I am glad on my own account too, I assure you.  Such a visitation is\r\nnot half so dreadful as I had fancied--not worth half the fear I have\r\nspent upon it all my life.  I am sure you felt as I did while he was\r\nhere; you felt quite yourself, did not you?  If it had not been for the\r\nwoman\'s clothes, it would really have been scarcely terrifying at all.\r\nThere is something much more human about a housebreaker than I had\r\nfancied.  But yet it was very inhuman of him to take your ring."\r\n\r\nMargaret wept more bitterly than any one had seen her weep since her\r\nunhappy days began, and her friend could not comfort her.  It was a case\r\nin which there was no comfort to be given, unless in the very faint and\r\nunreasonable hope that the ring might be offered for sale to some\r\njeweller in some market town in the county; a hope sadly faint and\r\nunreasonable; since country people who would take plate and ornaments\r\nmust, in all probability, be in communication with London rogues, who\r\nwould turn the property into money in the great city.  Still, there was\r\na possibility of recovering the lost treasure; and on this possibility\r\nMaria dwelt perseveringly.\r\n\r\n"But, Margaret," she went on to ask, "what is this about your watch?\r\nHave you indeed sold it?"\r\n\r\n"Yes.  Morris managed that for me while Hester was confined.  I am glad\r\nnow that I parted with it as I did.  It has paid some bills which I know\r\nmade Edward anxious; and that is far better than its being in a\r\nhousebreaker\'s hands."\r\n\r\n"Yes, indeed: but I am sorry you all have such a struggle to live.  Not\r\na shilling in the house but the one you gave up!"\r\n\r\n"So much for Edward\'s being out.  It happened very well; for he could\r\nnot have helped us, if he had been here.  You saw there were three of\r\nthem.  What I meant was, that Edward has about him the little money that\r\nis to last us till Christmas.  The rent is safe enough.  It is in Mr\r\nGrey\'s strong box or the bank at Blickley.  The rent is too important a\r\nmatter to be put to any hazard, considering that Mr Rowland is our\r\nlandlord.  It is all ready and safe."\r\n\r\n"That is well.  Now, Margaret, could you swear to this visitor of ours?"\r\n\r\n"No," said Margaret, softly, looking round, as if to convince herself\r\nthat he was not there still.  "No: his bonnet was so large, and he kept\r\nthe shadow of it so carefully upon his face, that I should not know him\r\nagain--at least, not in any other dress; and we shall never see him\r\nagain in this.  It is very disagreeable," she continued, shuddering\r\nslightly, "to think that we may pass him any day or every day, and that\r\nhe may say to himself as we go by, `There go the ladies that sat with\r\ntheir feet on the fender so comfortably when I went in, without leave!\'"\r\n\r\n"Poor wretch! he will rather say, `There goes the young lady that I made\r\nso unhappy about her ring.  I wish I had choked with the wine I drank,\r\nbefore I took that ring!\'  The first man you meet that cannot look you\r\nin the face is the thief, depend upon it, Margaret."\r\n\r\n"I must not depend upon that.  But, Maria, could you swear to him?"\r\n\r\n"I am not quite sure at this moment, but I believe I could.  The light\r\nfrom the fire shone brightly upon his black chin, and a bit of lank hair\r\nthat came from under his mob cap.
