I could swear to the shawl."\r\n\r\n"So could I: but that will be burned to-morrow morning.  Now, Maria, do\r\ngo to bed."\r\n\r\n"Well, if you had rather--.  Cannot we be together?  Must I be treated\r\nas a guest, and have a room to myself?"\r\n\r\n"Not if you think we can make room in mine.  We shall be most\r\ncomfortable there, shall not we--near to Morris and Hester?"\r\n\r\nRather than separate, they both betook themselves to the bed in\r\nMargaret\'s room.  Maria lay still, as if asleep, but wide awake and\r\nlistening.  Margaret mourned her turquoise with silent tears all the\r\nrest of the night.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER FORTY.\r\n\r\nLIGHTSOME DAYS.\r\n\r\nBefore he returned home in the morning, Hope went to Dr Levitt\'s, to\r\nreport of what he had seen and heard on Mr Grey\'s premises in the\r\ncourse of the night.  He was persuaded that several persons had been\r\nabout the yards; and he had seen a light appearing and disappearing\r\namong the shrubs which grew thick in the rear of the house.  Sydney and\r\nhe had examined the premises this morning, in company with Mr Grey\'s\r\nclerk; and they had found the flower-beds trampled, and drops of tallow\r\nfrom a candle which had probably been taken out of a lantern, and ashes\r\nfrom tobacco-pipes, scattered under the lee of a pile of logs.  Nothing\r\nwas missed from the yards: it was probable that they were the resort of\r\npersons who had been plundering elsewhere: but the danger from fire was\r\nso great, and the unpleasantness of having such night neighbours so\r\nextreme, that the gentlemen agreed that no time must be lost in\r\nproviding a watch, which would keep the premises clear of intruders.\r\nThe dog, which had by some means been cajoled out of his duty, must be\r\nreplaced by a more faithful one; and Dr Levitt was disposed to\r\nestablish a patrol in the village.\r\n\r\nThe astonishment of both was great when Margaret appeared, early as it\r\nwas, with her story.  It was the faint hope of recovering her ring which\r\nbrought her thus early to the magistrate\'s.  Her brother was satisfied\r\nto stay and listen, when he found that Hester knew as yet nothing of the\r\nmatter.  It was a clear case that the Greys must find some other\r\nguardian for the nights that Mr Grey spent from home; and Dr Levitt\r\nsaid that no man was justified in leaving his family unprotected for a\r\nsingle night in such times as these.  He spoke with the deepest concern\r\nof the state of the neighbourhood this winter, and of his own inability\r\nto preserve security, by his influence either as clergyman or\r\nmagistrate.  The fact was, he said, that neither law nor gospel could\r\ndeter men from crime, when pressed by want, and hardened against all\r\nother claims by those of their starving families.  Such times had never\r\nbeen known within his remembrance; and the guardians of the public peace\r\nand safety were almost as much at their wits\' end as the sickly and\r\nsavage population they had to control.  He must to-day consult with as\r\nmany of his brother magistrates as he could reach, as to what could be\r\ndone for the general security and relief.\r\n\r\nAs Hope and Margaret returned home to breakfast, they agreed that their\r\nlittle household was more free to discharge the duties of such a time\r\nthan most of their neighbours of their own rank could possibly be.  They\r\nhad now little or nothing of which they could be robbed.  It was\r\ndifficult to conceive how they could be further injured.  They might\r\nnow, wholly free from fear and self-regards, devote themselves to\r\nforgive and serve their neighbours.  Such emancipation from care as is\r\nthe blessing of poverty, even more than of wealth, was theirs; and, as a\r\ngreat blessing in the midst of very tolerable evil, they felt it.\r\nMargaret laughed, as she asked Edward if he could spare a few pence to\r\nbuy horn spoons in the village, as all the silver ones were gone.\r\n\r\nHester was not at all too much alarmed or disturbed, when she missed her\r\nwatch, and heard what had happened.  She was chiefly vexed that she had\r\nslept through it all.  It seemed so ridiculous that the master of the\r\nhouse should be safe at a distance, and the mistress comfortably asleep,\r\nduring such an event, leaving it to sister, maid, and guest, to bear all\r\nthe terror of it!\r\n\r\nDr Levitt\'s absence of mind did not interfere with the activity of his\r\nheart, or with his penetration in cases where the hearts of others were\r\nconcerned.  He perceived that the lost turquoise was, from some cause,\r\ninestimable to Margaret, and he spared no pains to recover it: but weeks\r\npassed on without any tidings of it.  Margaret told herself that she\r\nmust give up this, as she had given up so much else, with as much\r\ncheerfulness as she could; but she missed her ring every hour of the\r\nday.\r\n\r\nChristmas came; and the expected contest took, place about the rent of\r\nthe corner-house.  Mr Rowland showed his lady the bank-notes on the\r\nmorning of quarter-day, and then immediately and secretly sent them\r\nback.  Mrs Rowland had never been so sorry to see bank-notes; yet she\r\nwould have been so angry at their being returned, that her husband\r\nconcealed the fact from her.  Within an hour the money was in Mr\r\nRowland\'s hands again, with a request that he would desist from pressing\r\nfavours upon those who could not but consider them as pecuniary\r\nobligation, and not as justice.  Mr Rowland sighed, turned the key of\r\nhis desk upon the money, and set forth to the corner-house, to see\r\nwhether no repairs were wanted--whether there was nothing that he could\r\ndo as landlord to promote the comfort and security of his excellent\r\ntenants.\r\n\r\nChristmas came; and Morris found she could not leave her young ladies\r\nwhile the days were so very short.  She would receive no wages after\r\nChristmas, and she would take care that she cost them next to nothing;\r\nbut she could not be easy to go till brighter days--days externally\r\nbrighter, at least--were at hand, nor till the baby was a little less\r\ntender, and had shown beyond dispute that he was likely to be a stout\r\nlittle fellow.  She could not think of Miss Margaret getting up quite in\r\nthe dark, to light the fire; it was a dismal time to begin such a new\r\nsort of work.  Margaret privately explained to her that these little\r\ncircumstances brought no discouragement to persons who undertake such\r\nlabour with sufficient motive; and Morris admitted this.  She saw the\r\ndifference between the case of a poor girl first going to service, who\r\ntrembles half the night at the idea of her mistress\'s displeasure if she\r\nshould not happen to wake in time; such poor girl undertaking service\r\nfor a maintenance, and by no means from love in either party towards the\r\nother--Morris saw the difference between the morning waking to such a\r\nservice and Margaret\'s being called from her bed by love of those whom\r\nshe was going to serve through the day, and by an exhilarating sense of\r\nhonour and duty.  Morris saw that, while to the solitary dependant every\r\naccessory of cheerfulness is necessary to make her willingly leave her\r\nrest--the early sunshine through her window, and the morning songs of\r\nbirds--it mattered little to Margaret under what circumstances she went\r\nabout her business--whether in darkness or in light, in keen frost or\r\ngenial warmth.  She had the strength of will, in whose glow all the\r\ndisgust, all the meanness, all the hardship of the most sordid\r\noccupations is consumed, leaving unimpaired the dignity and delight of\r\ntoil.  Morris saw and fully admitted all this; and yet she stayed on\r\ntill the end of January.\r\n\r\nBy that time her friends were not satisfied to have her remain any\r\nlonger.  It was necessary that she should earn money; and she had an\r\nopportunity now of earning what she needed at Birmingham.  The time was\r\ncome when Morris must go.\r\n\r\nThe family had their sorrow all to themselves that dismal evening; for\r\nnot a soul in Deerbrook, except Maria, knew that Morris was going at\r\nall.  Maria had known all along; and it had been settled that Maria\r\nshould occupy Morris\'s room, after it was vacated, as often as she felt\r\nnervous and lonely in her lodging.  But she was not aware of the precise\r\nday when the separation of these old and dear friends was to take place.\r\nSo they mourned Morris as privately as she had long grieved over their\r\nadversity.\r\n\r\nMr Hope meant to drive Morris to Buckley himself, and to see her into\r\nthe coach for Birmingham; and he had borrowed Mr Grey\'s gig for the\r\npurpose.  He had been urged by Mr Grey not to think of returning that\r\nnight, had desired his wife and sister not to expect him, and had\r\nengaged a neighbour to sleep in the house.  The sisters might well look\r\nforward to a sad evening; and their hearts were heavy when the gig came\r\nto the door, when they were fortifying Morris with a parting glass of\r\nwine, and wrapping her up with warm things which were to come back with\r\nher master, and expressing their heart-sorrow by the tenderness with\r\nwhich they melted the very soul of poor Morris.  She could not speak;\r\nshe could resist nothing.  She took all they offered her to comfort\r\nherself with, from having neither heart nor voice to refuse.  Morris\r\nnever gave way to tears; but she was as solemn as if she were going to\r\nexecution.  The baby alone was insensible to her gravity; he laughed in\r\nher face when she took him into her arms for the last time;--a\r\nseasonable laugh it was, for it relieved his mother of some slight\r\nsuperstitious dread which was stealing upon her, as she witnessed the\r\nsolemnity of Morris\'s farewell to him.  They all spoke of her return to\r\nthem; but no one felt that there was any comfort in so vague a hope,\r\namidst the sadness of the present certainty.\r\n\r\nAs Hester and Margaret stood out on the steps to watch the gig till the\r\nlast moment, a few flakes of snow were driven against their faces.  They\r\nfeared Morris would have a dreary journey; and this was not the\r\npleasantest thought to carry with them into the house.\r\n\r\nWhile Hester nursed her infant by the fire, Margaret went round the\r\nhouse, to see what there was for her to do to-night.  It moved her to\r\nfind how thoughtfully everything was done.  Busy as Morris had been with\r\na thousand little affairs and preparations, every part of the house was\r\nleft in the completest order.  The very blinds of the chambers were\r\ndrawn down, and a fire was laid in every grate, in case of its being\r\nwanted.  The tea-tray was set in the pantry, and not a plate left from\r\ndinner unwashed.  Margaret felt and said how badly she should supply the\r\nplace of Morris\'s hands, to say nothing of their loss of her head and\r\nheart.  She sighed her thankfulness to her old friend, that she was\r\nalready at liberty to sit down beside her sister, with actually nothing\r\non her hands to be done before tea-time.\r\n\r\nIt was always a holiday to Margaret when she could sit by at leisure, as\r\nthe morning and evening dressing and undressing of the baby went on.\r\nHester would never entrust the business to her or to any one: but it was\r\nthe next best thing to watch the pranks of the little fellow, and the\r\nplay between him and his mother; and then to see the fun subside into\r\ndrowsiness, and be lost in that exquisite spectacle, the quiet sleep of\r\nan infant.  When he was this evening laid in his basket, and all was\r\nunusually still, from there being no one but themselves in the house,\r\nand the snow having by this time fallen thickly outside, Margaret said\r\nto her sister--"If I remember rightly, it is just a twelvemonth since\r\nyou warned me how wretched marriage was.  Just a year, is it not?"\r\n\r\n"Is it possible?" said Hester, withdrawing her eyes from her infant.\r\n\r\n"I wish I could have foreseen then how soon I might remind you of this."\r\n\r\n"Is it possible that I said so?--and of all marriage?"\r\n\r\n"Of all love, and all marriage.  I remember it distinctly."\r\n\r\n"You have but too much reason to remember it, love.  But how thankless,\r\nhow wicked of me ever to say so."\r\n\r\n"We all, perhaps, say some wretched things which dwell on other people\'s\r\nminds, long after we have forgotten them ourselves.  It is one of the\r\nacts we shall waken up to as sins--perhaps every one of us--whenever we\r\nbecome qualified to review our lives dispassionately;--as sins, no\r\ndoubt, for the pain does not die with the utterance; and to give pain\r\nneedlessly, and to give lasting pain, is surely a sin.  We are none of\r\nus guiltless; but I am glad you said this particular thing--dreadful as\r\nit was to hear it.  It has caused me a great deal of thought within the\r\nyear; and it now makes us both aware how much happier we are than we\r\nwere then."\r\n\r\n"We!"\r\n\r\n"Yes; all of us.  I rather shrink from measuring states of fortune and\r\nof mind, as they are at one time against those of another; but it is\r\nimpossible to recall that warning of yours, and be unaware how\r\ndifferently we have cause to think and speak now.  I felt at the time\r\nthat it was too late for us to complain of love and of marriage.  The\r\ndie was then cast for us all.  It is much better to feel now that those\r\ncomplaints were the expression of passing pain, long since over."\r\n\r\n"I rejoice to hear you say this for yourself, Margaret; though I own I\r\nshould scarcely have expected it.  And yet no one is more aware than I\r\nthat it is a blessing to love--a blessing still, whatever may be the woe\r\nthat must come with the love.  It is a blessing to live for another, to\r\nfeel far more deeply than the most selfish being on earth ever felt for\r\nhimself.  I know that it is better to have felt this disinterested\r\nattachment to another, even in the midst of storms of passion hidden in\r\nthe heart, and of pangs from disappointment, than to live on in the very\r\nbest peace of those who have never loved.  Yet, knowing this, I have\r\nbeen cowardly for you, Margaret, and at one time sank under my own\r\ntroubles.  Any one who loved as I did should have been braver.  I should\r\nhave been more willing, both for you and for myself, to meet the\r\nsuffering which belongs to the exercise of all the highest and best part\r\nof our nature: but I was unworthy then of the benignant discipline\r\nappointed to me: and at the moment, I doubt not I should have preferred,\r\nif the choice had been offered to me, the safety and quiet of a\r\npassionless existence to the glorious exercise which has been graciously\r\nappointed me against my will.  I do try now, Margaret, to be thankful\r\nthat you have had some of this exercise and discipline; but I have not\r\nfaith enough.  My thanks are all up in grief before I have done--grief\r\nthat you have the struggle and the sorrow, without the support and the\r\nfull return which have been granted to me."\r\n\r\n"You need not grieve much for me.  I have not only had the full return\r\nyou speak of, but I have it still.  It cannot be spoken, or written, or\r\neven indulged; but I know it exists; and therefore am I happier than I\r\nwas last year.  How foolish it is," she continued, as if thinking aloud,\r\n"how perfectly childish to set our hearts on what we call happiness,--on\r\nany arrangement of circumstances, either in our minds or our fortunes--\r\nso little as we know!  How you and I should have dreaded this night and\r\nto-morrow, if they could have been foreshown to us a while ago!  How we\r\nshould have shrunk from sitting down under the cloud of sorrow which\r\nappears to have settled upon this house!  And now this evening has\r\ncome--"\r\n\r\n"The evening of Morris\'s going away, and everything else so dreary!  No\r\nservant, no money, no prospect!  Careful economy at home, ill-will\r\nabroad; the times bad, the future all blank--we two sitting here alone,\r\nwith the snow falling without!"\r\n\r\n"And our hearts aching with parting with Morris (we must come back to\r\nthat principal grief).  How dismal all this would have looked, if we\r\ncould have seen it in a fairy-glass at Birmingham long ago!--and yet I\r\nwould not change this very evening for any we ever spent in Birmingham,\r\nwhen we were exceedingly proud of being very happy."\r\n\r\n"Nor I.  This is life: and to live--to live with the whole soul, and\r\nmind, and strength, is enough.  It is not often that I have strength to\r\nfeel this, and courage to say it; but to-night I have both."\r\n\r\n"And in time we may be strong enough to pray that this child may truly\r\nand wholly live--may live in every capacity of his being, whatever\r\nsuffering may be the condition of such life: but it requires some\r\ncourage to pray so for him, he looks so unfit for anything but ease at\r\npresent!"\r\n\r\n"For anything but feeding and sleeping, and laughing in our faces.  Did\r\nyou ever see an infant sleep so softly?  Are not those wheels passing?\r\nYes; surely I heard wheels rolling over the snow."\r\n\r\nShe was right.  In five minutes more, Margaret had to open the door to\r\nher brother.\r\n\r\nHope had arrived at Blickley only just in time to drive Morris up to the\r\ndoor of the Birmingham coach, and put her in as the guard was blowing\r\nhis horn.  Mr Grey\'s horse had gone badly, and they had been full late\r\nin setting off.  He had not liked the prospect of staying where he was\r\ntill morning, and had resolved to bid defiance to footpads, and return:\r\nso he stepped into the coffee-room, and read the papers while the horse\r\nwas feeding, and came home as quickly after as he could.  As he was\r\nsafe, all the three were glad he had done so; and the more that, for\r\nonce, Edward seemed sad.  They made a bright fire, and gave him tea; but\r\ntheir household offices did not seem to cheer him as usual.  Hester\r\nasked, at length, whether he had heard any bad news.\r\n\r\n"Only public news.  The papers are full of everything that is dismal.\r\nThe epidemic is spreading frightfully.  It is a most serious affair.\r\nThe people you meet in the streets at Blickley look as if they had the\r\nplague raging in the town.  They say the funerals have never ceased\r\npassing through the streets, all this week; and really the churchyard I\r\nsaw seemed full of new graves.  I believe the case is little better in\r\nany town in the kingdom."\r\n\r\n"And in the villages?"\r\n\r\n"The villages follow, of course, with differences according to their\r\ncircumstances.  None will be worse than this place, when once the fever\r\nappears among us.  I would not say so anywhere but by our own fireside,\r\nbecause everything should be done to encourage the people instead of\r\nfrightening them; but indeed it is difficult to imagine a place better\r\nprepared for destruction than our pretty village is just now, from the\r\nextreme poverty of most of the people, and their ignorance, which\r\nrenders them unfit to take any rational care of themselves."\r\n\r\n"You say, `whenever the fever comes.\'  Do you think it must certainly\r\ncome?"\r\n\r\n"Yes: and I have had some suspicions, within a day or two, that it is\r\nhere already.  I must see Walcot to-morrow; and learn what he has\r\ndiscovered in his practice."\r\n\r\n"Mr Walcot!  Will not Dr Levitt do as well?"\r\n\r\n"I must see Dr Levitt too, to consult about some means of cleansing and\r\ndrying the worst of the houses in the village.  But it is quite\r\nnecessary that I should have some conversation with Walcot about the\r\nmethods of treatment of this dreadful disease.  If he is not glad of an\r\nopportunity of consulting with a brother in the profession, he ought to\r\nbe--and I have no doubt he will be; for he will very soon have as much\r\nupon him as any head and hands in the world could manage."\r\n\r\n"Cannot you let him come to you for advice and assistance when he wants\r\nit?"\r\n\r\n"I must not wait for that.  He is young, and, as we all imagine, not\r\nover wise: and a dozen of our poor neighbours might die before he became\r\naware of as much as I know to-night about this epidemic.  No, love; my\r\ndignity must give way to the safety of our neighbours.  Depend upon it,\r\nWalcot will be glad enough to hear what I have to say--if not to-morrow,\r\nby next week at furthest."\r\n\r\n"So soon?  What makes you say next week?"\r\n\r\n"I judge partly from the rate of progress of the fever elsewhere, and\r\npartly from the present state of health in Deerbrook.  There are other\r\nreasons too.  I have seen some birds of ill omen on the wing hitherward\r\nthis evening."\r\n\r\n"What can you mean?"\r\n\r\n"I mean fortune-tellers.  Are you not aware that in seasons of plague--\r\nof the epidemics of our times, as well as the plagues of former days--\r\nconjurors, and fortune-tellers, and quacks appear, as a sort of heralds\r\nof the disease?  They are not really so, for the disease in fact\r\nprecedes them; but they show themselves so immediately on its arrival,\r\nand usually before its presence is acknowledged, that they have often\r\nbeen thought to bring it.  They have early information of its existence\r\nin any place; and they come to take advantage of the first panic of the\r\ninhabitants, where there are enough who are ignorant to make the\r\nspeculation a good one.  I saw two parties of these people trooping\r\nhither; and we shall have heard something of their prophecies, and of a\r\nfever case or two, before this time to-morrow, I have little doubt."\r\n\r\n"It is this prospect which has made you sad," said Hester.\r\n\r\n"No, my dear--not that alone.  But do not let us talk about being sad.\r\nWhat does it matter?"\r\n\r\n"Yes; do let us talk about it," said Margaret, "if, as I suspect, you\r\nare sad for us.  It is about Morris\'s going away, is it not?"\r\n\r\n"About many things.  It is impossible to be at all times unaffected by\r\nsuch changes as have come upon us; I cannot always forget what my\r\nprofession once was to me, for honour, for occupation, and for income.\r\nI confidently reckoned on bringing you both to a home full of comfort.\r\nNever were women so cherished as I meant that you should be.  And now it\r\nhas ended in your little incomes being almost our only resource, and in\r\nyour being deprived of your old friend Morris, some years before her\r\ntime.  I can hardly endure to think of to-morrow."\r\n\r\n"And do you really call this the end?" asked Margaret.  "Do you consider\r\nour destiny fixed for evermore?"\r\n\r\n"As far as you and I are concerned, love," said Hester to him, "I could\r\nalmost wish that this were the end.  I feel as if almost any change\r\nwould be for the worse; I mean supposing you not to look as you do now,\r\nbut as you have always been till now.  Oh, Edward, I am so happy!"\r\n\r\nHer husband could not speak for astonishment and delight.  "You remember\r\nthat evening in Verdon woods, Edward--the evening before we were\r\nmarried?"\r\n\r\n"Remember it!"\r\n\r\n"Well.  How infinitely happier are we now than then!  Oh! that fear--\r\nthat mistrust of myself!  You reproved me for my fear and mistrust then;\r\nand I must beg leave to remind you of what you then said.  It is not\r\noften that I can have the honour of preaching to you, my dear husband,\r\nas it is rather difficult to find an occasion; but now I have caught you\r\ntripping.  What is there for you to be uneasy about now, that can at all\r\nbe compared with what I troubled myself about then?--Since that time I\r\nhave caused you much misery, I know--misery which I partly foresaw I\r\nshould cause you: but that is over, I trust.  It is over at least for\r\nthe time that we are poor and persecuted.  I dare not and do not wish\r\nfor anything otherwise than as we have it flow.  Persecution seems to\r\nhave made us wiser, and poverty happier; and how, if only Margaret were\r\naltogether as we would see her, how could we be better than we are?"\r\n\r\n"You are right, my dear wife."  These few tender words, and her\r\nhusband\'s brightened looks, sufficed--Hester had no cares.  She forgot\r\neven the fever, in seeing Edward look as gay as usual again, and in\r\nfeeling that she was everything to that feeling, that conviction, for\r\nwhich she had sighed in vain, for long after her marriage.  She had then\r\nfancied that his profession, his family, his own thoughts, were as\r\nimportant to him as herself.  She now knew that she was supreme; and\r\nthis was supreme satisfaction.\r\n\r\nWhen Margaret sprang up to her new labours in the chill dusk of the next\r\nmorning, she flattered herself that she was the first awake; but it was\r\nnot so.  When she went down, she found her brother busy shovelling the\r\nsnow away, and making a clear path from the kitchen door to the\r\ncoal-house.  He declared it delightfully warm work, by the time he had\r\nbrought in coals enough for the day, and wanted more employment of the\r\nsame sort.  He went round to the front of the house, and cleared the\r\nsteps and pavement there; caring nothing for the fact, that two or three\r\nneighbours gazed from their doors, and that some children stood blowing\r\nupon their fingers, and stamping with their feet, enduring the cold, for\r\nthe sake of seeing the gentleman clearing his own steps.\r\n\r\n"What would the Greys say?" asked Margaret, laughing; as, duster in\r\nhand, she looked from the open window, and spoke to her brother outside.\r\n\r\n"I am sure they ought to say I have done my work well."\r\n\r\n"That is just what Hester is observing within here.  You are almost\r\nready for breakfast, are you not?  She is setting the table."\r\n\r\n"Quite ready.  What warm work this is!  Really I do not believe there is\r\nsuch a bit of pavement in all Deerbrook as this of ours."\r\n\r\n"Come--come in to breakfast.  You have admired your work quite enough\r\nfor this morning."\r\n\r\nThe three who sat down to breakfast were as reasonable and philosophical\r\nas most people; but even they were taken by surprise with the sweetness\r\nof comforts provided by their own immediate toil.  There was something\r\nin the novelty, perhaps; but Hope threw on the fire with remarkable\r\nenergy the coals he had himself brought in from the coal-house, and ate\r\nwith great relish the toast toasted by his wife\'s own hands.  Margaret,\r\ntoo, looked round the room more than once, with a new sort of pride in\r\nthere being not a particle of dust on table, chair, or book.  It was\r\nscarcely possible to persuade Edward that there was nothing more for him\r\nto do about the house till the next morning; that the errand-boy would\r\ncome in an hour, and clean the shoes; and that the only assistance the\r\nmaster of the house could render, would be to take charge of the baby\r\nfor a quarter of an hour, while Hester helped her sister to make the\r\nbeds.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast, when Hester was dressing her infant, and Margaret\r\nwashing up the tea-cups and saucers, the postman\'s knock was heard.\r\nMargaret went to the door, and paid for the letter from the "emergency\r\npurse," as they called the little sum of money they had put aside for\r\nunforeseen expenses.  The letter was for Edward, and so brief that it\r\nmust be on business.\r\n\r\nIt was on business.  It was from the lawyer of Mr Hope\'s aged\r\ngrandfather; and it told that the old gentleman had at last sunk rather\r\nsuddenly under his many infirmities.  Mr Hope was invited to go--not to\r\nthe funeral, for it must be over before he could arrive, but to see the\r\nwill, in which he had a large beneficial interest, the property being\r\ndivided between himself and his brother, subject to legacies of one\r\nhundred pounds to each of his sisters, and a few smaller bequests to the\r\nservants.\r\n\r\n"This is as you always feared," said Hester to her husband, observing\r\nthe expression of concern in his face, on reading the letter.\r\n\r\n"Indeed, I always feared it would be so," he replied.  "I did what I\r\ncould to prevent this act of posthumous injustice; and I am grieved that\r\nI failed; for nothing can repair it.  My sisters will have their money--\r\nthe same in amount, but how different in value!  They will receive it as\r\na gift from their brothers, instead of as their due from their\r\ngrandfather.  I am very sorry his last act was of this character."\r\n\r\n"Will you go?  Must you go?"\r\n\r\n"No, I shall not go--at least, not at present.  The funeral would be\r\nover, you see, before I could get there; and I doubt not the rest of the\r\nbusiness may be managed quietly and easily by letter.  I have no\r\ninclination to travel just now, and no money to do it with, and strong\r\nreasons of another kind for staying at home.  No, I shall not go."\r\n\r\n"I am very glad.  Now, the first duty is to write to Emily and Anne, I\r\nsuppose: and to Frank?"\r\n\r\n"Not to Frank just yet.  He knows what I meant to do, in case of my\r\ngrandfather recurring to this disposition of his property; and, further\r\nthan this, I must not influence Frank.  He must be left entirely free to\r\ndo as he thinks proper, and I shall not communicate with him till he has\r\nhad ample time to decide on his course.  I shall write to Emily and Anne\r\nto-day."\r\n\r\n"I am sorry for them."\r\n\r\n"So am I.  What a pity it is, when the aged, whom one would wish to\r\nhonour after they are gone to their graves, impair one\'s respect, by an\r\nunjust arrangement of their affairs!  How easily might my grandfather\r\nhave satisfied us all, and secured our due reverence at the last, by\r\nmerely being just!  Now, after admitting what was just, he has gone back\r\ninto his prejudices, and placed us all in a painful position, from which\r\nit will be difficult to every one of us to regard his memory as we\r\nshould wish."\r\n\r\n"He little thought you would look upon his rich legacy in this way,"\r\nsaid Margaret, smiling.\r\n\r\n"I gave him warning that I should.  It was impossible to refuse it more\r\nperemptorily than I did."\r\n\r\n"That must be your satisfaction now, love.  You have done everything\r\nthat was right; so we will not discompose ourselves because another has\r\ndone a wrong which you can partly repair."\r\n\r\n"My dear wife, what comfort you give!  What a blessing it is, that you\r\nthink, and feel, and will act, with me--making my duty easy instead of\r\ndifficult!"\r\n\r\n"I was going to ask," observed Margaret, "whether you have no\r\nmisgiving--no doubt whatever that you are right in refusing all this\r\nmoney."\r\n\r\n"Not the slightest doubt, Margaret.  The case is not in any degree\r\naltered by my change of fortune.  The facts remain, that my sisters have\r\nreceived nothing yet from the property, while I have had my professional\r\neducation out of it.  That my profession does not at present supply us\r\nwith bread does not affect the question at all: nor can you think that\r\nit does, I am sure.  But Hester, my love, what think you of our prospect\r\nof a hundred pounds?"\r\n\r\n"A hundred pounds!"\r\n\r\n"Yes; that is the sum set down for me when the honest will was made; and\r\nthat sum I shall of course retain."\r\n\r\n"Oh, delightful!  What a quantity of comfort we may get out of a hundred\r\npounds!  How rich we shall be!"\r\n\r\n"She is thinking already," said Margaret, "what sort of a pretty cloak\r\nbaby is to have for the summer."\r\n\r\n"And Margaret must have something out of it, must not she, love?" asked\r\nHester.\r\n\r\n"We will all enjoy it, with many thanks to my poor grandfather.  Surely\r\nthis hundred pounds will set us on through the year."\r\n\r\n"That will be very pleasant, really," observed Margaret.  "To be sure of\r\nbread for all the rest of the year!  Oh, the value of a hundred pounds\r\nto some people!"\r\n\r\n"What a pity that Morris did not stay this one other day!" exclaimed\r\nHester.  "And yet, perhaps, not so.  It might have perplexed her mind\r\nabout leaving us, and induced her to give up her new place; and there is\r\nnothing in a chance hundred pounds to justify that.  It is better as it\r\nis."\r\n\r\n"All things are very well as they are," said Hope, "as long as we think\r\nso.  Now, I am going to call on Walcot.  Good-bye."\r\n\r\n"Stop, stop one moment!  Stay, and see what I have found!" cried his\r\nwife, in a tone of glee.  "Look!  Feel!  Tell me--is not this our boy\'s\r\nfirst tooth?"\r\n\r\n"It is--it certainly is.  I give you joy, my little fellow!"\r\n\r\n"Worth all the hundreds of pounds in the world," observed Margaret,\r\ncoming in her turn to see and feel the little pearly edge, whose value\r\nits owner was far from appreciating, while worried with the inquisition\r\nwhich was made into the mysteries of his mouth.  "Now it _is_ a pity\r\nthat Morris is not here!" all exclaimed.\r\n\r\n"We must write to her.  Perhaps we might have found it yesterday, if we\r\nhad had any idea it would come so soon."\r\n\r\nNo: Hester was quite positive there was no tooth to be seen or felt last\r\nnight.\r\n\r\n"Well, we must write to Morris."\r\n\r\n"You must leave me a corner," said Hope.  "We must all try our skill in\r\ndescribing a first tooth.  I will consider my part as I walk.  Bite my\r\nfinger once more before I go, my boy."\r\n\r\nThe sisters busied themselves in putting the parlour in order, for the\r\nreception of any visitors who might chance to call, though the streets\r\nwere so deep in snow as to render the chance a remote one.  Margaret\r\nbelieved that, when the time should come, she might set the potatoes\r\nover the parlour fire to boil, and thus, without detection, save the\r\nlighting another fire.  But before she had taken off her apron, while\r\nshe was in the act of sweeping up the hearth, there was a loud knock,\r\nwhich she recognised as proceeding from the hand of a Grey.  The family\r\nresemblance extended to their knocks at the door.\r\n\r\nAs if no snow had fallen, Mrs Grey and Sophia entered.\r\n\r\n"You are surprised to see us, my dears, I have no doubt.  But I could\r\nnot be satisfied without knowing what Mr Hope thinks of this epidemic,\r\nthis terrible fever, which every one is speaking about so frightfully."\r\n\r\n"Why, what can he think?"\r\n\r\n"I mean, my dear, does he suppose that it will come here?  Are we likely\r\nto have it?"\r\n\r\n"He tells us, what I suppose you hear from Mr Grey, that the fever\r\nseems to be spreading everywhere, and is just now very destructive at\r\nBuckley.  Does not Mr Grey tell you so?"\r\n\r\n"No, indeed; there is no learning anything from Mr Grey that he does\r\nnot like to tell.  Sophia, I think we must take in a newspaper again,\r\nthat we may stand a chance of knowing something."\r\n\r\nSophia agreed.\r\n\r\n"Sophia and I found that we really had no time to read the newspaper.\r\nThere it lay, and nobody touched it; for Mr Grey reads the news in the\r\noffice always.  I told Mr Grey it was just paying so much a-week for no\r\ngood to anybody, and I begged he would countermand the paper.  But we\r\nmust take it in again, really, to know how this fever goes on.  Does Mr\r\nHope think, my dears, as many people are saying here this morning, that\r\nit is a sort of plague?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, mamma," exclaimed Sophia, "how can you say anything so dreadful?"\r\n\r\n"I have not heard my husband speak of it so," said Hester.  "He thinks\r\nit a very serious affair, happening as it does in the midst of a\r\nscarcity, when the poor are already depressed and sickly."\r\n\r\n"Ah! that is always the way, Mr Grey tells me.  After a scarcity comes\r\nthe fever, he says.  The poor are much to be pitied indeed.  But what\r\nshould those do who are not poor, have you heard Mr Hope say?"\r\n\r\n"He thinks they should help their poor neighbours to the very utmost."\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes; of course: but what I mean is, what precautions would be\r\nadvise?"\r\n\r\n"We will ask him.  I have not heard him speak particularly of this on\r\nthe present occasion."\r\n\r\n"Then he has not established any regulations in his own family?"\r\n\r\n"No.  But I know his opinion on such cases in general to be, that the\r\nsafest way is to go on as usual, taking rational care of health, and\r\navoiding all unnecessary terror.  This common way of living, and a\r\nparticularly diligent care of those who want the good offices of the\r\nrich, are what he would recommend, I believe, at this time: but when he\r\ncomes in, we will ask him.  You had better stay till he returns.  He may\r\nbring some news.  Meantime, I am sorry my baby is asleep.  I should like\r\nto show you his first tooth."\r\n\r\n"His first tooth?  Indeed!  He is a forward little fellow.  But, Hester,\r\ndo you happen to have heard your husband say what sort of fumigation he\r\nwould recommend in case of such a fever as this showing itself in the\r\nhouse?"\r\n\r\n"Indeed I have not heard him speak of fumigations at all.  Have you,\r\nMargaret?"\r\n\r\n"I should just like to know; for Mrs Jones told me of a very good one;\r\nand Mrs Howell thinks ill of it.  Mrs Jones recommended me to pour\r\nsome sulphuric acid upon salt--common salt--in a saucer; but Mrs Howell\r\nsays there is nothing half so good as hot vinegar."\r\n\r\n"Somebody has come and put up a stall," said Sophia, "where he sells\r\nfumigating powders, and some pills, which he says are an infallible\r\nremedy against the fever."\r\n\r\n"Preventive, my dear."\r\n\r\n"Well, mamma, \'tis just the same thing.  Does Mr Hope know anything of\r\nthe people who have set up that stall?"\r\n\r\nHester thought she might venture to answer that question without waiting\r\nfor her husband\'s return.  She laughed as she said, that medical men\r\navoided acquaintance with quacks.\r\n\r\n"Does Mr Hope think that medical men are in any particular danger?"\r\nasked Sophia, bashfully, but with great anxiety.  "I think they must be,\r\ngoing among so many people who are ill.  If there is a whole family in\r\nthe fever in a cottage at Crossly End, as Mrs Howell says there is, how\r\nvery dangerous it must be to attend them!"\r\n\r\nSophia was checked by a wink from her mother, and then first remembered\r\nthat she was speaking to a surgeon\'s wife.  She tried to explain away\r\nwhat she had said; but there was no need.  Hester calmly remarked that\r\nit was the duty of many to expose themselves at such times in an equal\r\ndegree with the medical men; and that she believed that few were more\r\nsecure than those who did so without selfish thoughts and ignorant\r\npanic.  Sophia believed that every one did not think so.  Some of Mr\r\nWalcot\'s friends had been remonstrating with him about going so much\r\namong the poor sick people, just at this time; and Mr Walcot had been\r\nconsulting her as to whether his duty to his parents did not require\r\nthat he should have some regard to his own safety.  He had not known\r\nwhat to do about going to a house in Turnstile-lane, where some people\r\nwere ill.\r\n\r\nA dead silence followed this explanation.  Mrs Grey broke it by asking\r\nMargaret if she might speak plainly to her--the common preface to a\r\nlecture.  As usual, Margaret replied, "Oh! certainly."\r\n\r\n"I would only just hint, my dear, that it would be as well if you did\r\nnot open the door yourself.  You cannot think how strangely it looks:\r\nand some very unpleasant remarks might be made upon it.  It is of no\r\nconsequence such a thing happening when Sophia and I come to your door.\r\nI would not have you think we regard it for ourselves in the least--the\r\nnot being properly shown in by a servant."\r\n\r\n"Oh! not in the least," protested Sophia.\r\n\r\n"But you know it might have been the Levitts.  I suppose it would have\r\nbeen just the same if the Levitts had called?"\r\n\r\n"It certainly would."\r\n\r\n"It might have been the Levitts certainly," observed Hester: "but I must\r\njust explain that it was to oblige me that Margaret went to the door."\r\n\r\n"Then, my dear, I hope you will point out some other way in which\r\nMargaret may oblige you; for really you have no idea how oddly it looks\r\nfor young ladies to answer knocks at the door.  It is not proper\r\nself-respect, proper regard to appearance.  And was it to oblige you\r\nthat Margaret carried a basket all through Deerbrook on Wednesday, with\r\nthe small end of a carrot peeping out from under the lid?  Fie, my\r\ndears!  I must say fie!  It grieves me to find fault with you: but\r\nreally this is folly.  It is really neglecting appearances too far."\r\n\r\nMr Hope did not return in time to see Mrs Grey.  When she could wait\r\nno longer, Hester promised to send her husband to solve Mrs Grey\'s\r\ndifficulties.\r\n\r\n"What would she have said," exclaimed Hester, "if she had seen my\r\nhusband\'s doings of this morning?"\r\n\r\n"Ah! what indeed?"\r\n\r\n"Actually shovelling snow from his own steps!"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I thought you meant giving away a competence.  Which act would she\r\nhave thought the least self-respectful?"\r\n\r\n"She would have had a great deal to say on his duty to his family in\r\nboth cases.  But it is all out of kindness that she grieves so much over\r\nhis `enthusiasm,\' and lectures us for our disregard of appearances.  If\r\nshe loved us less, we should hear less of her concern, and it would be\r\ntold to others behind our backs.  So we will not mind it.  You do not\r\nmind it, Margaret?"\r\n\r\n"I rather enjoy it."\r\n\r\n"That is right.  Now I wish my husband would come in.  He has been gone\r\nvery long; and I want to hear the whole truth about this fever."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER FORTY ONE.\r\n\r\nDEERBROOK IN SHADOW.\r\n\r\nIt was some hours before Hope appeared at home again; and when he did,\r\nhe was very grave.  Mr Walcot had been truly glad to see him, and, it\r\nwas plain, would have applied to him for aid and co-operation some days\r\nbefore, if Mrs Rowland had not interfered, to prevent any consultation\r\nof the kind.  The state of health of Deerbrook was bad,--much worse than\r\nHope had had any suspicion of.  Whole families were prostrated by the\r\nfever in the labourers\' cottages, and it was creeping into the better\r\nsort of houses.  Mr Walcot had requested Hope to visit some of his\r\npatients with him: and what he had seen had convinced him that the\r\ndisease was of a most formidable character, and that a great mortality\r\nmust be expected in Deerbrook.  Walcot appeared to be doing his duty\r\nwith more energy than might have been expected: and it seemed as if\r\nwhatever talent he had, was exercised in his profession.  Hope\'s opinion\r\nof him was raised by what he had seen this morning.  Walcot had\r\ncomplained that his skill and knowledge could have no fair play among a\r\nset of people so ignorant as the families of his Deerbrook patients.\r\nThey put more faith in charms than in medicines or care; and were\r\nrunning out in the cold and damp to have their fortunes told by night,\r\nor in the grey of the morning.  If a fortune-teller promised long life,\r\nall the warnings of the doctor went for nothing.  Then, again, the\r\npeople mistook the oppression which was one of the first symptoms of the\r\nfever, for debility; and before the doctor was sent for, or in defiance\r\nof his directions, the patient was plied with strong drinks, and his\r\ncase rendered desperate from the beginning.  Mr Walcot had complained\r\nthat the odds were really too much against him, and that he believed\r\nhimself likely to lose almost every fever patient he had.  It may be\r\nimagined how welcome to him were Mr Hope\'s countenance, suggestions,\r\nand influence,--such as the prejudices of the people had left it.\r\n\r\nDr Levitt\'s influence was of little more avail than Mr Hope\'s.  From\r\nthis day, he was as busily engaged among the sick as the medical\r\ngentlemen themselves; laying aside his books, and spending all his time\r\namong his parishioners; not neglecting the rich, but especially devoting\r\nhimself to the poor.  He co-operated with Hope in every way; raising\r\nmoney to cleanse, air, and dry the most cheerless of the cottages, and\r\nto supply the indigent sick with warmth and food.  But all appeared to\r\nbe of little avail.  The disease stole on through the village, as if it\r\nhad been left to work its own way; from day to day tidings came abroad\r\nof another and another who was down in the fever,--the Tuckers\'\r\nmaidservant, Mr Hill\'s shop-boy, poor Mrs Paxton, always sure to be\r\nill when anybody else was, and all John Ringworth\'s five children.  In a\r\nfortnight, the church bell began to give token how fatal the sickness\r\nwas becoming.  It tolled till those who lived very near the church were\r\nweary of hearing it.\r\n\r\nOn the afternoon of a day when its sound had scarcely ceased since\r\nsunrise, Dr Levitt and Hope met at the door of the corner-house.\r\n\r\n"You are the man I wanted to meet," said Dr Levitt.  "I have been\r\ninquiring for you, but your household could give me no account of you.\r\nCould you just step home with me?  Or come to me in the evening, will\r\nyou?  But stay!  There is no time like the present, after all; so, if\r\nyou will allow me, I will walk in with you now; and, if you are going to\r\ndinner, I will make one.  I have nobody to sit down with me at home at\r\npresent, you know,--or perhaps you do not know."\r\n\r\n"Indeed I was not aware of the absence of your family," said Hope,\r\nleading the way into the parlour, where Margaret at the moment was\r\nlaying the cloth.\r\n\r\n"You must have wondered that you had seen nothing of my wife all this\r\nweek, if you did not know where she was.  I thought it best, all things\r\nconsidered, to send them every one away.  I hope we have done right.  I\r\nfind I am more free for the discharge of my own duty, now that I am\r\nunchecked by their fears for me, and untroubled by my own anxiety for\r\nthem.  I have sent them all abroad, and shall go for them when this\r\nepidemic has run its course; and not till then.  I little thought what\r\nsatisfaction I could feel in walking about my own house, to see how\r\ndeserted it looks.  I never hear that bell but I rejoice that all that\r\nbelong to me are so far off."\r\n\r\n"I wanted to ask you about that bell," said Hope.  "My question may seem\r\nto you to savour strongly of dissent; but I must inquire whether it is\r\nabsolutely necessary for bad news to be announced to all Deerbrook every\r\nday, and almost all day long.  However far we may be from objecting to\r\nhear it in ordinary times, should not our first consideration now be for\r\nthe living?  Is not the case altered by the number of deaths that takes\r\nplace at a season like this?"\r\n\r\n"I am quite of your opinion, Mr Hope; and I have talked with Owen, and\r\nmany others, about that matter, within this week.  I have proposed to\r\ndispense, for the present, with a custom which I own myself to be\r\nattached to in ordinary times, but which I now see may be pernicious.\r\nBut it cannot be done.  We must yield the point."\r\n\r\n"I will not engage to cure any sick, or to keep any well, who live\r\nwithin sound of that bell."\r\n\r\n"I am not surprised to hear you say so.  But this practice has so become\r\na part of people\'s religion, that it seems as if worse effects would\r\nfollow from discontinuing it than from pursuing the usual course.  Owen\r\nsays there is scarcely a person in Deerbrook who would not talk of a\r\nheathen death and burial if the bell were silenced; and, if once the\r\npeople\'s repose in their religion is shaken, I really know not what will\r\nbecome of them."\r\n\r\n"I agree with you there.  Their religious feelings must be left\r\nuntouched, or all is over; but I am sorry that this particular\r\nobservance is implicated with them so completely as you say.  It will be\r\nwell if it does not soon become an impossibility to toll the bell for\r\nall who die."\r\n\r\n"It would be well, too," said Dr Levitt, "if this were the only\r\nsuperstition the people entertained.  They are more terrified with some\r\nothers than with this bell.  I am afraid they are more depressed by\r\ntheir superstitions than sustained by their religion.  Have you\r\nobserved, Hope, how many of them stand looking at the sky every night?"\r\n\r\n"Yes; and we hear, wherever we go, of fiery swords, and dreadful angels,\r\nseen in the clouds; and the old prophecies have all come up again--at\r\nleast, all of them that are dismal.  As for the death-watches, they are\r\nout of number; and there is never a fire lighted but a coffin flies\r\nout."\r\n\r\n"And this story of a ghost of a coffin, with four ghosts to bear it,\r\nthat goes up and down in the village all night long," said Hester, "I\r\nreally do not wonder that it shakes the nerves of the sick to hear of\r\nit.  They say that no one can stop those bearers, or get any answer from\r\nthem: but on they glide, let what will be in their way."\r\n\r\n"Come, tell me," said Dr Levitt, "have not you yourself looked out for\r\nthat sight?"\r\n\r\nHester acknowledged that she had seen a real substantial coffin, carried\r\nby human bearers, pass down the middle of the street, at an hour past\r\nmidnight; the removal of a body from a house where it had died, she\r\nsupposed, to another whence it was to be buried.  This coffin and the\r\nghostly one she took to be one and the same.\r\n\r\nDr Levitt mentioned instances of superstition, which could scarcely\r\nhave been believed by him, if related by another.\r\n\r\n"Do you know the Platts?" he inquired of Hope.  "Have you seen the poor\r\nwoman that lies ill there with her child?"\r\n\r\n"Yes: what a state of destitution they are in!"\r\n\r\n"At the very time that that woman and her child are lying on shavings,\r\nbegged from the carpenter\'s yard, her mother finds means to fee the\r\nfortune-teller in the lane for reading a dream.  The fortune-teller\r\ndooms the child, and speaks doubtfully of the mother."\r\n\r\n"I could not conceive the reason why no one of the family would do\r\nanything for the boy.  I used what authority I could, while I was there;\r\nbut I fear he has been left to his fate since.  The neighbours will not\r\nenter the house."\r\n\r\n"What neighbours?" said Margaret.  "You have never so much as asked me."\r\n\r\n"You are our main stay at home, Margaret.  I could ask no more of you\r\nthan you do here."\r\n\r\nMargaret was now putting the dinner on the table.  It consisted of a\r\nbowl of potatoes, salt, the loaf and butter, and a pitcher of water.\r\nDr Levitt said grace, and they sat down, without one word of apology\r\nfrom host or hostess.  Though Dr Levitt had not been prepared for an\r\nevidence like this of the state of affairs in the family, he had known\r\nenough of their adversity to understand the case now at a glance.  No\r\none ate more heartily than he; and the conversation went on as if a\r\nsumptuous feast had been spread before the party.\r\n\r\n"I own myself disappointed," said Hope, "in finding among our neighbours\r\nso little disposition to help each other.  I hardly understand it,\r\ntrusting as I have ever done in the generosity of the poor, and having\r\nalways before seen my faith justified.  The apathy of some, and the\r\nselfish terrors of others, are worse to witness than the disease\r\nitself."\r\n\r\n"How can you wonder," said Dr Levitt, "when they have such an example\r\nbefore their eyes in certain of their neighbours, to whom they are\r\naccustomed to look up?  Sir William Hunter and his lady are enough to\r\nparalyse the morals of the whole parish at a time like this.  Do not you\r\nknow the plan they go upon?  They keep their outer gates locked, lest\r\nany one from the village should set foot within their grounds; every\r\narticle left at the lodge for the use of the family is fumigated before\r\nit is admitted into the house: and it is generally understood that\r\nneither the gentleman nor the lady will leave the estate, in any\r\nemergency whatever, till the disease has entirely passed away.  Our poor\r\nare not to have the solace of their presence even in church, during this\r\ntime of peril, when the face of the prosperous is like light in a dark\r\nplace.  Sir William makes it no secret that they would have left home\r\naltogether, if they could have hoped to be safer anywhere else--if they\r\ncould have gone anywhere without danger of meeting the fever."\r\n\r\n"If the fact had not been," said Hester, "as Mrs Howell states it, that\r\nthe epidemic prevails partially everywhere."\r\n\r\n"There is a case where Lady Hunter\'s example immediately operates,"\r\nobserved Dr Levitt.  "If Lady Hunter had not forgotten herself in her\r\nduty, Mrs Howell would have given the benefit of her good offices to\r\nsome whom she might have served; for she is really a kind-hearted woman:\r\nbut she is struck with a panic because Lady Hunter is, and one cannot\r\nget a word with her or Miss Miskin."\r\n\r\n"I saw that her shutters were nearly closed," observed Margaret.  "I\r\nsupposed she had lost some relation."\r\n\r\n"No: she is only trying to shut out the fever.  She and Miss Miskin are\r\nafraid of the milkman, and each tries to put upon the other the peril of\r\nserving a customer.  This panic will destroy us if it spreads."\r\n\r\nThe sisters looked at each other, and in one glance exchanged agreement\r\nthat the time was fully come for them to act abroad, let what would\r\nbecome of their home comforts.\r\n\r\n"I ought to add, however," said Dr Levitt, "that Sir William Hunter has\r\nsupplied my poor\'s purse with money very liberally.  I spend his money\r\nas freely as my own at a time like this; but I tell him that one hour of\r\nhis presence among us would do more good than all the gold he can send.\r\nHis answer comes in the shape of a handsome draft on his banker,\r\nsmelling strongly of aromatic vinegar.  They fumigate even their\r\nblotting-paper, it seems to me.  I did hope my last letter would have\r\nbrought him to call."\r\n\r\n"Our friends are very ready with their money," said Hope.  "I should\r\nhave begged of you before this, but that Mr Grey has been liberal in\r\nthat way.  He concludes it to be impossible that he should look himself\r\ninto the wants of the village; but he permits me to use his purse pretty\r\nfreely.  Is there anything that you can suggest that can be done by me,\r\nDr Levitt?  Is there any case unknown to me where I can be of service?"\r\n\r\n"Or I?" said Margaret.  "My brother and sister will spare me, and put up\r\nwith some hardship at home, I know, if you can point out any place where\r\nI can be more useful."\r\n\r\n"To be sure I can.  Much as I like to come to your house, to witness and\r\nfeel the thorough comfort which I always find in it, I own I shall care\r\nlittle to see everything at sixes and sevens here for a few weeks, if\r\nyou will give me your time and talents for such services as we gentlemen\r\ncannot perform, and as we cannot at present hire persons to undertake.\r\nYou see I take you at your word, my dear young lady.  If you had not\r\noffered, I should not have asked you: as you have, I snatch at the good\r\nyou hold out.  I mean to preach a very plain sermon next Sunday on the\r\nduties of neighbours in a season of distress like this: and I shall do\r\nit with the better hope, if I have, meanwhile, a fellow-labourer of your\r\nsex, no less valuable in her way than my friend Hope in his."\r\n\r\n"I shall come and hear your sermon," said Hester, "if Margaret will take\r\ncharge of my boy for the hour.  I want to see clearly what is my duty at\r\na time when claims conflict as they do now."\r\n\r\nThere was at present no time for the conscientious and charitable to\r\nlose in daylight loiterings over the table, or chat by the fireside.  In\r\na few minutes the table was cleared, and Margaret ready to proceed with\r\nDr Levitt to the Platts\' Cottage.\r\n\r\nAs soon as Margaret saw what was the real state of affairs in the\r\ncottage, she sent away Dr Levitt, who could be of no use till some\r\ndegree of decency was instituted in the miserable abode.  What to set\r\nabout first was Margaret\'s difficulty.  There was no one to help her but\r\nMrs Platt\'s mother, who was sitting down to wait the result of the\r\nfortune-teller\'s predictions.  Her daughter lay moaning on a bedstead\r\nspread with shavings only, and she had no covering whatever but a\r\nblanket worn into a large hole in the middle.  The poor woman\'s long\r\nhair, unconfined by any cap, strayed about her bare and emaciated\r\nshoulders, and her shrunken bands picked at the blanket incessantly,\r\neverything appearing to her diseased vision covered with black spots.\r\nNever before had so squalid an object met Margaret\'s eyes.  The husband\r\nsat by the empty grate, stooping and shrinking, and looking at the floor\r\nwith an idiotic expression of countenance, as appeared through the\r\nhandkerchief which was tied over his head.  He was just sinking into the\r\nfever.  His boy lay on a heap of rags in the corner, his head also tied\r\nup, but the handkerchief stiff with the black blood which was still\r\noozing from his nose, ears, and mouth.  It was inconceivable to Margaret\r\nthat her brother, with Mr Grey\'s money in his pocket, could have left\r\nthe family in this state.  He had not.  There were cinders in the hearth\r\nwhich showed that there had been a fire; and the old woman acknowledged\r\nthat a pair of sheets and a rug had been pawned to the fortune-teller in\r\nthe lane since the morning.  There had been food; but nobody had any\r\nappetite but herself, and she had eaten it up.  The fortune-teller had\r\ncharmed the pail of fresh water that stood under the bed, and had\r\npromised a new spell in the morning.\r\n\r\nIn a case of such extremity, Margaret had no fears.  She set forth alone\r\nfor the fortune-teller\'s, not far off, and redeemed the sheets and\r\nblanket, which were quite clean.  As she went, she was sorry she had\r\ndismissed Dr Levitt so soon.  As a magistrate, he could have\r\nimmediately compelled the restoration of the bedding.  The use of his\r\nname, however, answered the purpose, and the conjurer even offered to\r\ncarry the articles for her to Platt\'s house.  She so earnestly desired\r\nto keep him and her charge apart, that she preferred loading herself\r\nwith the package.  Then the shavings were found to be in such a state\r\nthat every shred of them must be removed before the sick man could be\r\nallowed to lie down.  No time was to be lost.  In the face of the old\r\nwoman\'s protestations that her daughter should not stir, Margaret spread\r\nthe bedding on the floor, wrapped the sick woman in a sheet, and laid\r\nher upon it, finding the poor creature so light from emaciation that she\r\nwas as easy to lift as a child.  The only thing that the old woman would\r\nconsent to do, was to go with a pencil note to Mr Grey, and bring back\r\nthe clean dry straw which would be given her in his yard.  She went, in\r\nhopes of receiving something else with the straw; and while she was\r\ngone, Margaret was quite alone with the sick family.\r\n\r\nStruggling to surmount her disgust at the task, she resolved to employ\r\nthe interval in removing the shavings.  The pail containing the charmed\r\nwater was the only thing in the cottage which would hold them; and she\r\nmade bold to empty it in the ditch close at hand.  Platt was capable of\r\nwatching all she did; and he made a frightful gesture of rage at her as\r\nshe re-entered.  She saw in the shadow of the handkerchief his quivering\r\nlips move in the act of speaking, and her ear caught the words of an\r\noath.  Her situation now was far from pleasant; but it was still a\r\nrelief that no one was by to witness what she saw and was doing.  She\r\nconveyed pailful after pailful of the noisome shavings to the dunghill\r\nat the back of the cottage, wondering the while that the inhabitants of\r\nthe dwelling were not all dead of the fever long ago.  She almost gave\r\nover her task when a huge toad crawled upon her foot from its\r\nresting-place among the shavings.  She shrunk from it, and was glad to\r\nsee it make for the door of its own accord.  Platt again growled, and\r\nclenched his fist at her.  He probably thought that she had again broken\r\na charm for which he had paid money.  She spoke kindly and cheerfully,\r\nagain and again; but he was either deaf or too ill to understand.  To\r\nrelieve the sense of dreariness, she went to work again.  She thoroughly\r\ncleansed the pail, and filled it afresh from the brook, looking\r\nanxiously down the lane for the approach of some human creature, and\r\nthen applied herself to rubbing the bedstead as dry and clean as she\r\ncould, with an apron of the old woman\'s.\r\n\r\nIn due time her messenger returned; and with her Ben, carrying a truss\r\nof straw.  His face was the face of a friend.\r\n\r\n"We must have some warm water, Ben, to clean these poor creatures; and\r\nthere seems to be nothing to make a fire with."\r\n\r\n"And it would take a long time, Miss, to get the coals, and heat the\r\nwater; and the poor soul lying there all the time.  Could not I bring\r\nyou a pail of hot water from the `Bonnet-so-Blue\' quicker than that?"\r\n\r\n"Do; and soap and towels from home."\r\n\r\nBen was gone with the pail.  During the whole time of spreading the\r\nstraw on the bedstead, the old woman remonstrated against anything being\r\ndone to her daughter, beyond laying her where she was before, and giving\r\nher a little warm spirits; but when she discovered that the charmed\r\nwater had been thrown out into the ditch, all to her seemed over.  Her\r\nlast hope was gone; and she sat down in sulky silence, eyeing Margaret\'s\r\nproceedings without any offer to help.\r\n\r\nWhen the warm water arrived, and the sick woman seemed to like the\r\nsponging and drying of her fevered limbs, the mother began to relent,\r\nand at last approached to give her assistance, holding her poor daughter\r\nin her arms while Margaret spread the blanket and sheet on the straw,\r\nand then lifting the patient into the now clean bed.  She was still\r\nunwilling to waste any time and trouble on the child in the corner; but\r\nMargaret was peremptory.  She saw that he was dying; but not the less\r\nfor this must he be made as comfortable as circumstances would permit.\r\nIn half an hour he, too, was laid on his bed of clean straw; and the\r\nfilthy rags with which he had been surrounded were deposited out of\r\ndoors till some one who would wash them could come for them.  By a\r\npromise of fire and food, Margaret bribed the old woman to let things\r\nremain as they were while she went for her brother, whose skill and care\r\nshe hoped might now have some chance of saving his patients.  She\r\nrecommended that Platt himself should not attempt to sit up any longer,\r\nand engaged to return in half an hour.\r\n\r\nShe paused on the threshold a minute, to see how far Platt was able to\r\nwalk; so great seemed to be the difficulty with which he raised himself\r\nfrom his chair, with the old woman\'s assistance.  Once he stumbled, and\r\nwould have fallen, if Margaret had not sprung to his side.  On\r\nrecovering himself; he wrenched his arm from her, and pushed her\r\nbackwards with more force than she had supposed he possessed.  There was\r\na half-smile on the old woman\'s face as he did this, which made Margaret\r\nshudder; but she was more troubled by a look from the man, which she\r\ncaught from beneath the handkerchief that bound his head; a look which\r\nshe could not but fancy she had met before with the same feeling of\r\nuneasiness.\r\n\r\nWhen she had seen him safely seated on the bedside, she hastened away\r\nfor her brother.  They lost no more time in returning than just to step\r\nto Widow Rye\'s, to ask whether she would sit up with this miserable\r\nfamily this night.  The widow would have done anything else in the world\r\nfor Mr Hope; and she did not positively refuse to do this; but the fear\r\nof her neighbours had so infected her, and her terror of a sick-room was\r\nso extreme, that it was evident her presence there would do more harm\r\nthan good.  She was glad to compound for a less hazardous service, and\r\nagreed to wash for the sick with all diligence, if she was not required\r\nto enter the houses, but might fetch the linen from tubs of water placed\r\noutside the doors.  After setting on plenty of water to heat, she now\r\nfollowed Hope and Margaret to the cottage in the lane.\r\n\r\nIt was nearly dark, and they walked rapidly, Margaret describing as they\r\nwent what she had done, and what she thought remained to be done, to\r\ngive Mrs Platt a chance of recovery.\r\n\r\n"What now?  Why do you start so?" cried Hope, as she stopped short in\r\nthe middle of a sentence.\r\n\r\nMargaret even stood still for one moment.  Hope looked the way she was\r\nlooking, and saw, in the little twilight that remained, the figure of\r\nsome one who had been walking on the opposite side of the road, but\r\nwhose walk was now quickened to a run.\r\n\r\n"It is--it is he," said Hope, as Philip disappeared in the darkness.\r\nAnswering to what he knew must be in Margaret\'s thoughts, he continued--\r\n\r\n"He knows the state the village is in--the danger that we are all in,\r\nand he cannot stay away."\r\n\r\n"`We!\'  `All?\'"\r\n\r\n"When I say `we,\' I mean you particularly."\r\n\r\n"If you think so--" murmured Margaret, and stopped for breath.\r\n\r\n"I think so; but it does not follow that there is any change.  He has\r\nalways loved you.  Margaret, do not deceive yourself.  Do not afflict\r\nyourself with expectations--"\r\n\r\n"Do not speak to me, brother.  I cannot bear a word from you about him."\r\n\r\nHope sighed deeply, but he could not remonstrate.  He knew that Margaret\r\nhad only too much reason for saying this.  They walked on in entire\r\nsilence to the lane.\r\n\r\nA fire was now kindled, and a light dimly burned in Platt\'s cottage.  As\r\nMargaret stood by the bedside, watching her brother\'s examination of his\r\npatient, and anxious to understand rightly the directions he was giving,\r\nthe poor woman half raised her head from her pillow, and fixed her dull\r\neyes on Margaret\'s face, saying, as if thinking aloud:\r\n\r\n"The lady has heard some good news, sure.  She looks cheerful-like."\r\n\r\nThe mother herself turned round to stare, and, for the first time,\r\ndropped a curtsey.\r\n\r\n"I hope we shall see you look cheerful too, one day soon, if we nurse\r\nyou well," said Margaret.\r\n\r\n"Then, Miss, don\'t let them move me, to take the blankets away again."\r\n\r\n"You shall not be moved unless you wish it.  I am going to stay with you\r\nto-night."\r\n\r\nHer brother did not oppose this, for he did not know of the unpleasant\r\nglances and mutterings, with which Platt rewarded all Margaret\'s good\r\noffices.  Hope believed he should himself be out all night among his\r\npatients.  He would come early in the morning, and now fairly warned\r\nMargaret that it was very possible that the child might die in the\r\ncourse of the night.  She was not deterred by this, nor by her dread of\r\nthe sick man.  She had gained a new strength of soul, and this night she\r\nfeared nothing.  During the long hours there was much to do--three\r\nsufferers at once requiring her cares; and amidst all that she did, she\r\nwas sustained by the thought that she had seen Philip, and that he was\r\nnear.  The abyss of nothingness was passed, and she now trod the ground\r\nof certainty of his existence, and of his remembrance.  When her brother\r\nentered, letting in the first grey of the morning as he opened the\r\ncottage door, he found her almost untired, almost gay.  Platt was worse,\r\nhis wife much the same, and the child still living.  The old woman\'s\r\nheart was so far touched with the unwonted comfort of the past night,\r\nand with her having been allowed, and even encouraged, to take her rest,\r\nthat she now offered her bundle of clothes for the lady to lie down\r\nupon; and when that favour was declined, readily promised not to part\r\nwith any article to the fortune-teller, till she should see some of Mr\r\nHope\'s family again.\r\n\r\nHope thought Mrs Platt might possibly get through: and this was all\r\nthat was said on the way home.  Margaret lay down to rest, to sweet\r\nsleep, for a couple of hours: and when she appeared below, her brother\r\nand sister had half done breakfast, and Mr Grey and his twin daughters\r\nwere with them.\r\n\r\nMr Grey came to say that he and all his family were to leave Deerbrook\r\nin two hours.  Where they should settle for the present, they had not\r\nyet made up their minds.  The first object was to get away, the epidemic\r\nbeing now really too frightful to be encountered any longer.  They\r\nshould proceed immediately to Brighton, and there determine whether to\r\ngo to the Continent, or seek some healthy place nearer home, to stay in,\r\ntill Deerbrook should again be habitable.  They were extremely anxious\r\nto carry Hester, Margaret, and the baby, with them.  They knew Mr Hope\r\ncould not desert his posts: but they thought he would feel as Dr Levitt\r\ndid, far happier to know that his family were out of danger, than to\r\nhave them with him.  Hester had firmly refused to go, from the first\r\nmention of the plan; and now Margaret was equally decided in expressing\r\nher determination to stay.  Mr Grey urged the extreme danger: Fanny and\r\nMary hung about her, and implored her to go, and to carry the baby with\r\nher.  They should so like to have the baby with them for a great many\r\nweeks! and they would take care of him, and play with him all day long.\r\nTheir father once more interposed for the child\'s sake.  Hester might go\r\nto Brighton, there wean her infant, and return to her husband; so that\r\nthe little helpless creature might at least be safe.  Mr Grey would not\r\nconceal that he considered this a positive duty--that the parents would\r\nhave much to answer for, if anything should happen to the boy at home.\r\nThe parents\' hearts swelled.  They looked at each other, and felt that\r\nthis was not a moment in which to perplex themselves with calculations\r\nof incalculable things--with comparisons of the dangers which threatened\r\ntheir infant abroad and at home.  This was a decision for their hearts\r\nto make.  Their hearts decided that their child\'s right place was in his\r\nparents\' arms; and that their best hope now, as at all other times, was\r\nto live and die together.\r\n\r\nHester had heard from her husband of the apparition of the preceding\r\nevening, and she therefore knew that there was less of `enthusiasm,\' as\r\nMr Grey called what some others would have named virtue, in Margaret\'s\r\ndetermination to stay, than might appear.  If Philip was here, how vain\r\nmust be all attempts to remove her!  Mr Grey might as well set about\r\npersuading the old church tower to go with him: and so he found.\r\n\r\n"Oh, cousin Margaret," said Mary, in a whisper, with a face of much\r\nsorrow, "mamma will not ask Miss Young to go with us!  If she should be\r\nill while we are gone!  If she should die!"\r\n\r\n"Nonsense, Mary," cried Fanny, partly overhearing, and partly guessing\r\nwhat her sister had said; "you know mamma says it is not convenient: and\r\nMiss Young is not like my cousins, as mamma says, a member of a family,\r\nwith people depending upon her.  It is quite a different case, Mary, as\r\nyou must know very well.  Only think, cousin Margaret! what an odd thing\r\nit will be, to be so many weeks without saying any lessons!  How we\r\nshall enjoy ourselves!"\r\n\r\n"But if Miss Young should be ill, and die!" persisted Mary.\r\n\r\n"Pooh! why should she be ill and die, more than Dr Levitt, and Ben, and\r\nour cook, and my cousins, and all that are going to stay behind?\r\nMargaret, I do wish cousin Hester would let us carry the baby with us.\r\nWe shall have no lessons to do, you know; and we could play with him all\r\nday long."\r\n\r\n"Yes, I wish he might go," said Mary.  "But, Margaret, do you not think,\r\nif you spoke a word to papa and mamma, they would let me stay with Miss\r\nYoung?  I know she would make room for me; for she did for Phoebe, when\r\nPhoebe nursed her; and I should like to stay and help her, and read to\r\nher, even if she should not be ill.  I think papa and mamma might let me\r\nstay, if you asked them."\r\n\r\n"I do not think they would, Mary: and I had rather not ask them.  But I\r\npromise you that we will all take the best care we can of Maria.  We\r\nwill try to help and amuse her as well as you could wish."\r\n\r\n"Come, Mary, we must go!" cried Fanny.  "There is papa giving Mr Hope\r\nsome money for the poor; people always go away quick after giving money.\r\nGood bye, cousin Margaret.  We shall bring you some shells, or\r\nsomething, I dare say, when we come back.  Now let me kiss the baby once\r\nmore.  I can\'t think why you won\'t let him go with us: we should like so\r\nto have him!"\r\n\r\n"So do we," said Hester, laughing.\r\n\r\nAs the door closed behind the Greys, the three looked in each other\'s\r\nfaces.  That glance assured each other that they had done right.  In\r\nthat glance was a mutual promise of cheerful fidelity through whatever\r\nmight be impending.  There was no sadness in the tone of their\r\nconversation; and when, within two hours, the Greys went by, driven\r\nslowly, because there was a funeral train on each side of the way, there\r\nwas full as much happiness in the faces that smiled a farewell from the\r\nwindows, as in the gestures of the young people, who started up in the\r\ncarriage to kiss their hands, and who were being borne away from the\r\nabode of danger and death, to spend several weeks without doing any\r\nlessons.  Often, during this day, was the voice of mirth even heard in\r\nthis dwelling.  It was not like the mirth of the well-known company of\r\nprisoners in the first French revolution--men who knew that they should\r\nleave their prison only to lose their heads, and who, once mutually\r\nacknowledging this, agreed vainly and pusillanimously to banish from\r\nthat hour all sad, all grave thoughts, and laugh till they died.  It was\r\nnot this mirth of despair; nor yet that of carelessness; nor yet that of\r\ndefiance.  Nor were theirs the spirits of the patriot in the hour of\r\nstruggle, nor of the hero in the crisis of danger.  In a peril like\r\ntheirs, there is nothing imposing to the imagination, or flattering to\r\nthe pride, or immediately appealing to the energies of the soul.  There\r\nwere no resources for them in emotions of valour or patriotism.  Theirs\r\nwas the gaiety of simple faith and innocence.  They had acted from pure\r\ninclination, from affection, unconscious of pride, of difficulty, of\r\nmerit; and they were satisfied, and gay as the innocent ought to be,\r\nenjoying what there was to enjoy, and questioning and fearing nothing\r\nbeyond.\r\n\r\nFrom a distant point of time or place, such a state of spirits in the\r\nmidst of a pestilence may appear unnatural and wrong; but experience\r\nproves that it is neither.  Whatever observers may think, it is natural\r\nand it is right that minds strong enough to be settled, either in a good\r\nor evil frame, should preserve their usual character amidst any changes\r\nof circumstance.  To those involved in new events, they appear less\r\nstrange than in prospect or in review.  Habitual thoughts are present,\r\nfamiliarising wonderful incidents; and the fears of the selfish, the\r\nrepose of the religious, the speculations of the thoughtful, and the\r\ngaiety of the innocent, pervade the life of each, let what will be\r\nhappening.\r\n\r\nYet to the prevailing mood the circumstances of the time will interpose\r\nan occasional check.  This very evening, when Margaret was absent at the\r\ncottage in the lane, and Hope, wearied with his toils among the sick all\r\nthe night, and all this day, was apparently sleeping for an hour on the\r\nsofa, Hester\'s heart grew heavy, as she lulled her infant to rest by the\r\nfire.  As she thought on what was passing in the houses of her\r\nneighbours, death seemed to close around the little being she held in\r\nher arms.  As she gazed in his face, watching the slumber stealing on,\r\nshe murmured over him--\r\n\r\n"Oh, my child, my child! if I should lose you, what _should_ I do?"\r\n\r\n"Hester! my love!" said her husband, in a tone of tender remonstrance,\r\n"what _do_ you mean?"\r\n\r\n"I did not think you would hear me, love; but I thank you.  What did I\r\nmean?  Not exactly what I said; for God knows, I would strive to part\r\nwillingly with whatever he might see fit to take away.  But, oh, Edward!\r\nwhat a struggle it would be! and how near it comes to us!  How many\r\nmothers are now parting from their children!"\r\n\r\n"God\'s will be done!" cried Hope, starting up, and standing over his\r\nbabe.\r\n\r\n"Are you sure, Edward may we feel quite certain that we have done\r\nrightly by our boy in keeping him here?"\r\n\r\n"I am satisfied, my love."\r\n\r\n"Then I am prepared.  How still he is now!  How like death it looks!"\r\n\r\n"What, that warm, breathing sleep!  No more like death than his laugh is\r\nlike sin."\r\n\r\nAnd Hope looked about him for pencil and paper, and hastily sketched his\r\nboy in all the beauty of repose, before he went forth again among the\r\nsick and wretched.  It was very like; and Hester placed it before her as\r\nshe plied her needle, all that long solitary evening.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER FORTY TWO.\r\n\r\nCHURCH-GOING.\r\n\r\nHester went to church the next Sunday, as she wished, to hear Dr\r\nLevitt\'s promised plain sermon on the duties of the times.  Margaret\r\ngladly staid at home with the baby, thankful for the relief from the\r\nsight of sickness, and for the quiet of solitude while the infant slept.\r\nEdward was busy among those who wanted his good offices, as he now was,\r\nalmost without intermission.  Hester had to go alone.\r\n\r\nEverything abroad looked very strange--quite unlike the common Sunday\r\naspect of the place.  The streets were empty, except that a party of\r\nmourners were returning from a funeral.  Either people were already all\r\nin church, or nobody was going.  She quickened her pace in the fear that\r\nshe might be late, though the bell seemed to assure her that she was\r\nnot.  Widow Rye\'s little garden-plot was all covered with linen put out\r\nto dry, and Mrs Rye might be seen through the window, at the wash-tub.\r\nThe want of fresh linen was so pressing, that the sick must not be kept\r\nwaiting, though it was Sunday.  Miss Nares and Miss Flint were in\r\ncurl-papers, plying their needles.  They had been up all night, and were\r\nnow putting the last stitches to a suit of family mourning, which was to\r\nenable the bereaved to attend afternoon church.  Miss Nares looked quite\r\nhaggard, as she well might, having scarcely left her seat for the last\r\nfortnight, except to take orders for mourning, and to snatch a scanty\r\nportion of rest.
