She had endeavoured to procure an additional\r\nwork-woman or two from among her neighbours, and then from Blickley: but\r\nher neighbours were busy with their domestic troubles, and the Blickley\r\npeople wanted more mourning than the hands there could supply; so Miss\r\nNares and Miss Flint had been compelled to work night and day, till they\r\nboth looked as if they had had the sickness, and were justified in\r\nsaying that no money could pay them for what they were undergoing.  They\r\nbegan earnestly to wish what they had till now deprecated--that Dr\r\nLevitt might succeed in inducing some of his flock to forego the\r\npractice of wearing mourning.  But of this there was little prospect:\r\nthe people were as determined upon wearing black, as upon having the\r\nbell tolled for the dead; and Miss Nares\'s heart sank at the prospect\r\nbefore her, if the epidemic should continue, and she should be able to\r\nget no help.\r\n\r\nAlmost every second house in the place was shut up.  The blank windows\r\nof the cottages, where plants or smiling faces were usually to be seen\r\non a Sunday morning, looked dreary.  The inhabitants of many of the\r\nbetter dwellings were absent.  There were no voices of children about\r\nthe little courts; no groups of boys under the churchyard wall.  Of\r\nthose who had frequented this spot, several were under the sod; some\r\nwere laid low in fever within the houses; and others were with their\r\nparents, forming a larger congregation round the fortune-tellers\' tents\r\nin the lanes, than Dr Levitt could assemble in the church.\r\n\r\nHester heard the strokes of the hammer and the saw as she passed the\r\nclosed shop of the carpenter, who was also the undertaker.  She knew\r\nthat people were making coffins by candlelight within.  Happening to\r\nlook round after she had passed, she saw a woman come out, wan in\r\ncountenance, and carrying under her cloak something which a puff of wind\r\nshowed to be an infant\'s coffin--a sight from which every young mother\r\naverts her eyes.  As Hester approached a cottage whose thatch had not\r\nbeen weeded for long, she was startled by a howl and whine from within;\r\nand a dog, emaciated to the last degree, sprang upon the sill of an open\r\nwindow.  A neighbour who perceived her shrink back, and hesitate to\r\npass, assured her that she need not be afraid of the dog.  The poor\r\nanimal would not leave the place, whose inmates were all dead of the\r\nfever.  The window was left open for the dog\'s escape; but he never came\r\nout, though he looked famished.  Some persons had thrown in food at\r\nfirst; but now no one had time or thought to spare for dogs.\r\n\r\nMr Walcot issued from a house near the church as Hester passed, and he\r\nstopped her.  He was roused or frightened out of his usual simplicity of\r\nmanner, and observed, with an air of deep anxiety, that he trusted Mr\r\nHope had better success with his patients than he could boast of.  The\r\ndisease was most terrific: and the saving of a life was a chance now\r\nseemingly too rare to be reckoned on.  It really required more strength\r\nthan most men had to stand by their duty at such a time, when they could\r\ndo little more than see their patients die.  Hester thought him so much\r\nmoved, that he was at this moment hardly fit for business.  She said:\r\n\r\n"We all have need of all our strength.  I do not know whether worship\r\ngives it to you as it does to me.  Will it not be an hour, or even half\r\nan hour, well spent, if you go with me there?" pointing to the church.\r\n"You will say you are wanted elsewhere; but will you not be stronger and\r\ncalmer for the comfort you may find there?"\r\n\r\n"I should like it...  I have always been in the habit of going to\r\nchurch...  It would do me good, I know.  But, Mrs Hope, how is this?  I\r\nthought you had been a dissenter.  I always said so.  I have been very\r\nwrong--very ill-natured."\r\n\r\n"I am a dissenter," said Hester, smiling, "but you are not; and\r\ntherefore I may urge you to go to church.  As for the rest of the\r\nmystery, I will explain it when we have more time.  Meanwhile, I hope\r\nyou do not suppose that dissenters do not worship and need and love\r\nworship as other people do!"\r\n\r\nMr Walcot replied by timidly offering his arm, which Hester accepted,\r\nand they entered the church together.\r\n\r\nThe Rowlands were already in their pew.  There was a general commotion\r\namong the children when they saw Mrs Hope and Mr Walcot walking up the\r\naisle arm-in-arm.  Matilda called her mother\'s attention to the\r\nremarkable fact, and the little heads all whispered together.  The\r\nchurch looked really almost empty.  There were no Hunters, with their\r\ntrain of servants: there were no Levitts.  The Miss Andersons had not\r\nentered Deerbrook for weeks; and Maria Young sat alone in the large\r\ndouble pew commonly occupied by her scholars.  There was a sprinkling of\r\npoor; but Hester observed that every one in the church was in mourning\r\nbut Maria and herself.  It looked sadly chill and dreary.  The sights\r\nand sounds she had met, and the aspect of the place she was in, disposed\r\nher to welcome every thought of comfort that the voice of the preacher\r\ncould convey.\r\n\r\nThere were others to whom consolation appeared even more necessary than\r\nto herself.  Philip Enderby had certainly seen her, and was distressed\r\nat it.  He could not have expected to meet her here; and his\r\ndiscomposure was obvious.  He looked thin, and grave,--not to say\r\nsubdued.  Hester was surprised to find how she relented towards him, the\r\nmoment she saw he was not gay and careless, and how her feelings grew\r\nsofter and softer under the religious emotions of the hour.  She was so\r\nnear forgiving him, that she was very glad Margaret was not by her side.\r\nIf she could forgive, how would it be with Margaret?\r\n\r\nThe next most melancholy person present, perhaps, was Mr Walcot.  He\r\nknew that the whole family of the Rowlands remained in Deerbrook from\r\nMrs Rowland\'s ostentation of confidence in his skill.  He knew that Mr\r\nRowland would have removed his family when the Greys departed, but that\r\nthe lady had refused to go; and he felt how groundless was her\r\nconfidence: not that he had pretended to more professional merit than he\r\nhad believed himself to possess; but that, amidst this disease, he was\r\nlike a willow-twig in the stream.  He became so impressed with his\r\nresponsibilities now, in the presence of the small and sad-faced\r\ncongregation, that he could not refrain from whispering to Hester, that\r\nhe could never be thankful enough that Mr Hope had not left Deerbrook\r\nlong ago, and that he hoped they should be friends henceforth,--that Mr\r\nHope would take his proper place again, and forgive and forget all that\r\nhad passed.  He thought he might trust Mr Hope not to desert him and\r\nDeerbrook now.  Hester smiled gently, but made no reply, and did not\r\nappear to notice the proffered hand.  It was no time or place to ratify\r\na compact for her husband in his absence.  All this time, Mr Walcot\'s\r\ncountenance and manner were sufficiently subdued: but his agitation\r\nincreased when the solemn voice of Dr Levitt uttered the prayer--\r\n\r\n"Have pity upon us, miserable sinners, who now are visited with great\r\nsickness and mortality."\r\n\r\nHere the voice of weeping became so audible from the lower part of the\r\nchurch, that the preacher stopped for a moment, to give other people,\r\nand possibly himself, time to recover composure.  He then went on--\r\n\r\n"That, like as Thou didst then accept of an atonement, and didst command\r\nthe destroying angel to cease from punishing, so it may now please thee\r\nto withdraw from us this plague and grievous sickness; through Jesus\r\nChrist, our Lord."\r\n\r\nEvery voice in the church uttered `Amen,\' except Mr Walcot\'s.  He was\r\nstruggling with his sobs.  Unexpected and excessive as were the tokens\r\nof his grief, Hester could not but respect it.  It was so much better\r\nthan gross selfishness and carelessness, that she could pity and almost\r\nhonour it.  She felt that Mr Walcot was as far superior to the quacks\r\nwho were making a market of the credulity of the suffering people, as\r\nher husband, with his professional decision, his manly composure, and\r\nhis forgetfulness of the injuries of his foes in their hour of\r\nsuffering, was above Mr Walcot.  The poor young man drank in, as if\r\nthey were direct from Heaven, the suggestions contained in the\r\npreacher\'s plain sermon on the duties of the time.  Plain it was\r\nindeed,--familiarly practical to an unexampled degree; so that most of\r\nhis hearers quitted the church with a far clearer notion of their\r\nbusiness as nurses and neighbours than they had ever before had.  The\r\neffect was visible as they left their seats, in the brightening of their\r\ncountenances, and the increased activity of their step as they walked.\r\n\r\n"There, go," said Hester, kindly, to her companion.  "Many must be\r\nwanting you: but you have lost no time by coming here."\r\n\r\n"No, indeed.  But Mr Hope--"\r\n\r\n"Rely upon him.  He will do his duty.  Go and do yours."\r\n\r\n"God bless you!" cried Walcot, squeezing her hand affectionately.\r\n\r\nMrs Rowland saw this, as she always saw everything.  She beckoned to\r\nMr Walcot, with her most engaging smile, and whispered him with an air\r\nof the most intimate confidence, till she saw that her presence was\r\nwanted elsewhere, when she let him go.\r\n\r\nMr Rowland, followed by Philip, slipped out of his pew as Hester\r\npassed, and walked down the aisle with her.  He was glad to see her\r\nthere; he hoped it was a proof that all her household were well in this\r\nsickly time.  Philip bent forward to hear the answer.  Mr Rowland went\r\non to say how still and dull the village was.  The shutters up, or the\r\nblinds down, at all the Greys\' windows, looked quite sad; and he never\r\nsaw any of his friends from the corner-house in the shrubbery now.  They\r\nhad too many painful duties, he feared, to allow of their permitting\r\nthemselves such pleasures: but his friends must take care not to\r\noverstrain their powers.  They and he must be very thankful that their\r\nrespective households were thus far unvisited by the disease; and they\r\nshould all, in his opinion, favour their health by the indulgence of a\r\nlittle rational cheerfulness.  Hester smiled, aware that never had their\r\nhousehold been more cheerful than now.\r\n\r\nWhether it was that Hester\'s smile was irresistible, or that other\r\ninfluences were combined with it, it had an extraordinary effect upon\r\nPhilip.  He started forward in front of her, and offered his hand,\r\nsaying, so as to be heard by her alone--\r\n\r\n"Will you not?--I have no quarrel with you."\r\n\r\n"And can you suppose," she replied, in a tone more of compassion than of\r\nanger, "that I have none with you?--How strangely you must forget!" she\r\nadded, as he precipitately withdrew his offered hand, and turned from\r\nher.\r\n\r\n"Forget!  I forget!" he murmured, turning his face of woe towards her\r\nfor one instant.  "How little you know me!"\r\n\r\n"How little we all know each other!" said Hester, for the moment\r\ncareless what construction might be put upon her words.\r\n\r\n"Even in this place," said Dr Levitt, who had now joined them, and had\r\nheard the last words: "even in this place, where all hearts should be\r\nopen, and all resentments forgotten.  Are there any here who refuse to\r\nshake hands--at such a time as this?"\r\n\r\n"It is not for myself," said Hester, distressed: "but how can I?"\r\n\r\n"It is true; she cannot.  Do not blame her, Dr Levitt," said Philip;\r\nand he was gone.\r\n\r\nIt was this meeting which had cut short Mrs Rowland\'s whispers with Mr\r\nWalcot, and brought her down the aisle in all her stateliness, with her\r\ntrain of children behind her.\r\n\r\nWhen Hester went home, she thought it right to tell Margaret exactly\r\nwhat had happened.\r\n\r\n"I knew it?" was all that Margaret said; but her heightened colour\r\nduring the day told what unspeakable things were in her heart.\r\n\r\nHester was occupied with speculations as to what might have been the\r\nevent if Margaret had been to church instead of herself.  Her husband\r\nwould only shake his head, and look hopeless: but she still thought all\r\nmight have come right, under the influences of the hour.  Whether it\r\nwere to be wished that Philip and Margaret should understand each other\r\nagain, was another question.  Yesterday Hester would have earnestly\r\ndesired that Margaret should never see Enderby again.  To-day she did\r\nnot know what to wish.  She and Margaret came silently to the same\r\nconclusion; "there is nothing for it but waiting."  If he had heard\r\nthis, Hope would have shaken his head again.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER FORTY THREE.\r\n\r\nWORKING ROUND.\r\n\r\nSeveral days passed, and there was no direct news of Enderby.  Maria\r\nnever spoke of him, though many little intervals in Margaret\'s busy life\r\noccurred when the friends were together, and Maria ought have taken\r\noccasion to say anything she wished.  It was clear that she chose to\r\navoid the subject.  Her talk was almost entirely about the sick, for\r\nwhom she laboured as strenuously as her strength would permit.  She\r\ncould not go about among them, nor sit up with the sufferers: but she\r\ncooked good things over her fire for them, all day long; and she took to\r\nher home many children who were too young to be useful, and old enough\r\nto be troublesome in a sick house.  Between her cooking, teaching, and\r\nplaying with the children, she was as fully occupied as her friends in\r\nthe corner-house, and perhaps might not really know anything about Mr\r\nEnderby.\r\n\r\nEach one of the family had caught glimpses of him at one time or\r\nanother.  There was reason to think that he was active among Mr\r\nWalcot\'s poor patients; and Hope had encountered him more than once in\r\nthe course of his rounds, when a few words on the business of the moment\r\nwere exchanged, and nothing more happened.  Margaret saw him twice: once\r\non horseback, when he turned suddenly down a lane to avoid her; and at\r\nthe Rowlands\' dining-room window, with Ned in his arms.  She never now\r\npassed that house when she could help it: but this once it was\r\nnecessary; and she was glad that Philip had certainly not seen her.  His\r\nback was half-turned to the window at the moment, as if some one within\r\nwas speaking to him.  Each time, his image was so stamped in upon her\r\nmind, that, amidst all the trials of such near neighbourhood without\r\nintercourse, his presence in Deerbrook was, on the whole, certainly a\r\nluxury.  She had gained something to compensate for all her\r\nrestlessness, in the three glimpses of him with which she had now been\r\nfavoured.  A thought sometimes occurred to her, of which she was so\r\nashamed that she made every endeavour to banish it.  She asked herself\r\nnow and then, whether, if she had been able to sit at home, or take her\r\naccustomed walks, she should not have beheld Philip oftener:--whether\r\nshe was not sadly out of the way of seeing him at the cottage in the\r\nlane, and the other sordid places where her presence was necessary.  Not\r\nfor this occasional question did she stay away one moment longer than\r\nshe would otherwise have done from the cottage in the lane; but while\r\nshe was there, it was apt to recur.\r\n\r\nThere she sat one afternoon, somewhat weary, but not dreaming of going\r\nhome.  There lay the three sick creatures still.  The woman was likely\r\nto recover; the boy lingered, and seemed waiting for his father to go\r\nwith him.  Platt had sunk very rapidly, and this day had made a great\r\nchange.  Margaret had taken the moaning and restless child on her lap,\r\nfor the ease of change of posture: and she was now shading from his eyes\r\nwith her shawl, the last level rays of the sun which shone in upon her\r\nfrom the window.  She was unwilling to change her seat, for it seemed as\r\nif the slightest movement would quench the lingering life of the child:\r\nand there was no one to draw the window-curtain, the old woman having\r\ngone to buy food in the village.  Mrs Platt slept almost all the day\r\nand night through, and she was asleep now: so Margaret sat quite still,\r\nholding up her shawl before the pallid face which looked already dead.\r\nNothing broke the silence but the twitter of the young birds in the\r\nthatch, and the mutterings of the sick man, whom Margaret imagined to be\r\nsomewhat disturbed by the unusual light that was in the room.  It had\r\nnot been the custom of the sun to shine into any houses of late; and the\r\nplace full of yellow light, did not look like itself.  She knew that in\r\na few minutes the sun would have set; and she hoped that then poor Platt\r\nwould be still.  Meantime she appeared to take no notice, but sat with\r\nher eyes fixed on the boy\'s face, marking that each sigh was fainter\r\nthan the last.  At length a louder sound than she had yet heard from the\r\nsick man, made her look towards him; and the instant throb of her heart\r\nseemed to be felt by the child, for he moved his head slightly.  Platt\r\nwas trying to support himself upon his elbow, while in the other shaking\r\nhand, he held towards her her turquoise ring.  She remembered her\r\ncharge, and did not spring to seize it; but there was something in her\r\ncountenance that strongly excited the sick man.  He struggled to rise\r\nfrom his bed, and his face was fierce.  Margaret spoke gently--as calmly\r\nas she could--told him she would come presently--that there was no\r\nhurry, and urged him to lie down till she could put the child off her\r\nlap; but her voice failed her, in spite of herself; for now, at last,\r\nshe recognised in Platt the tall woman.  This was the look which had\r\nperplexed her more than once.\r\n\r\n"Patience! a little further patience!" she said to herself, as she saw\r\nthe ring still trembling in the sick man\'s hand, and felt one more sigh\r\nfrom the little fellow on her lap.  No more patience was needed.  This\r\nwas the boy\'s last breath.  His head fell back, and the sunlight, which\r\nstreamed in upon his half-closed eyes, could now disturb them no more.\r\nMargaret gently closed them and laid the body on its little bed in the\r\ncorner, straightening and covering the limbs before she turned away.\r\n\r\nShe then gently approached the bed, and took her ring into a hand which\r\ntrembled little less than the sick man\'s own.  She spoke calmly,\r\nhowever.  She strove earnestly to learn something of the facts: she\r\ntried to understand the mutterings amidst which only a word here and\r\nthere sounded like speech.  She thought, from the earnestness with which\r\nPlatt seized and pressed her hand, that he was seeking pardon from her;\r\nand she spoke as if it were so.  It grew very distressing--the\r\nearnestness of the man, and the uncertainty whether his mind was\r\nwandering or not.  She wished the old woman would come back.  She went\r\nto the door to look for her.  The old woman was coming down the lane.\r\nMargaret put on her ring, and drew on her gloves, and determined to say\r\nnothing about it at present.\r\n\r\n"Mr Platt has been talking almost ever since you went," said Margaret;\r\n"and I can make out nothing that he says.  Do try if you can understand\r\nhim.  I am sure there is something he wishes me to hear.  There is no\r\ntime to lose, I am afraid.  Do try."\r\n\r\nThe woman coaxed him to lie down, and then turning round, said she\r\nthought he wanted to know what o\'clock it was.\r\n\r\n"Is that all?  Tell him that the sun is now setting.  But if you have a\r\nwatch, that will show more exactly.  Are you sure you have no watch in\r\nthe house?"\r\n\r\nThe old woman looked suspiciously at her, and asked her what made her\r\nsuppose that poor folks had watches, when some gentlefolks had none?\r\nMargaret inquired whether a watch was not a possession handed down from\r\nfather to son, and sometimes found in the poorest cottages.  She\r\nbelieved she had seen such at Deerbrook.  The old woman replied by\r\nsaying, she believed Margaret might have understood some few things\r\namong the many the poor sick creature had been saying.  Not one,\r\nMargaret declared; but it was so plain that she was not believed, that\r\nshe had little doubt of Hester\'s watch having been harboured in this\r\nvery house, if it was not there still.\r\n\r\nThe poor boy, who had had little care from his natural guardians while\r\nalive from the hour of his being doomed by the fortune-teller, was now\r\nloudly mourned as dead.  Yet the mourning was strangely mixed with\r\nexultation at the fortune-teller having been right in the end.  The\r\nmother, suddenly awakened, groaned and screamed, so that it was fearful\r\nto hear her.  All efforts to restore quiet were in vain.  Margaret was\r\nmoved, shocked, terrified.  She could not keep her own calmness in such\r\na scene of confusion: but, while her cheeks were covered with tears,\r\nwhile her voice trembled as she implored silence, she never took off her\r\nglove.  In the midst of the tumult, Platt sank back and died.  The\r\nrenewed cries had the effect of bringing some neighbours from the end of\r\nthe lane.  While they were there, Margaret could be of no further use.\r\nShe promised to send coffins immediately--that stage of pestilence being\r\nnow reached when coffins were the first consideration--and then slipped\r\nout from the door into the darkness, and ran till she had turned the\r\ncorner of the long lane.  She usually considered herself safe abroad,\r\neven in times like these, as she carried no property of value about with\r\nher: but now that she was wearing her precious ring again, she felt too\r\nrich to be walking alone in the dark.\r\n\r\nShe did not slacken her pace till she approached lights and people; and\r\nthen she was glad to stop for breath.  She could not resist going first\r\nto Maria, to show her the recovered treasure; and this caused her to\r\ndirect her steps through the churchyard.  It was there that she came in\r\nview of lights and people; and under the limes it was that she stopped\r\nfor breath.  The churchyard was now the most frequented spot in the\r\nvillage.  The path by the turnstile was indeed grown over with grass:\r\nbut the great gate was almost always open, and the ground near it was\r\ntrodden bare by the feet of many mourners.  Funeral trains--trains which\r\ndaily grew shorter, till each coffin was now followed only by two or by\r\nthree--were passing in from early morning, at intervals, till sunset,\r\nand now might be often seen by torchlight far into the night.  The\r\nvillager passing the churchyard wall might hear, in the night air, the\r\ndeep voice of the clergyman announcing the farewell to some brother or\r\nsister, committing "ashes to ashes, and dust to dust."  There was no\r\ndisturbance now from boys leaping over the graves, or from little\r\nchildren, eager to renew their noisy play.  Such of the young villagers\r\nas remained above ground appeared to be silenced and subdued by the\r\nprivation, the dreariness, the neglect, of these awful days: they looked\r\non from afar, or avoided the spot.  Instead of such, the observer of the\r\ntwo funerals which were now in the churchyard, was a person quite at the\r\nother extremity of life.  Margaret saw the man of a hundred years, Jem\r\nBird, the pride of the village in his way, seated on the bench under the\r\nspreading tree, which was youthful in comparison with himself.  He was\r\nlistlessly watching the black figures which moved about in the light of\r\na solitary torch, by an open grave, while waiting for the clergyman who\r\nwas engaged with the group beyond.\r\n\r\n"You are late abroad, Mr Bird," said Margaret.  "I should not have\r\nlooked for you here so far on in the evening."\r\n\r\n"What\'s your will?" said the old man.\r\n\r\n"Grandfather won\'t go home ever, till they have done here," said a\r\ngreat-grandchild of the old man, running up from his amusement of\r\nhooting to the owls in the church tower.  "They\'ll soon have done with\r\nthese two, and then grandfather and I shall go home.  Won\'t we, granny?"\r\n\r\n"Does it not make you sad to see so many funerals?" said Margaret,\r\nsitting down on the bench beside him.\r\n\r\n"Ay."\r\n\r\n"Had you not better stay at home than see so many that you knew laid in\r\nthe ground?"\r\n\r\n"Does he understand?" she asked aside of the boy.  "Does he never answer\r\nbut in this way?"\r\n\r\n"Oh! he talks fast enough sometimes.  It is just as you happen to take\r\nhim."\r\n\r\nMargaret was curious to know what were the meditations among the tombs\r\nof one so aged as this man: so she spoke again.\r\n\r\n"I have heard that you knew this place before anybody lived in it: and\r\nnow you seem likely to see it empty again."\r\n\r\n"It was a wild place enough in my young time," said Jem, speaking now\r\nvery fluently.  "There was nothing of it but the church; and that was\r\nnever used, because it had had its roof pulled off in the wars.  There\r\nwas only a footpath to it through the fields then, and few people went\r\nnigh it--except a few gentry that came a-pleasuring here, into the\r\nwoods.  The owls and I knew it as well then as we do to-day, and nobody\r\nelse that is now living.  The owls and I."\r\n\r\nAnd the old man laughed the chuckling laugh which was all he had\r\nstrength for.\r\n\r\n"The woods!" said Margaret.  "Did the Verdon woods spread as far as this\r\nchurch in those days?  And were they not private property then?"\r\n\r\n"It was all forest hereabouts, except a clear space round the church\r\ntower.  It might be thin sprinkled, but it was called forest.  The place\r\nwhere I was born had thorns all about it; and when I could scarce walk\r\nalone, I used to scramble among the blossoms that made the ground white\r\nall under those thorns.  The birds that lived by the haws in winter were\r\nprodigious.  That cottage stood, as near as I can tell, where Grey and\r\nRowland\'s great granary is now.  There used to be much swine in the\r\nwoods then; and many\'s the time they have thrown me down when I was a\r\nyoung thing getting acorns.  That was about the time of my hearing the\r\nfirst music I ever heard--unless you call the singing of the birds music\r\n(we had plenty of that), and the bells on the breeze from a distance,\r\nwhen the wind was south.  The first music (so to call it) that I heard\r\nwas from a blind fiddler that came to us.  What brought him, I don\'t\r\nknow--whether he lost his way, or what; but he lost his way after he\r\nleft us.  His dog seems to have been in fault: but he got into a pool in\r\nthe middle of the wood, and there he lay drowned, with one foot up on\r\nthe bank, when I went to see what the harking of the dog could be about.\r\nHe clutched his fiddle in drowning; and I remember I tried to get the\r\nmusic out of it as it lay wet and broken on the bank, while father was\r\nsaying the poor soul must have been under the water now two days.  So I\r\nhave reason to remember the first music I heard."\r\n\r\n"You have got him talking now," said the grandchild, running off; and\r\npresently the owls were heard hooting again.\r\n\r\n"Whereabouts was this pool?" asked Margaret.\r\n\r\n"It is a deep part of the brook, that in hot summers is left a pond.  It\r\nis there that the chief of the sliding goes on in winter now, in the\r\nmeadow.  It is meadow now; but then the deer used to come down through\r\nthe wood to drink at the brook there.  That is how the village got its\r\nname."\r\n\r\n"So you remember the time when the deer came down to drink at the brook!\r\nHow many things have happened since then!  You have heard a great deal\r\nof music since those days."\r\n\r\n"Ay, there has been a good deal of fiddling at our weddings since that.\r\nAnd we have had recruiting parties through in war times."\r\n\r\n"And many a mother singing to her baby; and the psalm in the church for\r\nso many years!  Yes, the place has been full of music for long; but it\r\nseems likely to be silent enough now."\r\n\r\n"I began to think I should be left the last, as I was the first," said\r\nthe old man: "but they say the sickness is abating now, and that several\r\nare beginning to recover.  Pray God it may be so!  First, after the wood\r\nwas somewhat cleared, there was a labourer\'s cottage or two--now\r\nstanding empty, and the folk that lived in them lying yonder.  Then\r\nthere was the farmhouse; and then a carpenter came, and a wheeler.  Then\r\nthere was a shop wanted; and the church was roofed in and used: and some\r\ngentry came and sat down by the river side; and the place grew to what\r\nit is.  They say now, it is not near its end yet: but it is strange to\r\nme to see the churchyard the fullest place near, so that I have to come\r\nhere for company."\r\n\r\nAnd the old man chuckled again.  As she rose to go, Margaret asked\r\nwhether he knew the Platts, who lived in the cottage in the lane.\r\n\r\n"I know him to see to.  Is he down?"\r\n\r\n"He is dead and his child: but his wife is recovering."\r\n\r\n"Ay, there\'s many recovering now, they say."\r\n\r\n"Indeed! who?"\r\n\r\n"Why, a many.  But the fever has got into Rowland\'s house, they say."\r\nMargaret\'s heart turned sick at hearing these words, and she hastily\r\npursued her way.  It was not Philip, however, who was seized.  He was in\r\nthe churchyard at this moment.  She saw him walking quickly along the\r\nturnstile path, slackening his pace only for a moment, as he passed the\r\nfuneral group.  The light from the torch shone full upon his face--the\r\nface settled and composed, as she knew it would not be if he were aware\r\nwho was within a few paces of him.  She felt the strongest impulse to\r\nshow him her ring--the strongest desire for his sympathy in its\r\nrecovery: but an instant showed her the absurdity of the thought, and\r\nshe hung down her blushing head in the darkness.\r\n\r\nFrom Maria she had sympathy, such as it was--sympathy without any faith\r\nin Philip.  She had from her also good news of the state of the village.\r\nThere were recoveries talked of; and there would be more, now that\r\nthose who were seized would no longer consider death inevitable.  Mrs\r\nHowell was ill; and poor Miss Nares was down with the fever, which no\r\none could wonder at: but Mr Jones and his son John were both out of\r\ndanger, and the little Tuckers were likely to do well.  Mr James was\r\nalready talking of sending for his wife and sister-in-law home again, as\r\nthe worst days of the disease seemed to be past, and so many families\r\nhad not been attacked at all.  It was too true that Matilda Rowland was\r\nunwell to-day; but Mr Walcot hoped it was only a slight feverish\r\nattack, which would be thought nothing of under any other\r\ncircumstances.--On the whole, Maria thought the neighbours she had seen\r\nto-day in better spirits than at any time since the fever made its\r\nappearance.\r\n\r\nMargaret found more good news at home.  In the first place, the door was\r\nopened to her by Morris.  Hester stood behind to witness the meeting.\r\nShe had her bonnet on: she was going with her husband to see Mrs\r\nHowell, and make some provision for her comfort: but she had waited a\r\nlittle while, in hopes that Margaret would return, and be duly\r\nastonished to see Morris.\r\n\r\n"You must make tea for each other, and be comfortable while we are\r\naway," said Hester.  "We will go now directly, that we may be back as\r\nearly as we can."\r\n\r\n"I have several things to tell you," said Margaret, "when you return:\r\nand one now, brother, which must not be delayed.  Platt and his child\r\nare dead, and coffins must be sent.  The sooner the better, or we shall\r\nlose the poor woman too."\r\n\r\nHope promised to speak to the undertaker as he went by.\r\n\r\n"We have become very familiar with death, Morris, since you went away,"\r\nsaid Margaret, as she obliged her old friend to sit down by the fire,\r\nand prepared to make tea for both.\r\n\r\n"That is why you see me here, Miss Margaret.  Every piece of news I\r\ncould get of this place was worse than the last; and I could perceive\r\nfrom your last letter, that you had sickness all about you; and I could\r\nnot persuade myself but that it was my duty to come and be useful, and\r\nto take care of you, my dear, if I may say so."\r\n\r\n"And now you are here, I trust you may stay--I trust we may be justified\r\nin keeping you.  We have meat every day now, Morris,--at least when we\r\nhave time to cook it.  Since my brother has been attending so many of\r\nMr Jones\'s family, we have had meat almost every day."\r\n\r\n"Indeed, my dear, I don\'t know how you could keep up without it, so busy\r\nas I find you are among the sick;--busy night and day, my mistress tells\r\nme, till the people have got to call you `the good lady.\'  You do not\r\nlook as if you had lost much of your natural rest: but I know how the\r\nmind keeps the body up.  Yours is an earnest mind, Margaret, that will\r\nalways keep you up: but, my dear, I do hope it has been an easy mind\r\ntoo.  You will excuse my saying so."\r\n\r\nMargaret more than excused it, but she could not immediately answer.\r\nThe tears trembled in her eyes, and her lip quivered when she would have\r\nspoken.  Morris stroked her hair, and kissed her forehead, as if she had\r\nbeen still a child, and whispered that all things ended well in God\'s\r\nown time.\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes!  I know," said Margaret.  "Has Hester told you how prosperous\r\nwe are growing?  I do not mean only about money.  We are likely to have\r\nenough of that too, for my brother\'s old patients have almost all sent\r\nfor him again: but we care the less about that from having discovered\r\nthat we were as happy with little money as with much.  But it is a\r\nsatisfaction and pleasure to find my brother regarded more and more as\r\nhe ought to be: and yet greater to see how nobly he deserves the best\r\nthat can be thought of him."\r\n\r\n"He forgives his enemies, no doubt, heaping coals of fire on their\r\nheads."\r\n\r\n"You will witness it Morris.  You will see him among them, and it will\r\nmake your heart glow.  Poor creatures!  I have heard some of them own to\r\nhim, from their sick beds, with dread and tears, that they broke his\r\nwindows, and slandered his name.  Then you should see him smile when he\r\ntells them that is all over now, and that they will not mistake him so\r\nmuch again."\r\n\r\n"No, never.  He has shown himself now what he is."\r\n\r\n"He sat up two nights with one poor boy who is now likely to get\r\nthrough; and in the middle of the second night, the boy\'s father got up\r\nfrom his sick bed in the next room, and came to my brother, to say that\r\nhe felt that ill luck would be upon them all, if he did not confess that\r\nhe put that very boy behind the hedge, with stones in his hand, to throw\r\nat Edward, the day he was mobbed at the almshouses.  He was deluded by\r\nthe neighbours, he said, into thinking that my brother meant ill by the\r\npoor."\r\n\r\n"They have learned to the contrary now, my dear.  And what does Sir\r\nWilliam Hunter say of my master, now-a-days?  Do you know?"\r\n\r\n"There is very little heard of Sir William and Lady Hunter at present--\r\nshut up at home as they are.  But Dr Levitt, who loves to make peace,\r\nyou know, and tell what is pleasant, declares that Sir William Hunter\r\nhas certainly said that, after all, it does not so much signify which\r\nway a man votes at an election, if he shows a kind heart to his\r\nneighbours in troublesome times."\r\n\r\n"Sir William Hunter has learned his lesson then, it seems, from this\r\naffliction.  I suppose he sees that one who does his duty as my master\r\ndoes at a season like this, is just the one to vote according to his\r\nconscience at an election.  But, my dear, what sort of a heart have\r\nthese Hunters got, that they shut themselves up as you say?"\r\n\r\n"They give their money freely: and that is all that we can expect from\r\nthem.  If they have always been brought up and accustomed to fear\r\nsickness, and danger, and death, we cannot expect that they should lose\r\ntheir fear at a time like this.  We must be thankful for what they give;\r\nand their money has been of great service, though there is no doubt that\r\ntheir example would have been of more."\r\n\r\n"One would like to look into their minds, and see how they regard my\r\nmaster there."\r\n\r\n"They regard him, no doubt, so far rightly as to consider him quite a\r\ndifferent sort of person from themselves, and no rule for them.  So far\r\nthey are right.  They do not comprehend his satisfactions and ease of\r\nmind; and it is very likely that they have pleasures of their own which\r\nwe do not understand."\r\n\r\n"And they are quite welcome, I am sure, my dear, as long as they do not\r\nmeddle with my master\'s name.  That is, as he says, all over now.  After\r\nthis, however, the people in Deerbrook will be more ready to trust in my\r\nmaster\'s skill and kindness than in Sir William Hunter\'s grandeur and\r\nmoney, which can do little to save them in time of need."\r\n\r\nMargaret explained how ignorantly the poor in the neighbourhood had\r\nrelied on the fortune-tellers, who had only duped them; how that which\r\nwould have been religion in them if they had been early taught, and\r\nwhich would have enabled them to rely on the only power which really can\r\nsave, had been degraded by ignorance into a foolish and pernicious\r\nsuperstition.  Morris hoped that this also was over now.  She had met\r\nsome of these conjurors on the Blickley road; and seen others breaking\r\nup their establishment in the lanes, and turning their backs upon\r\nDeerbrook.  Whether they were scared away by the mortality of the place,\r\nor had found the tide of fortune-telling beginning to turn, mattered\r\nnothing as long as they were gone.\r\n\r\nThe tea-table was cleared, and Morris and Margaret were admiring the\r\nbaby as he slept, when Hester and her husband returned.  Mrs Howell was\r\nvery unwell, and likely to be worse.  All attempts to bring Miss Miskin\r\nto reason, and induce her to enter her friend\'s room, were in vain.  She\r\nbestowed abundance of tears, tremors, and foreboding on Mrs Howell\'s\r\nstate and prospects, but shut herself up in a fumigated apartment, where\r\nshe promised to pray for a good result, and to await it.  The maid was a\r\nhearty lass, who would sit up willingly, under Hester\'s promise that she\r\nshould be relieved in the morning.  The girl\'s fear was of not being\r\nable to satisfy her mistress, whom it was not so easy to nurse as it\r\nmight have been, from her insisting on having everything arranged\r\nprecisely as it was in her poor dear Howell\'s last illness.  As Miss\r\nMiskin had refused to enter the chamber, Hester had been obliged to\r\nsearch a chest of drawers for Mr Howell\'s last dressing-gown, which\r\nMiss Miskin had promised should be mended and aired, and ready for wear\r\nby the morning.\r\n\r\n"Margaret!" cried Hester, as her sister was lighting her candle.  The\r\nexclamation made Edward turn round, and brought back Morris into the\r\nparlour after saying `Good-night.\'  "Margaret! your ring?"\r\n\r\nThere was as much joy as shame in Margaret\'s crimson blush.  She let her\r\nsister examine the turquoise, and said:\r\n\r\n"Yes, this is the boon of to-day."\r\n\r\n"Edward\'s hundred pounds has come," said Hester: "but that is nothing to\r\nthis."\r\n\r\nMargaret\'s eyes thanked her.  She just explained that poor Platt had\r\nbeen the thief, and had restored it to her before he died, and that she\r\ncould get no explanation, no tidings of Hester\'s watch; and she was\r\ngone.\r\n\r\n"Dr Levitt\'s early stir about this ring prevented its being disposed\r\nof, I have no doubt," said Edward.  "If so, it is yet possible that we\r\nmay recover your watch.  I will speak to Dr Levitt in the morning."\r\n\r\n"Dear Margaret!" said Hester.  "She is now drinking in the hue of that\r\nturquoise, and blessing it for being unchanged.  She regards this\r\nrecovery of it as a good omen, I see; and far be it from us to mock at\r\nsuch a superstition!"\r\n\r\nAs usual, when she was upon this subject, Hester looked up into her\r\nhusband\'s face: and as usual, when she spoke on this subject, he made no\r\nreply.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER FORTY FOUR.\r\n\r\nLATE RELIGION.\r\n\r\nA few days after Morris\'s return, she told Margaret that the tidings in\r\nthe village of Miss Rowland\'s illness were not good.  Mrs Rowland was\r\nquite as sure as ever that, if anybody could cure Matilda, it was Mr\r\nWalcot; but Mr Walcot himself looked anxious; and a bed had been put up\r\nfor him in the room next to the sick child.  Margaret wondered why Mr\r\nRowland did not send to Blickley for further advice: but Morris thought\r\nthat Mrs Rowland would not give up her perfect faith in Mr Walcot, if\r\nall her children should die before her face.\r\n\r\nWhen Morris had left the room, Margaret was absorbed in speculations, as\r\nshe played with her sister\'s infant--speculations on the little life of\r\nchildren, and on their death.  Her memory followed Matilda through every\r\ncircumstance in which she had seen her.  The poor little girl\'s very\r\nattitude, voice, and words--words full, alas! of folly and vanity--rose\r\nagain upon her eye and ear, in immediate contrast with the image of\r\ndeath, and the solemnity of the life to come.  In the midst of these\r\nthoughts came tears of shame and self-reproach; for another thought (how\r\nlow! how selfish!) thrust itself in among them--that she was secure for\r\nthe present from Philip\'s departure--that he would not leave Deerbrook\r\nwhile Matilda was in a critical state.  As these tears rolled down her\r\ncheeks, the baby looked full in her face, and caught the infection of\r\ngrief.\r\n\r\nHe hung his little lip, and looked so woe-begone, that Margaret dashed\r\naway the signs of her sorrow, and spoke gaily to him; and, as the sun\r\nshone in at the moment upon the lustres on the mantelpiece, she set the\r\nglass-drops in motion, and let the baby try to catch the bright colours\r\nthat danced upon the walls and ceiling.  At this moment, Hester burst in\r\nwith a countenance of dismay.\r\n\r\n"Margaret, my husband has a headache!"\r\n\r\nA headache was no trifle in these days.\r\n\r\n"Anything more than a headache?" asked Margaret.  "No other feeling of\r\nillness?  There is nothing to wonder at in a mere headache.  It is very\r\nsurprising that he has not had it before, with all his toil and want of\r\nsleep."\r\n\r\n"He declares it is a trifle," said Hester: "but I see he can hardly hold\r\nup.  What shall I do?"\r\n\r\n"Make him lie down and rest, and let me go to Mrs Howell instead of\r\nyou.  She will be a little disappointed; but that cannot be helped.  She\r\nmust put up with my services to-day.  Now, do not frighten yourself, as\r\nif no one ever had a headache without having a fever."\r\n\r\n"I shall desire Morris to let no one in; and to bring no messages to her\r\nmaster while his headache lasts."\r\n\r\n"Very right.  I will tell her as I go for my bonnet.  One more kiss\r\nbefore I go, baby.  Do not wait tea for me, Hester.  I cannot say when I\r\nshall be back."\r\n\r\nMargaret had been gone to Mrs Howell\'s about an hour and a half, when\r\nthere was a loud and hasty knock at the door of the corner-house.  It\r\nroused Hope from a doze into which he had just fallen, and provoked\r\nHester accordingly.  There was a parley between Morris and somebody in\r\nthe hall; and presently a voice was heard calling loudly upon Mr Hope.\r\nHester could not prevent her husband from springing from the bed, and\r\ngoing out upon the stairs.  Mr Rowland was already half-way up, looking\r\nalmost beside himself with grief.\r\n\r\n"You must excuse me, Mr Hope--you must not judge me hardly;--if you are\r\nill, I am sorry... sir; but sir, my child is dying.  We fear she is\r\ndying, sir; and you must come, and see if anything can save her.  I\r\nshall never forgive myself for going on as we have been doing.  She has\r\nbeen sacrificed--fairly sacrificed, I fear."\r\n\r\n"Nay, Mr Rowland, I must comfort you there," said Hope, as they walked\r\nrapidly along the street.  "I have had occasion to see a great deal of\r\nMr Walcot and his professional conduct, in the course of the last few\r\nweeks; and I am certain that he has a very competent knowledge of his\r\nbusiness.  I assure you he shows more talent, more power altogether, in\r\nhis professional than his unprofessional conduct; and in this particular\r\ndisease he has now had much experience."\r\n\r\n"God bless you for saying so, my dear sir!  It is like you--always\r\ngenerous, always just and kind!  You must forgive us, Mr Hope.  At a\r\ntime like this, you must overlook all causes of offence.  They are very\r\ngreat, I know; but you will not visit them upon us now."\r\n\r\n"We have only to do with the present now," said Hope.  "Not a word about\r\nthe past, I entreat you."\r\n\r\nMrs Rowland, to-day reckless of everything but her child, was standing\r\nout on the steps, watching, as for the last hope for her Matilda.\r\n\r\n"She is much worse, Mr Hope; suddenly and alarmingly worse.  This way:\r\nfollow me."\r\n\r\nHope would speak with Mr Walcot first.  As he entered the study, to\r\nawait Mr Walcot, Philip passed out.  They did not speak.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Philip! speak to Mr Hope!" cried Mrs Rowland.  "For God\'s sake do\r\nnot do anything to offend him now!"\r\n\r\n"I will do everything in my power, madam, to save your child," said\r\nHope.  "Do not fear that the conduct of her relations will be allowed to\r\ninjure her."\r\n\r\n"My love," said Mr Rowland, "Mr Hope came from a sick bed to help us.\r\nDo not distrust him.  Indeed he deserves better from us."\r\n\r\n"Pray forgive me," said the miserable mother.  "I do not well know what\r\nI am saying.  But I will atone for all if you save my child."\r\n\r\n"Priscilla!" cried her brother, from the doorway, against which he was\r\nleaning.  His tone of wonder was lost as Walcot entered, and the study\r\nwas left for the conference of the medical men.\r\n\r\nAs the gentlemen went upstairs to Matilda\'s room, they saw one child\r\nhere, and another there, peeping about, in silence and dismay.  As Hope\r\nput his hand on the head of one in passing, Mr Rowland said:\r\n\r\n"There is a carriage coming for them presently, to take them away.  Anna\r\nand George are now with Miss Young, and she will take them all away.\r\nShe is very good: but I knew we might depend upon her--upon her heart,\r\nand her forgiveness.  Ah! you hear the poor child\'s voice.  That shows\r\nyou the way."\r\n\r\nMatilda was wandering, and, for the moment, talking very loud.\r\nSomething about grandmamma seeing her dance, and "When I am married,"\r\nstruck the ear as Hope entered her chamber, and entirely overset the\r\nmother.  Matilda was soon in a stupor again.\r\n\r\nIt was impossible to hold out much prospect of her recovery.  It was\r\npainful to every one to hear how Mrs Rowland attempted to bribe Mr\r\nHope, by promises of doing him justice, to exert himself to the utmost\r\nin Matilda\'s behalf.  He turned away from her, again and again, with a\r\ndisgust which his compassion could scarcely restrain.  Philip was so far\r\nroused by the few words which had been let drop below-stairs, as to\r\nchoose to hear what passed now, in the antechamber to the patient\'s\r\nroom.  It was he who decidedly interposed at last.  He sent his\r\nbrother-in-law to Matilda\'s bedside, dismissed Mr Walcot from the room,\r\nand then said--\r\n\r\n"A very few minutes will suffice, I believe, sister, to relieve your\r\nmind: and they will be well spent.  Tell us what you mean by what you\r\nhave been saying so often within this quarter of an hour.  As you hope\r\nin Heaven--as you dare to ask God to spare your child, tell us the\r\nextent to which you feel that you have injured Mr Hope."\r\n\r\nHope sank down into the window-seat by which he had been standing.  He\r\nthought the whole story of his love was now coming out.  He waited for\r\nthe first words as for a thunderclap.  The first words were--\r\n\r\n"Oh, Philip!  I am the most wretched woman living!  I never saw it so\r\nstrongly before; I believe I did it with an idea of good to you; but I\r\nburned a letter of Margaret\'s to you."\r\n\r\n"What letter?  When?"\r\n\r\n"The day you left us last--the day you were in the shrubbery all the\r\nmorning--the day the children found the shavings burnt."\r\n\r\n"What was in the letter?  Did you read it?"\r\n\r\n"No; I dared not."\r\n\r\n"What made you burn it?"\r\n\r\n"I was afraid you would go to her, and that your engagement would come\r\non again."\r\n\r\n"Then what you told me--what made me break it off--could not have been\r\ntrue."\r\n\r\n"No, it was not--not all true."\r\n\r\n"What was true, and what was not?"\r\n\r\nMrs Rowland did not answer, but looked timidly at Mr Hope.  Now was\r\nthe moment for him to speak.\r\n\r\n"It was true," said he, "that, at the very beginning of my acquaintance\r\nwith Hester and Margaret, I preferred Margaret--and that my family\r\ndiscerned that I did--as true as that Hester has long been the beloved\r\nof my heart--beloved as--but I cannot speak of my wife, of my home, in\r\nthe hearing of one who has endeavoured to profane both.  All I need say\r\nis that neither Hester nor Margaret ever knew where my first transient\r\nfancy lighted, while they both know--know as they know their own\r\nhearts--where it has fixed.  It is not true that Margaret ever loved any\r\none but you, Enderby; and Mrs Rowland cannot truly say that she ever\r\ndid."\r\n\r\n"What was it then that Margaret confided to my mother?" asked Enderby,\r\nturning to his sister.\r\n\r\n"I cannot tell what possessed me at the time to say so, but that I\r\nthought I was doing the best for your happiness--but--but, Philip, I\r\nreally believe now, that Margaret never did love any one but you.  I\r\nknow nothing to the contrary."\r\n\r\n"But my mother?"\r\n\r\n"She knew very little of any troubles in Mr Hope\'s family; and--and\r\nwhat she did hear was all from me."\r\n\r\n"Do you mean that all you told me of Margaret\'s confidences to my mother\r\nwas false?"\r\n\r\nThere was no answer; but Mrs Rowland\'s pale cheeks grew paler.\r\n\r\n"Oh God! what can Margaret have thought of me all this time?" cried\r\nPhilip.\r\n\r\n"I can tell you what she has thought, I believe," said Hope.  "Her\r\nbrother and sister have read her innocent mind, as you yourself might\r\nhave done, if your faith in her had been what she deserved.  She has\r\nbelieved that you loved her, and that you love her still.  She has\r\nbelieved that some one--that Mrs Rowland traduced her to you: and in\r\nher generosity, she blames you for nothing but that you would not see\r\nand hear her--that you went away on the receipt of her letter--of that\r\nletter which it now appears you never saw."\r\n\r\n"Where is she?" cried Enderby, striding to the door.\r\n\r\n"She is not at home.  You cannot find her at this moment: and if you\r\ncould, you must hear me first.  You remember the caution I gave you when\r\nwe last conversed--in the abbey, and again in the meadows."\r\n\r\n"I do; and I will observe it now."\r\n\r\n"You remember that she is unaware--"\r\n\r\n"That you ever--that that interview with Mrs Grey ever took place?  She\r\nshall never learn it from me.  It is one of those facts which have\r\nceased to exist--which is absolutely dead, and should be buried in\r\noblivion.  You hear, Priscilla?"\r\n\r\nShe bowed her head.\r\n\r\n"You believe that--."\r\n\r\n"Say no more, brother.  Do not humble me further.  I will make what\r\nreparation I can--indeed I will--and then perhaps God will spare my\r\nchild."\r\n\r\nHope\'s passing reflection was, "How alike is the superstition of the\r\nignorant and of the wicked!  My poor neighbours stealing to the\r\nconjuror\'s tent in the lane, and this wretched lady, hope alike to bribe\r\nHeaven in their extremity--they by gifts and rites, she by remorse and\r\nreparation.--How different from the faith which say; `Not as I will, but\r\nas thou wilt!\'"\r\n\r\n"Where _is_ Margaret?  Will you tell me?" asked Enderby, impatiently.\r\n"But before I see her, I ought to ask forgiveness from you, Hope.  You\r\nfind how cruelly I have been deceived--by what incredible falsehood--.\r\nBut," glancing at his pale sister, "we will speak no more of that.  If,\r\nin the midst of all this error and wretchedness, I have hurt your\r\nfeelings more than my false persuasions rendered necessary...  I hope\r\nyou will forgive me."\r\n\r\n"And me!  Will you forgive me?" asked Mrs Rowland, faintly.\r\n\r\n"There is nothing to pardon in you," said Hope to Philip.  "Your belief\r\nin what your own sister told you in so much detail can scarcely be\r\ncalled a weakness; and you did and said nothing to me that was not\r\nwarranted by what you believed.--And I forgive you, madam.  I will do\r\nwhat I can to relieve your present affliction; and, as long as you\r\nattempt no further injustice towards my family, no words shall be spoken\r\nby any of us, to remind you of what is past."\r\n\r\n"You are very good, Mr Hope."\r\n\r\n"I tell you plainly," he resumed, "that you cannot injure us beyond a\r\ncertain point.  You cannot make it goodness in us to forget what is\r\npast.  It is of far less consequence to us what you and others think of\r\nus than what we think of our neighbours.  Our chief sorrow has been the\r\nspectacle of yourself in your dealings with us.  We shall be thankful to\r\nbe reminded of it no more.  And now enough of this."\r\n\r\n"Where _is_ Margaret?" again asked Enderby, as if in despair of an\r\nanswer.\r\n\r\n"She is nursing Mrs Howell.  As soon as I have seen this poor child\r\nagain, I will go home, and take care that Margaret is prepared to see\r\nyou.  Remember how great the surprise, the mystery, must be to her."\r\n\r\n"If the surprise were all--" said Philip.--"But will she hear me?  Will\r\nshe forgive me?  Will she trust me?"\r\n\r\n"Was there ever a woman who really loved who would not hear, would not\r\nforgive, would not trust?" said Hope, smiling.  "I must not answer for\r\nMargaret; but I think I may answer for woman in the abstract."\r\n\r\n"I will follow you in an hour, Hope."\r\n\r\n"Do so.  Now, madam."\r\n\r\nAnd Hope followed Mrs Rowland again to the bedside of her dying child.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER FORTY FIVE.\r\n\r\nREST OF THE PLACABLE.\r\n\r\nMargaret was not at Mrs Howell\'s at the moment that her brother\r\nbelieved and said she was.  She had been there just in time to witness\r\nthe poor woman\'s departure; and she was soon home again and relating the\r\ncircumstances to Hester, by the fireside.  Even the news that Edward was\r\nnow in the same house with Philip, could not efface from her mind what\r\nshe had seen; nor could Hester help listening, though full of anxiety\r\nabout her husband.\r\n\r\n"Miss Miskin was prevailed upon to leave her room at the last, I\r\nsuppose?"\r\n\r\n"Scarcely.  Poor Nanny was supporting her mistress\'s head when I went\r\nin; and she said, with tears, that there was no depending on any one but\r\nus.  They both looked glad enough to see me: but then, nothing would\r\nsatisfy Mrs Howell but that I should warm myself, and be seated."\r\n\r\n"To the last! and she offered you some cherry-bounce, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"Yes; just as usual.  Then she told me that it would be as well to\r\nmention now, in case she should grow worse, and be in any danger, that\r\nshe should be gratified if you and I would select each a rug or screen\r\npattern from her stock, and worsteds to work it with: and she gave a\r\nbroad hint that there was one with a mausoleum and two weeping willows,\r\nwhich she hoped one of us would choose; and that perhaps her name might\r\nfill up the space on the tomb.  Poor Nanny began to cry; and this\r\naffected Mrs Howell; and she begged earnestly to see Miss Miskin."\r\n\r\n"And then she came, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"Not she!  She would not come till her friend sent a message threatening\r\nto haunt her if she did not."\r\n\r\n"Did you carry the message?"\r\n\r\n"No; but Nanny did; and, I thought, with hearty good will; Miss Miskin\r\ncame trembling, but too much frightened to cry.  She would not approach\r\nnearer than the doorway, and there fell down on her knees, and so\r\nremained the whole time she was receiving directions about the shop and\r\nthe stock,--`in case,\' as the poor soul again said, `of my getting\r\nworse, so as to be in any danger.\'  And yet Dr Levitt thought he had\r\ntold her, plainly enough, what he thought of her state this morning."\r\n\r\n"And was she aware at last? or did she go off unconsciously?"\r\n\r\n"I think she was aware; I think so from her last words--`Oh, my poor\r\ndear Howell!\'  I sat behind the curtain while she was speaking to Miss\r\nMiskin--sometimes so faintly that Nanny had to repeat her words, to make\r\nthem heard as far as the door."\r\n\r\n"That selfish wretch--Miss Miskin!"\r\n\r\n"It was very moving, I assure you, to hear not one word of reproach,--or\r\neven notice of Miss Miskin\'s desertion in this illness.  What was said\r\nwas common-place enough; but every word was kind.  I have it all.  I\r\ntook it down with my pencil, behind the curtain; for I was sure Miss\r\nMiskin would never remember it.  Mrs Howell went on till she came to\r\ndirections about the bullfinch that her poor dear Howell used to laugh\r\nto see perched upon her nightcap of a morning; and then she grew\r\nunintelligible.  I thought she was only fainting; but while we were\r\ntrying to revive her, Nanny said she was going.  Miss Miskin drew back\r\ninto the passage, shut the door, and made her escape.  Her friend looked\r\nthat way once more, and said that we had all been very good to her.  She\r\nmentioned her husband, as I told you, and then died very quietly."\r\n\r\n"Miss Miskin knows, of course?"\r\n\r\n"I told her, and did not pretend to feel much sympathy in her\r\nlamentations.  I told her she had lost a friend who would have watched\r\nover her, I believed, till her last breath, if she had been the one\r\nattacked by the fever."\r\n\r\n"What did she say?"\r\n\r\n"She exclaimed a great deal about how good we all were, and wondered\r\nwhat Deerbrook would have done without us; and said she was sure I was\r\ntoo kind to think of leaving her in the house with the corpse, with only\r\nNanny.  When I declined passing the night there, she comforted herself\r\nwith thinking aloud that her friend would not haunt her--certainly would\r\nnot haunt her--as she _had_ gone to her room at last.  Her final\r\nquestion was, how soon I thought it likely that she should feel the\r\nfever coming on, in case of her having caught it, after all, by going\r\ninto the room."\r\n\r\n"What an end to a sentimental friendship of so many years!"\r\n\r\n"I rather expect to hear in the morning that she has taken refuge in\r\nsome neighbour\'s house, and left Nanny alone with the corpse to-night."\r\n\r\n"My husband\'s knock!" cried Hester, starting up.  "How is your headache,\r\nlove?" asked she anxiously, as she met him at the room door.\r\n\r\n"Gone, quite gone," he replied.  "I must step down into the surgery for\r\na minute, about this poor little girl\'s medicine; and then I have a\r\ngreat deal to tell you."\r\n\r\nThe sisters sat in perfect silence till his return.\r\n\r\n"Matilda?" said Margaret, looking up at her brother.\r\n\r\n"She is very ill;--not likely to be better."\r\n\r\n"And poor Mrs Howell is gone," said Hester.  "What a sweep it is!  Did\r\nyou hear, love?  Mrs Howell is dead."\r\n\r\n"I hear.  It is a terrible destruction that we have witnessed.  But I\r\ntrust it is nearly over.  I know of only one or two cases of danger now,\r\nbesides this little girl\'s.  Poor Matilda!  But we have little thought\r\nto spare, even for her, to-night.  If I did not know that Margaret is\r\nready for whatever may betide," he continued, fixing his benevolent gaze\r\nupon her, "and if, moreover, I were not afraid that some one would be\r\ncoming to tell my news if I do not get it out at once, I should hesitate\r\nabout saying what I have to say."\r\n\r\n"Philip has been explaining--He is coming," said Margaret, with such\r\ncalmness as she could command.\r\n\r\n"Enderby is coming; and some one else, whose explanations are more to\r\nthe purpose, has been explaining.  Mrs Rowland, alarmed and shaken by\r\nher misery, has been acknowledging the whole series of falsehoods by\r\nwhich she persuaded, convinced her brother that you did not love him--\r\nthat you were, in fact, attached elsewhere.  I see how angry you are,\r\nHester.  I see you asking in your own mind how Enderby could be thus\r\ndeluded--how he could trust his sister rather than Margaret--how I can\r\nspeak of him as deserving to have her after all this.  Your questions\r\nare reasonable enough, love, and yet they cannot be answered.  Your\r\ndoubts of Enderby are reasonable enough; and yet I declare to you that\r\nhe is in my eyes almost, if not quite, blameless."\r\n\r\n"Thank you, brother!" said Margaret, looking up with swimming eyes.\r\n\r\n"There is one great point to be settled," resumed Hope: "and that is,\r\nwhether you will both be content to bury in silence the subject of this\r\nquarrel, from this hour, relying upon my testimony and Mrs Rowland\'s."\r\n\r\n"Oh, Edward, do not put your name and hers together!"\r\n\r\n"For Enderby\'s justification, and for Margaret\'s sake, my name shall be\r\njoined with the arch-fiend\'s, if necessary, my love.  You must, as I was\r\nsaying, rely upon the testimony of those who know the whole, that\r\nEnderby\'s conduct throughout has been, if not the very wisest and best,\r\nperfectly natural, and consistent with the love for Margaret which he\r\nhas cherished to this hour."\r\n\r\n"I knew it," murmured Margaret.\r\n\r\n"He will himself disclose as much as he thinks proper, when he comes:\r\nbut he comes full of fear and doubt about his reception."\r\n\r\nMargaret hung her head, feeling that it was well she was reminded what\r\nreason there was for his coming with doubt and trembling in his heart.\r\n\r\n"As he comes full of fear and doubt," resumed Hope, "I must tell you\r\nfirst that he never received your last letter, Margaret.  He thought you\r\nwould not answer his.  He thought you took him at his word about not\r\nattempting explanation."\r\n\r\n"What an unhappy accident!" cried Hester.  "Who carried that letter?\r\nHow did it happen?"\r\n\r\n"It was no accident, my dear.  Mrs Rowland burned that letter."\r\n\r\nMargaret covered her face with her hands; then, suddenly looking up, she\r\ncried:\r\n\r\n"Did she read it?"\r\n\r\n"No.  She says she dared not.  Why, Margaret, you seem sorry that she\r\ndid not!  You think it would have cleared you.  I have no doubt she\r\nthought so too; and that that was the reason why she averted her eyes\r\nfrom it.  Yes, it was a cruel injury, Margaret.  Can you forgive it, do\r\nyou think?"\r\n\r\n"Not to-night," said Hester.  "Do not ask it of her to-night."\r\n\r\n"I believe I may ask it at this very moment.  The happy can forgive.  Is\r\nit not so, Margaret?"\r\n\r\n"For myself I could and I do, brother.  I would go now and nurse her\r\nchild, and comfort her.  But--"\r\n\r\n"But you cannot forgive the wretchedness she has caused to Philip.\r\nWell, if you each forgive her for your own part, there is a chance that\r\nshe may yet lift up her humbled head."\r\n\r\n"What possessed her to hate us so?" said Hester.\r\n\r\n"Her hatred to us is the result of long habits of ill-will, of selfish\r\npride, and of low pertinacity about small objects.  That is the way in\r\nwhich I account for it all.  She disliked you first for your connection\r\nwith the Greys; and then she disliked me for my connection with you.\r\nShe nourished up all her personal feelings into an opposition to us and\r\nour doings; and when she had done this, and found her own only brother\r\ngoing over to the enemy, as she regarded it, her dislike grew into a\r\npassion of hatred.  Under the influence of this passion, she has been\r\nled on to say and to do more and more that would suit her purposes, till\r\nshe has found herself sunk in an abyss of guilt.  I really believe she\r\nwas not fully aware of her situation, till her misery of to-day revealed\r\nit to her."\r\n\r\n"Poor thing!" said Margaret.  "Is there nothing we can do to help her?"\r\n\r\n"We will ask Enderby.  I take hers to be no uncommon case.  The dislikes\r\nof low and selfish minds generally bear very much the character of hers,\r\nthough they may not be pampered by circumstances into such a luxuriance\r\nas in this case.  In a city, Mrs Rowland might have been an ordinary\r\nspiteful fine lady.  In such a place as Deerbrook, and with a family of\r\nrivals\' cousins incessantly before her eyes, to exercise her passions\r\nupon, she has ended in being--"\r\n\r\n"What she is," said Margaret, as Hope stopped for a word.\r\n\r\n"Margaret is less surprised than you expected, is she not?" said Hester.\r\n"You did not suppose that she would sit and listen as she does to your\r\nanalysis of Mrs Rowland.  But if the truth were known, she carries a\r\nprophecy about her on her finger.  I have no doubt she has been\r\nexpecting this very news ever since she recovered her ring.  Yes or no,\r\nMargaret?"\r\n\r\n"I should rather say she has carried a prophecy in her heart all these\r\nlong months," said Hope, "of which that on her finger is only the\r\nsymbol."\r\n\r\n"However it may be," said Hester, "it has prepared a reception for Mr\r\nEnderby.  There is no resisting a prophecy.  What is written is\r\nwritten."\r\n\r\n"I must hear him, you know," said Margaret, gently.\r\n\r\n"You must; and you must hear him favourably," said her brother.\r\n\r\n"I had forgotten," said Hester, ringing the bell.  "Morris, a good fire\r\nin the breakfast-room, immediately."\r\n\r\nWithin the hour, Philip and Margaret were by that fireside, finally\r\nwedded in heart and soul.  It was astonishing how little explanation was\r\nneeded when Margaret had once been told, in addition to the fact of her\r\nletter having been destroyed, that she was declared to have made Mrs\r\nEnderby the depository of her confidence about a prior attachment.\r\nThere was, however, as much to relate as there was little to explain.\r\nHow Enderby\'s heart burned within him, when, in sporting with the idea\r\nof a prior attachment, it came out what Margaret had felt at the moment\r\nof his intrusion upon the conference with Hope, of which he had since,\r\nas at the time, been so jealous! the amusement on her own part, and the\r\njoy on Hester\'s, which she was trying to conceal by her downcast looks!\r\nHow his soul melted within him when she owned her momentary regret at\r\nbeing saved from under the ice, and the consolation and stimulus she had\r\nderived from her brother\'s expression of affection for her on the spot!\r\nHow clear, how true a refutation were these revealings of the\r\nimputations that had been cast upon her! and how strangely had the facts\r\nbeen distorted by a prejudiced imagination!  How sweet in the telling\r\nwas the story of the ring, so sad in the experience! and the recountings\r\nof the times that they had seen each other of late.  Philip had caught\r\nmore glimpses than she.  He came down--he dared not say to watch over\r\nher in this time of sickness--but because he could not stay away when he\r\nheard of the condition of Deerbrook.  But for this sickness would they\r\nhave met--should they ever have understood each other again?  This was a\r\nspeculation on which they could not dwell--it led them too near the\r\nverge of the grave which was yawning for Matilda.  Mrs Rowland would\r\nhave been relieved, but the relief would have been not unmixed with\r\nhumiliation, if she could have known how easily she was let off in this\r\nlong conference.  Not only can the happy easily forgive, but they are\r\nexceedingly apt to forget the causes and the history of their woes; and\r\nthe wretched lady who, in the midst of her grief and terror for her\r\nchild, trembled at home at the image of the lovers she had injured, was,\r\nto those lovers in their happiness, much as if she had never existed.\r\n\r\n"Mrs Howell!" said Margaret, hearing her sister mention their departed\r\nneighbour, after Philip was gone.  "Is it possible that it was this very\r\nafternoon that I saw that poor woman die?"\r\n\r\n"Even so, dear.  How many days, or months, or years, have you lived\r\nsince?  A whole age of bliss, Margaret!"\r\n\r\nMargaret\'s blush said "Yes."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER FORTY SIX.\r\n\r\nDEERBROOK IN SUNSHINE.\r\n\r\nOn the first news of the fever being gone, the Greys returned to\r\nDeerbrook, and Dr Levitt\'s family soon followed.  The place wore a\r\nstrange appearance to those who had been absent for some time.  Large\r\npatches of grass overspread the main street, and cows might have\r\npastured on the thatch of some of the cottages, while the once green\r\nchurchyard looked brown and bare from the number of new graves crowded\r\nin among the old ones.  In many a court were the spring-flowers running\r\nwild over the weedy borders, for want of hands to tend them; and the\r\nbirds built in many a chimney from which the blue smoke had been wont to\r\nrise in the morning air.  Sophia and her sisters noted these things as\r\nthey walked through the place on the morning after their arrival, while\r\ntheir father was engaged in inspecting the parish register, to learn how\r\nmany of his neighbours were gone, and their mother was paying her visit\r\nof condolence to Mrs Rowland.\r\n\r\nFanny and Mary were much impressed this day with Matilda\'s death.  They\r\nhad first wondered, and then wept, when they heard of it at a distance:\r\nand now, when once more on the spot where they had seen her daily, and\r\nhad hourly criticised her looks, her sayings, and doings, they were\r\nunder a strong sense of the meanness and frivolity of their talk, and\r\nthe unkindness of their feelings about one whose faults could hardly be\r\ncalled her own, and who might now, they supposed, be living and moving\r\nin scenes and amidst circumstances whose solemnity and importance put to\r\nshame the petty intercourse they had carried on with her here.  Both\r\nresolved in their hearts that if Anna Rowland should praise her own\r\ndancing, and flatten her back before she spoke, and talk often of the\r\ntime when she should be married, they would let it all pass, and not\r\ntell mamma or Sophia, or exchange satirical looks with each other.  They\r\nremembered now that Matilda had done good and kind things, which had\r\nbeen disregarded at the time when they were bent on ridiculing her.  It\r\nwas just hereabouts that she took off her worsted gloves, one bitter day\r\nin the winter, and put them on the hands of her little brother who was\r\ncrying with cold; and it was by yonder corner that she directed a\r\nstranger gentleman into the right road so prettily that he looked after\r\nher as she walked away, and said she would be the pride of the place\r\nsome day.  Alas! there she lay--in the vault under the church; and she\r\nwould be no one\'s pride in this world, except in her poor mother\'s\r\nheart.\r\n\r\n"There is somebody not in mourning," cried Fanny; "the very first,\r\nbesides my cousins, that we have seen to-day.  Oh, it is Mrs James!\r\nShall we not speak to her?"\r\n\r\nMrs James seemed warmed out of her usual indifference.  She shook hands\r\nalmost affectionately with Sophia.  The meeting of acquaintances who\r\nfind themselves alive after a pestilence is unlike any other kind of\r\nmeeting: it animates the most indifferent, and almost makes friends of\r\nenemies.  While Mrs James and Sophia were making mutual inquiries, Mary\r\ncalled Fanny\'s attention to what was to be seen opposite.  There was a\r\nglittering row of large, freshly-gilt letters--"Miskin, late Howell,\r\nHaberdasher, etcetera."  Miss Miskin, in the deepest mourning, with a\r\ncountenance trained to melancholy, was peeping through the ribbons and\r\nhandkerchiefs which veiled her window, to see whether the Miss Greys\r\nwere on their way to her or not.  Sophia would not have been able to\r\nresist going in, but that, on parting from Mrs James, she saw the true\r\nobject of her morning walk approaching in the person of Mr Walcot.  Her\r\nintention had been to meet him in his rounds; and here he was.\r\n\r\nIf Mrs James had been almost affectionate, what was Mr Walcot?  He had\r\nreally gone through a great deal of anxiety and suffering lately, and\r\nhis heart was very soft and tender just now.  He turned about, and\r\nwalked with Sophia--walked a mile out into the country by her side, and\r\nneither seemed to have any thought of turning back, till Fanny reminded\r\nher sister how long mamma would have been kept waiting for her to go and\r\ncall on the Levitts.  The conversation had been in an under voice, all\r\nthe way out and back; but, when the parting was to take place, when Mr\r\nWalcot was to leave them in the outskirts of the village, the little\r\ngirls heard a few words, which threw some light on what had been\r\npassing.  They caught from Sophia, "I must consult my parents;" and as\r\nthey hurried homewards with her, they ventured to cast up a glance of\r\ndroll meaning into her face, which made her try to help smiling, and to\r\nspeak sharply; and then they knew that they had guessed the truth.\r\n\r\nMr Grey made his call upon his cousins that evening.  He requested some\r\nprivate conversation with Hope.  His objects were, to learn Hope\'s\r\nopinion of Mr Walcot, as he had seen him of late under very trying\r\ncircumstances; and, if this opinion should be sufficiently favourable to\r\nwarrant the proposition, to open the subject of a partnership--a\r\npartnership in which, as was fair, Mr Walcot should have a small share\r\nat present of the income, and a large proportion of the labour--which\r\nwas all that the young man, under the effect of his recent terrors, and\r\nof his veneration for Mr Hope, wished or desired.  He had declared that\r\nif he could obtain his beloved Sophia, and be permitted to rely on Mr\r\nHope as his partner and friend, he should be the happiest man alive; and\r\nhe was confident that his parents would consider him a most fortunate\r\nyouth, to be received, at his outset into life, into such a family as\r\nMr Grey\'s, and under the professional guidance of such a practitioner\r\nand such a man as Mr Hope.\r\n\r\nThere seemed to be every probability of his becoming the happiest man\r\nalive for the Greys were clearly well disposed towards him, and Mr Hope\r\nhad nothing to say of him which could hurt their feelings.  He repeated\r\nwhat he had declared to Mr Rowland--that Mr Walcot\'s energies seemed\r\nto be concentrated in the practice of his profession, and that his\r\nprofessional knowledge appeared to be sufficient.  There was no doubt of\r\nhis kindness of heart; and, though it could not be expected of him that\r\nhe would ever make a striking figure in the world, yet he might sustain\r\na fair portion of respectability and usefulness in a country station.\r\nAs to the partnership, no difficulty arose.  Mr Grey frankly explained\r\nthat present income was far less of an object than to have his daughter\r\nsettled beside her parents, and his son-in-law usefully and honourably\r\noccupied.  Sophia would have enough money to make Walcot\'s income an\r\naffair of inferior consideration.  If he should deserve an increase by\r\nand by, it would be all very well.  If not, the young people must get on\r\nwithout.  Anything was better than sending the young man away to\r\nestablish himself in a new place, with no happier prospects to Sophia\'s\r\nfamily than that of parting with her to a distance at last.\r\n\r\nIt did not require many days to complete the arrangements.  Hester was\r\nat first a little vexed, but on the whole much more amused, at the idea\r\nof her husband having Mr Walcot for a partner: and she soon saw the\r\nadvantage of his being spared many a long country ride, and many a visit\r\nat inconvenient seasons, by his junior being at hand.  She made no\r\nsubstantial objection, and invited Mr Walcot to the house with all due\r\ncordiality.  The young man\'s gratitude and devotion knew no bounds; and\r\nthe only trouble Hope felt in the business was the awkwardness of\r\nchecking his expressions of thankfulness.\r\n\r\nWhen the announcement of the double arrangement was to be made, Mrs\r\nGrey could not resist going herself to Mrs Rowland; and Sophia was\r\nsorry that she could not be present too, to see how the lady would\r\nreceive the news of a third gentleman marrying into the Greys\'\r\nconnection so decidedly.  But Mr Grey took care to enlighten his\r\npartner on the matter some hours before; so that Mrs Rowland was\r\nprepared.  She persuaded herself that she was very apathetic--that she\r\nhad no feelings left for the affairs of life--that her interests were\r\nall buried in the tomb of her own Matilda.  Mrs Grey had therefore\r\nnothing in particular to tell Sophia when she returned from paying the\r\nvisit.\r\n\r\nIn exchange for the news, Sir William and Lady Hunter sent back their\r\ncongratulations, and a very gracious and extensive invitation to dinner.\r\nFinding that Mrs Rowland\'s brother was really, with the approbation of\r\nhis family, going to marry Mrs Hope\'s sister, and that Mrs Rowland\'s\r\n_protege_ was entering into partnership with Mr Hope himself, they\r\nthought it the right time to give their sanction to the reconciliations\r\nwhich were taking place, by being civil to all the parties round.  So\r\nLady Hunter came in state to Deerbrook, one fine day, made all due\r\napologies, and invited to dinner the whole connection.  Mrs Rowland\r\ncould not go, of course; and Margaret declined: but all the rest went.\r\nMargaret was on the eve of her marriage, and she preferred one more day\r\nwith Maria, to a visit of ceremony.  She begged Philip to go, as his\r\nsister could not; and he obeyed with a good grace, grudging the loss of\r\na sweet spring evening over Sir William Hunter\'s dinner-table the less,\r\nthat he knew Margaret and Maria were making the best use of it together.\r\n\r\nOnce more the friends sat in the summer-house, by the window, whence\r\nthey loved to look abroad upon meadow, wood, and stream.  Here they had\r\nstudied together, and cherished each other: here they had eagerly\r\nimparted a multitude of thoughts, and carefully concealed a few.  Here\r\nthey were now conversing together for the last time before their\r\napproaching separation.
