Maria sighed often, as she well might: and when\r\nMargaret looked abroad upon the bean-setters in the distant field, and\r\nlistened to the bleat of the lambs which came up from the pastures, and\r\nwas aware of the scent of the hyacinths occasionally wafted in from poor\r\nMatilda\'s neighbouring flower-plot, she sighed too.\r\n\r\n"You must take some of our hyacinths with you to London, and see whether\r\nthey will not blossom there," said Maria, answering to her friend\'s\r\nthought.\r\n\r\n"I hardly know whether there would be most pain or pleasure in seeing\r\nplants sprout, and then wither, in the little balcony of a back\r\ndrawing-room, which overlooks gables or stables, instead of these\r\ndelicious green meadows."\r\n\r\n"How fond you were, two years ago, of imagining the bliss of living\r\nalways in sight of this very landscape!  Yet it has yielded already to\r\nthe back drawing-room, with a prospect of stables and gables."\r\n\r\n"We shall come and look upon your woods sometimes, you know.  I am not\r\nbidding good-bye to this place, or to you.  God forbid!"\r\n\r\n"Now tell me, Margaret," said Maria, after a pause, "tell me when you\r\nare to be married."\r\n\r\n"That is what I was just about to do.  We go on Tuesday."\r\n\r\n"Indeed! in three days!  But why should it not be so?  It is a weary\r\ntime since you promised first."\r\n\r\n"A year ago, there were reasons, as Philip admits now, why I could not\r\nleave Hester and Edward.  There are no such reasons now.  They are\r\nprosperous: their days of struggle, when they wanted me--my head, my\r\nhands, my little income--are past.  Edward\'s practice has come back to\r\nhim, with increase for Mr Walcot.  There is nothing more to fear for\r\nthem."\r\n\r\n"You have done your duty by them: now--"\r\n\r\n"_My_ duty!  What has it been to theirs?  Oh, Maria! what a spectacle\r\nhas that been!  When I think how they have `overcome evil with good,\'\r\nhow they have endured, how forgiven, how toiled and watched on their\r\nenemies\' behalf, till they have ruled all the minds, and touched all the\r\nhearts, of friends and foes for miles round, I think theirs the most\r\ngracious piece of tribulation that ever befell.  At home,--Oh, even you\r\ndo not know what a home it is!"\r\n\r\nNor was Margaret herself aware what that home was now.  She saw how\r\nEdward had there, too, `overcome evil with good\' how he had permanently\r\nestablished Hester in her highest moods of mind, strengthened her to\r\novercome the one unhappy tendency from which she had suffered through\r\nthe whole of her life, and dispersed all storms from the dwelling\r\nwherein his child was to grow up: but she did not know half the extent\r\nof his victory, or the delight of its rewards.  She knew nothing of the\r\nsecret shudder with which he looked back upon the entanglement, the\r\nperil, the suffering he had gone through; or of the deep peace which had\r\nsettled down upon his soul, now that the struggle was well past.  She\r\nlittle imagined how, when all the world regarded him as an old married\r\nman, his was now, in truth, the soul of the lover: how, from having at\r\none time pitied, feared, recoiled from her with whom he had connected\r\nhimself for life, he had risen, by dint of a religious discharge of duty\r\ntowards her, from self-reproach and mere compassion, to patience, to\r\nhope, to interest, to admiration, to love--love at last worthy of hers--\r\nlove which satisfied even Hester\'s imperious affections, and set even\r\nher over-busy mind and heart at rest.  Little did Margaret imagine all\r\nthis.  There was but one, beside Edward himself, who knew it; and that\r\none was Morris, who daily thanked God that strength had been given\r\naccording to the need.\r\n\r\n"There is but one person in the world, Maria," said her friend, "on\r\nwhose account I cannot help being anxious.  I was faithless about Hester\r\nas long as it was possible to have an uneasy thought for her; and now I\r\nam afraid I shall sin in the same way about you."\r\n\r\n"And why should you, Margaret?  If I were without object, without hope,\r\nwithout experience, without the power of self-rule which such experience\r\ngives, you might well fear for me.  But why now?  It is not reasonable\r\ntowards the Providence under which we live; it is not just to me."\r\n\r\n"That is very true.  But though it is not too much for your faith, that\r\nyou are infirm and suffering in body, poor, solitary, living by toil,\r\nwithout love, without prospect--though all this may not be too much for\r\nyour faith, Maria, I own it is at times for mine."\r\n\r\n"Of all these evils, there is but one which is very hard to bear.  I\r\n_am_ solitary; and the suffering from the sense of this is great.  But\r\nwhat has been borne may be borne; and this evil is precisely that which\r\nhas been the peculiar trial of the greatest and best of their race--or\r\nof those who have been recognised as such.  You will not suppose that I\r\ntry to flatter my pride with this thought; or that the most insane pride\r\ncould be a support under this kind of suffering.  I mean only that there\r\ncan be nothing morally fatal in a trial which many of the wisest and\r\nbest have sustained."\r\n\r\n"But it is painful--very painful."\r\n\r\n"For the mere pain, let it pass; and for the other _desagremens_ of my\r\nlot, let us not dare to speak evil of them, lest we should be slandering\r\nmy best friends.  If infirmity, toil, poverty, and the foibles of people\r\nabout us, all go to fortify us in self-reliance, God forbid that we\r\nshould quarrel with them!"\r\n\r\n"But are you sure, quite sure, that you can stand the discipline? that\r\nyour nerves, as well as your soul, can endure?"\r\n\r\n"Far from sure: but my peril is less than it was; and I have, therefore,\r\nevery hope of victory at last.  In my wilderness, some tempter or\r\nanother comes, at times when my heart is hungry, and my faith is\r\nfainting, and shows me such a lot as yours--all the sunny kingdoms of\r\nlove and hope given into your hand--and then the desert of my lot looks\r\ndreary enough for the moment; but then arises the very reasonable\r\nquestion, why we should demand that one lot should, in this exceedingly\r\nsmall section of our immortality, be as happy as another: why we cannot\r\neach husband our own life and means without wanting to be all equal.\r\nLet us bless Heaven for your lot, by all means; but why, in the name of\r\nProvidence, should mine be like it?  Nay, Margaret, why these tears?\r\nFor their sake I will tell you--and then we shall have talked quite\r\nenough about me--that you are no fair judge of my lot.  You see me\r\noften, generally, in the midst of annoyance, and you do not (because no\r\none can) look with the eye of my mind upon the future.  If you could,\r\nfor one day and night, feel with my feelings, and see through my\r\neyes--."\r\n\r\n"Oh, that I could!  I should be the holier for ever after?"\r\n\r\n"Nay, nay! but if you could do this, you would know, from henceforth,\r\nthat there are glimpses of heaven for me in solitude, as for you in\r\nlove; and that it is almost as good to look forward without fear of\r\nchance or change, as with such a flutter of hope as is stirring in you\r\nnow.  So much for the solitaries of the earth, and because Providence\r\nshould be justified of his children.  Now, when is this family meeting\r\nto take place in the corner-house?"\r\n\r\n"Frank hopes to land in August; and Anne, Mrs Gilchrist, will meet him\r\nas soon as she can hear, in her by-corner of the world, of his arrival.\r\nThe other sister is still abroad, and cannot come.  I hope Anne may be a\r\nfriend to you--an intimate.  Judging by her brothers, and her own\r\nletters, I think she must be worthy."\r\n\r\n"Thank you; but you are, and ever will be, my intimate.  There can be no\r\nother.  We shall be often seeing you here."\r\n\r\n"Sometimes; and we shall have you with us."\r\n\r\n"No: I cannot come to London.  I shall never leave this place again, I\r\nbelieve; but you will be often coming to it.  When that crowd of new\r\ngraves in the churchyard shall be waving with grass, and those old woods\r\nlooking more ancient still, and the grown people of Deerbrook telling\r\ntheir little ones all about the pestilence that swept the place at the\r\nend of the great scarcity, when _they_ were children, you and yours, and\r\nperhaps I, may sit, a knot of grey-headed friends, and hear over again\r\nabout those good old days of ours, as we shall then call them."\r\n\r\n"And tell how there was an aged man, who told us of his seeing the deer\r\ncome down through the forest to drink at the brook.  I should like to\r\nbehold those future days."\r\n\r\n"And to remember whose face you saw in the torchlight, at the time and\r\nplace of your hearing the old man\'s tale.  Whose horse do I hear\r\nstopping at the stable?"\r\n\r\n"It is Philip\'s.  He has galloped home before the rest," said Margaret,\r\ndrawing back from the window with the smile still upon her face.  "Now,\r\nMaria, before any one comes, tell me--would you like to be with me on\r\nTuesday morning or not?  Do as you like."\r\n\r\n"I will come, to be sure," said Maria, smiling.  "And now, while there\r\nis any twilight left, go and give Mr Enderby the walk in the shrubbery\r\nthat he galloped home for."\r\n\r\nMargaret kept Philip waiting while she lighted her friend\'s lamp; and\r\nits gleam shone from the window of the summer-house for long, while,\r\ntalking of Maria, the lovers paced the shrubbery, and let the twilight\r\ngo.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of the Project Gutenberg EBook of Deerbrook, by Harriet Martineau\r\n\r\n*** END OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK DEERBROOK ***\r\n\r\n***** This file should be named 24210.txt or 24210.zip *****\r\nThis and all associated files of various formats will be found in:\r\n        http://www.gutenberg.org/2/4/2/1/24210/\r\n\r\nProduced by Nick Hodson of London, England\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions\r\nwill be renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from public domain print editions means that no\r\none owns a United States copyright in these works, so the Foundation\r\n(and you!) can copy and distribute it in the United States without\r\npermission and without paying copyright royalties.
